PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the $2m package of assistance to South African groups, including approximately $80,000 direct to the African National Congress (ANC), announced by the Minister during his recent visit to South Africa. I ask: when is it appropriate to apply Australian taxpayers' funds to an overseas political movement? If the economic policy measures included in the package are as important as the Minister has said, why did the ANC fail to allocate to these purposes any of the $15m placed at its disposal by the Australian Government last year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is based on a false premise because the $15m that was announced last year as a three-year development assistance package was not in the form of money given directly to the ANC for any purpose it chose. As has been amply documented on the public record, that money has all-to the extent that it has already been allocated-been arranged to be administered by non-government organisations or persons other than the ANC itself. It is for a variety of purposes, including training and education and the repatriation of exiles coming back into the country who manifestly need assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: The reason why taxpayers' money in the form of aid funds has been devoted both to that $15m package of measures that were certainly agreed in consultation with the ANC in terms of the direction in which they have been allocated and to the additional $2m package which was the subject of detailed announcement by me in South Africa last week, devoted specifically to the purposes of economic planning capacity assistance, is simply that we are engaged here not in the task, obviously, of assisting one political organisation in some looming partisan battle with other political organisations within a country but in the task of assisting a country which is in the process of nation-building.

We are talking about a country which for all practical purposes has denied 28 million of its 38 million citizens any rights in the active participation in the affairs of that country. They have had no political voice. They have had no role in the institutional structures of the government, and the implications of that in terms of the Third World status those people now live in is there for anyone who visits the country to see. It is a deeply depressing spectacle.

What we are engaged in is assistance in the process of developing what is, for all practical purposes, a brand new nation-a nation not with 10 million participating citizens but with 38 million participating citizens. The assistance that is being given is quintessentially, classically, development assistance, so defined, so regarded, by the international agencies that monitor these things; and we make absolutely no apology for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I pursue further the answer to the second part of my question, which the Minister answered first. Is it not the case that about $13 1/2m of the $15m that the Australian Government agreed to apply was for projects to be approved by the ANC, agreed over a period of three years? I therefore ask again: why did not the ANC, in negotiating with the Australian Government on the projects which it saw to be of priority, reach the same conclusions as the Minister did when he recently visited South Africa?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifteen million dollars was for projects defined in consultation with the ANC, not approved by it. The projects were essentially of a humanitarian kind but did have, in many instances, an education and training component. The particular more recent supplementary package of $2m, which will be the subject of a supplementary appropriation and which does not in any way involve the redirection of existing aid funds, represents a wholly new policy concept-one that was devised, initiated and stimulated by the Prime Minister himself in the form of a team of economists, led by Professor Garnaut, that he sent to South Africa and asked to report to him and to the Australian Government on the ways in which we could assist the post-apartheid South African economy to in fact take off in an environment where participating in the policy making process would be a completely different group of people than had been the case previously and where it was manifestly important that those new policy makers, decision makers and economic administrators have a sound and solid grasp and standing in economic policy matters.

ANSWER.PARA: It is still a development assistance exercise but a development exercise of a rather unique and distinctive kind and one which the Prime Minister should take full credit for devising. I acknowledge his role in this respect. It is a particular package of measures which was extremely well received in South Africa right across the whole spectrum-not only within the liberation movements themselves but also in the white business community, which saw much more clearly than the Opposition is capable of the point of this particular package of measures. It was also well received by the Government Ministers to whom I spoke and to whom I advised the general content of this package before it was publicly announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport, is prompted by calls from a road trauma expert for the introduction of improved safety features in Australian motor vehicles. Taking into account the financial and personal cost of road accidents, does the Government have any plans for the introduction of safety features, such as air bags, anti-locking brakes and better seat belts, as standard equipment in Australian motor vehicles?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport has provided me with the following response, which honourable senators may be interested in hearing-it was news to me. The fact is that Australia's road safety record is among the best in the world. Australia has a lower rate of fatalities per 10,000 vehicles than any other country. In terms of fatalities per 100,000 head of population, Australia's safety record is just behind that of the United Kingdom and Sweden.

ANSWER.PARA: Last year, road deaths in Australia were slashed by 468, or 17 per cent; in the first five months of this year fatalities are down by 52, or 6 per cent on the same period in 1990. In the past 18 months or so, the Federal Government has taken a number of initiatives to improve the safety of all Australians on our roads. It called upon all States and Territories to adopt a 10-point package of road safety measures relating, among other things, to speed, alcohol consumption and the provision of more time for young drivers to gain experience under controlled conditions.

The Federal Government has also allocated $110m to get rid of 2,000 to 3,000 of the worst accident black spots in Australia. The National Road Trauma Advisory Council has been established to provide advice from a panel of eminent Australians to the Federal and State governments on road safety.

In 1989, for the first time, the Government took responsibility for Australian vehicle safety standards and these standards are among the most stringent in the world. Australia has led the world in a number of safety areas, such as seat belts and safety requirements for forward controlled passenger vehicles. The Government is determined that Australia will maintain its position at the forefront of international developments in vehicle safety.

The Government asked the Monash University Accident Research Centre to examine how Australian vehicles were performing in real life crashes with a view to identifying areas for improvement. Its report recommends the examination of a number of measures to improve occupant protection, and the provision of air bags is one of them. A high level committee is considering the report. It includes Federal, State and Territory motor vehicle industry and consumer representatives. The objective will be to achieve the most cost-effective protection against the background of our high seat belt wearing rates.

In recent years, dramatic developments in seat belt and other technology have offered an alternative to air bags. All round, seat belts provide the cheapest and most effective protection. Air bags are only totally effective in frontal crashes. They do not help in other types of crashes where seat belts are effective. The cost of air bags is still high in spite of the economies of scale. Air bags have to be engineered into a vehicle from the early design stages. They are not simply add-on options.

We will proceed rationally to analyse all the options before we come to a decision in this complex area. The Government has put into place a comprehensive test and research program to determine the real facts and the most cost-effective way to ensure that the level of safety enjoyed by Australian motorists continues to be at the forefront of international standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It follows the response that he gave to Senator Hill's question earlier this afternoon. What is the Government's total commitment to the African National Congress (ANC)? Is it correct that the Government has committed more than the $15m referred to and more than the $2m supplementary grant that has been referred to? How much more? What is the total? What special checks does the Australian Government have in place to ensure that the money is used by the ANC for the purposes for which it is granted?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The total direct commitment to the ANC that we made is $83,000 for the establishment of an economic planning department within the ANC, in terms and circumstances that were fully described in the text of my announcement. In terms of moneys allocated, following consultations with the ANC, the total commitment, so far as I can recall, is just the $15m over three years that was announced last year. It should be understood that the $2m that is the subject of the current announcement is not really money to be regarded as even allocated in consultation with the ANC in the same way as the $15m announced last year was.

ANSWER.PARA: The other elements in this particular economic planning assistance program involve the establishment of an institute of economic research at a selected university, a number of consultancies, visits to Australia and upgrading training at university for black economists whose training hitherto may have been only in Eastern European universities or the University of Sussex or other such equivalent institutions. That kind of program is one that will be implemented in a variety of ways and, although it has been the subject of some generalised consultation with the ANC, it has also been the subject of consultation with government officials, with economists in the private sector in South Africa and particularly economists working in a number of tertiary institutions. It is really not at all accurate to call that latter sum of $2m which I announced last week as being ANC-related money in the same way as it is possible to describe the $15m that I referred to earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister did not refer to the second half of my question, which I now repeat: what special checks does the Australian Government have in place to ensure that the money is used by the ANC or by any of the others receiving these moneys that have been referred to for the purpose for which it is granted? Is it correct that the only audits carried out are internal ANC audits?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true so far as my present understanding and recollection is concerned. There is quite an elaborate system of auditing involved with all Australian International Development Assistance Bureau moneys that are expended. It varies depending on whether the moneys in question are spent through particular non-government organisations, such as the Australian People for Health, Education and Development Abroad-which does have a significant role in relation to some aspects of this South African money-whether it goes directly to government, as is often the case in the South Pacific and South East Asia and so on, but not so much the case in the South African context, or whether it goes directly to Australian private firms and so on that are contracted directly for particular program purposes.

ANSWER.PARA: The auditing arrangements differ in each case depending on the nature of the moneys paid, but they are substantial and effective. I will be happy to provide further information to the honourable senator on the specific means by which it is proposed to audit the moneys to which I have referred in this answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In the light of continuing concerns about the environment and the beneficial effects to industry and the community generally to be gained from recycling waste materials, can the Minister tell the Senate what the Government is doing to encourage the development of new environment management technologies and to implement them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot do a great deal about these things by means of direct intervention, but it is important that the Government act as a catalyst in bringing people together in industries such as this. The Government recognises the importance of this industry, as does the Opposition, I suspect. When I spoke to a seminar of this industry about two weeks ago the Opposition was represented at that seminar by its shadow spokesman for the environment, Mr Chaney.

ANSWER.PARA: The world market for the management of waste is estimated to be about $200 billion a year. We believe that this provides many opportunities for Australian industry, both domestically and in overseas markets. For that reason, the Government has made waste and environmental management a generic technology under the industry research and development program. Grants have been made under that program to companies such as BHP, Australian Newsprint Mills, Associated Pulp and Paper Mills, Pasminco and Caltex. A wide range of inquiries about this industry are made on a State basis. The waste and environmental management technology committee was very impressed by the quality of the applications from various States.

I referred in my opening remarks to a seminar which took place in Canberra a couple of weeks ago. It is proposed to hold seminars in particular sectors to identify gaps in technologies and to invite proposals relating to processing of agricultural commodities, recycling of plastics and recycling alternatives to land fills. These seminars will take place over the next few months in various States. The important thing about them is that they bring participants in waste management technologies together. There are a number of Australian companies interested in this issue and capable of obtaining a slice of the international market.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I preface my question by noting that Australia's export performance is hampered by multinational parent companies prohibiting competition between subsidiaries. Firstly, how can a foreign takeover which will affect approximately 25 per cent of the sugar market by a firm involved in price rigging in Britain not be contrary to the national interest? Secondly, what are the specific reasons for the Treasurer's finding that the proposal by Tate and Lyle to acquire Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd is not against the national interest? Thirdly, given that the Treasurer has the power to impose any conditions on foreign investment proposals, what conditions have been imposed on the Tate and Lyle bid? Fourthly, if no conditions have been imposed, why not? Finally, if the takeover is not contrary to the national interest, what benefits will accrue to the nation, given that the Queensland Government, which regulates the sugar industry, is opposed to the acquisition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —At last Senator Spindler has enlightened some Opposition senators from Queensland. Let me say, firstly, that the Foreign Investment Review Board has approved Tate and Lyle's application to make a takeover offer for Bundaberg Sugar Co. Ltd. The question of whether that takeover is successful or not will now be determined by the existing shareholders of the company. That is a matter which is appropriate for the marketplace to determine. Whether this is in the national interest or not has been determined by the Foreign Investment Review Board in its granting of the application to make an offer for Bundaberg Sugar.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Spindler prefaced his question by suggesting it was a fact that a number of foreign companies operating in Australia operate export franchise arrangements that prevent their Australian subsidiaries from exporting to overseas countries in this region in particular; those subsidiaries have been prohibited by their parent companies from doing that. Certainly instances of that have historically taken place in Australia. I think there are fewer instances of that now than there were a few years ago, largely because of some exposure of these practices and some pressure being put on overseas companies in relation to their export activities from Australian subsidiaries.

In respect of the specific questions about the terms and the conditions of the Foreign Investment Review Board's approval, I will seek an early answer from the Treasurer and will provide it as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question: in view of the Minister's answer to my question, would the Minister consider changing the test of `not contrary to the national interest' to `net economic benefit to the nation' when foreign investment propositions are being assessed? Would the Government be prepared to legislate accordingly?

—That is a question which should be on the agenda because `national interest' is not a well-defined concept; neither is `net economic benefit'. I do not want to enter into this discussion, but I will certainly raise that issue with the Treasurer for Senator Spindler.
—Why do you ignore the Queensland Government?

—Senator Macdonald asks why we have ignored the Queensland Government. That is not true. The views of the Queensland Government were certainly taken into account, as they always are in matters of this kind. Senator Macdonald should not be surprised about that. I frequently take his views into account and then discard them.
—Is the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support able to tell the Senate of the current state of progress in the transfer of responsibilities for regional aerodromes to local authorities?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in the fortunate position of being able to officiate at a ceremony in Adelaide last week where, on behalf of the Federal Government, I handed over all the airports-with the full support of the South Australian Local Government Association (LGA)-plus a cheque to assist that Association to provide maintenance grants for local operators to enable them to operate those aerodromes in the future. As a result of that agreement with the South Australian Local Government Association and a number of local authorities, the Whyalla Airport was transferred to the City of Whyalla, and the mayor of that city presented me in return with a 10-pound red snapper.
—Did you declare it?

—No, I told him I was glad it was the Mayor of Whyalla who was giving me the dead fish rather than the Mafia. Unfortunately, I was not able to take the fish back to Darwin with me; nevertheless, the local community was extremely pleased to get its airport.

ANSWER.PARA: As well as Whyalla, the 17 remaining South Australian airports withdrew from the aerodrome local ownership plan (ALOP). This transfer and withdrawal is an excellent example of cooperative effort between the Commonwealth Government and State and local governments. The basis of the agreement is that the Commonwealth has paid a total of $1.596m to the LGA, which will distribute payments to aerodromes on behalf of the Commonwealth. These payments are for airport maintenance expenditure purposes. A small amount of money will be retained by the Local Government Association for the administration of this scheme. Negotiations between the LGA and the South Australian Government concerning State Government support are continuing and the outcome of those negotiations is expected shortly.

This completes the transfer and withdrawal of airports in South Australia, with the single exception of Gawler. In addition, another 28 airports have withdrawn from the ALOP: five in New South Wales, 17 in Queensland, three in Western Australia, two in the Northern Territory, and one other in South Australia. These withdrawals have occurred since the new policy was announced in August 1990. As well, four Commonwealth airports have transferred to full local ownership and agreement has been reached on another one to transfer early in 1991-92. Officers of my Department have visited some 90 other local authorities to discuss the new policy and negotiate full local ownership with local communities. These visits will continue until all airports have been visited and the new policy explained to the relevant local authority.

The revised policy provides for the access and equity needs of smaller remote communities. The Government will provide social benefits subsidies where necessary to maintain a reasonable standard of social amenities at airports. When airport transfers or withdrawal to full local ownership are completed the Government will cease the collection of landing charges at the airport, allowing the new owners to develop their own charging regimes in line with the operating costs of each individual airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to various accounts given by the Minister in relation to his reported obscene abuse of officials in South Africa. Is it the case that the Minister used the expression-and I will censor myself-`f . . . ing useless' on two occasions: once to a police sergeant driving him, to whom he said, `You're f . . . ing useless. All the cops are f . . . ing useless. Who do they think they are?'; and on a second occasion to a police lieutenant opening a door for him at the airport in Cape Town, to whom he said, `You didn't impress me with your show. You're f . . . ing useless.'? How does the Minister justify this appalling behaviour whilst representing Australia abroad? Has he apologised yet to the South African officials involved?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did have one sharp exchange with the South African security official who was in charge of the arrangements for my first visit to a South African township complex. The circumstances of that exchange should be put on the record because it has been the subject of a massive amount of disinformation. The context was this: I had arranged to have a visit to the township complex of Crossroads and Khayelitsha outside Cape Town-a depressing spectacle for anyone who has any shred of decency or feeling about them because of the scale of the poverty and the immensity of the deprivation of the people there. It was an important visit to make and I wanted to make it in the company and with the guidance of two community workers-one black, one white-associated with a particular self-help program which the Embassy had been assisting.

ANSWER.PARA: In order to enable the visit to take place on that basis it was agreed-and this agreement was confirmed the night before with the security authorities-that the visit would be on a low key and unobtrusive basis with a minimal police presence. Namely, it would consist of three cars: me and my wife with the two community workers in the front car, an unmarked police car immediately behind, and a third car with other Australian officials.

There was an unresolved question as to whether there would be a camera crew going with us. That was resolved in favour of their exclusion the following morning when we discussed it with Alan Boesak, who said that the volatility of the situation in the township was such that it would be most unwise to draw that additional degree of attention to ourselves. That was understood and agreed with the Australian media accompanying us.

It was on that basis that we climbed into the cars from the agreed meeting point and set off. For reasons that still remain somewhat unclear but may have been, conceivably, the result of some failure of communication between the South Africans and ourselves-but that certainly was not apparent at the time because the agreement had been reached only the night before and there had been no further developments in terms of a worsening security situation on the ground-those arrangements went completely haywire. We had not got very far into the townships before that initial three-car convoy was joined by six or seven others, complete with people wired for sound in a variety of ways and, unequivocally, members of the South African security forces of one kind or another-either the township police or the security forces more generally.

The media, having seen this circus parade developing, decided that all bets were off and joined in as well. So we had something like 10 cars when we made the first stop. It was at that point that I realised for the first time what was going on. An attempt to talk to local people suddenly became totally impossible because there were security people everywhere and at that point the whole visit had to be aborted. I was extremely angry about that situation developing in that way. I was angry for two reasons, the first being that I wanted the visit to be conducted in a low key and unobtrusive way because I believe that visits of this kind should not be zoo inspections: that the dignity of people ought to be respected and that their private space should not be invaded to any greater extent than is inevitable by any visit of that kind. I have a very strong view to that effect-a view manifestly not shared by those insensitive souls opposite but one that I happen to take very seriously. A much more important consideration even than that was my concern not to prejudice in any way the position of the two community workers involved. They had made it very clear indeed to me beforehand that their effectiveness-to put the point at its most mild-would be very much diminished within the community if they were seen in the presence of a large scale contingent of security people. Even those people opposite should be able to understand the dynamics that are at work in those communities and the sensitivity of people being associated with that kind of situation.

That is the reason that I was upset. That is the reason why, when we returned to the airport and the security officer in charge of arrangements came into a private room at the airport in which the only other person present, to my recollection, was the Australian Ambassador, I engaged in what I readily acknowledge was a very sharp exchange indeed. Whether I used the particular words in question I cannot recall. The emphasis-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections.

— I never denied that I may have used the particular swear word in question; that is not unknown in my private vocabulary in situations of intense stress. I did not deny that at any stage and I do not deny it now. I have no recollection of using the word `useless'. I appreciate that, for an Afrikaner Calvinist, that is probably the most extreme form of insult of all. But the nub of my objection was not the uselessness of the security service but its over-exuberance, its over-presence and its breach of a very specific agreement that had been reached. The concept that was advanced thereafter in the media, that the security service was doing no more than acting in my interests to protect me and that therefore it was entirely unreasonable for it to be responded to in this way, completely misses the point that this was an agreement reached jointly with the security service beforehand.

ANSWER.PARA: The point I make is that the exchange that did occur was one that was made in private, in the circumstances that I have described-in a private room at the airport with no more than one other person within earshot, namely, the Australian Ambassador. The only reason that that exchange-which was, on all the evidence available to me at the time, a thoroughly justified exchange-became public was because of a deliberate leak to the media by the South African security establishment and, moreover, a deliberate leak in terms that were highly prejudicial to me and completely ignored the context in which the exchange had occurred.

The Australian media, and obviously the Opposition, thereafter allowed the agenda to be set for it in its reading of the situation by the combined efforts of the South African security establishment and the more paranoid elements of the South African media. It was only obviously a matter of time before that kind of thing, put into the media, became a lightning rod, as I have said publicly since I have returned, to attract oceans of the kind of angst and resentment that have long been felt against Australia by white South Africans, and the rest of the trip proceeded on that basis.

But that is the context which should be understood and that is the reading of the situation that any reasonable non-cringing observer of the scene, anyone who believes that diplomacy should be conducted not on one's back or belly but on one's two feet, would in fact have.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I ask the Minister, not in his role as a sensitive soul who was angry and upset but as Australia's Foreign Minister-and, by the way, a Foreign Minister who cannot recall this situation: does the use of this language, which he has been prepared almost to admit, enhance Australia's or his reputation abroad; does he regret it; and will he apologise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have the use of strong language in private to someone who, I think it would be reasonably well understood, would not be hearing such language for the first time, in circumstances which I have described, where not only had an organisational arrangement gone awry, which would no doubt not have justified such a reaction, but where an agreement had been breached and where the agreement in question was one that was of immense significance for the futures of two people for whom I had the greatest respect. In those circumstances, I believe the exchange was justified.

ANSWER.PARA: I regret-and I said this to Pik Botha-that there was this degree of unpleasantness. I regret very much that the South African security establishment and the South African media chose to make of it what they did. I regret even more that the Australian media and the Opposition chose to take such an attitude towards it and not make their own objective and independent assessment. I also said to Pik Botha on the subject of apologies-and there was no grovelling or abject approach by me in relation to this-in addition to the fact that I--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I would ask you to call the Minister to order. He should answer Senator Baume's questions and apologise, or sit down before he embarrasses this country further.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—The remaining point that I was making is that I said to Mr Botha that if--
—So, you would do it all again if you got half the chance, would you?
—Order!

—I am just giving honourable senators the complete story because I have absolutely nothing to apologise for in terms of the way this situation was handled, given the context which I have explained. In the course of my final, very amicable exchange with Mr Botha at the airport-he was not sent there to chew my ear; it had not been the subject, as reported, of any Cabinet discussion; and this incident occupied perhaps five minutes of a one hour discussion-I did say, in addition to obviously regretting the unpleasantness that had been associated with the whole thing, that if it should be the case that any aspect of what went wrong on that day was the product of some communication error on our part or some other contribution on our part such that the responsibility for the fiasco that occurred was not wholly attributable to the South African security police concerned, then, of course, it would be appropriate under those circumstances for an apology to go to them. They were the terms in which I spoke to Mr Botha and they were the terms in which, in a slightly liberal fashion, that was reported to the media.

—Is the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs aware of continuing community concern about the degree of vigour and, in some cases, violence used by the police teams which conduct raids on premises in relation to criminal investigations? What action is being taken at a national level to allay public concern on this issue and to ensure that essential investigative work is conducted with maximum possible restraint?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of the level of concern in the community about the use of force by police in raids which are connected with their investigation of suspected criminal activity or in their attempts to apprehend those who are engaging in such activity. Particularly because of the nature of the work of these special squads-the tactical response squads or the special weapons squads-around the Commonwealth, I believe there is widespread concern about their operations and a general concern that they should be restrained as much as possible in the force that they use.

ANSWER.PARA: This is mainly a matter for commissioners of police in the States and Territories. However, I am concerned because many of these squads form the backbone of those response groups for terrorists incidents, and the Federal Government involves itself in some funding for training and equipment for these particular squads.

I am pleased to be able to tell the Senate that the Australian Police Ministers Council, meeting here in Canberra some fortnight ago, when dealing with the question of the use of force by police tactical response squads and special weapons squads throughout Australia, determined that there should be a putting together of a uniform set of guidelines. The police commissioners throughout Australia requested that this be done. Therefore, at both the police and political level there is a commitment to the production of these uniform guidelines.

Naturally, I acknowledge the fact that when police are in a very dangerous situation they are of course entitled to use such force as is necessary in their self-defence or in the defence of innocent members of the community. In extremely perilous situations, they can be very vulnerable to violence, particularly when they are confronting a criminal or suspect who is armed and shows some willingness to use a weapon.

But there is also no doubt-and this came from the recommendations of the National Committee on Violence-that there is a need for training which emphasises that violence ought to be used by police forces as an absolute last resort. Maximum restraint ought to be used up to the absolute limit where it becomes necessary for the police to use violence or even weapons in a particular instance. I believe these various concerns can be accommodated in a very clearly drafted set of guidelines. I believe the police commissioners will, with their particular squads, work on these guidelines in a way which can be brought to the Ministers for endorsement in September or October of this year so that throughout the Australian community we can have absolute confidence-as we ought to have-in our police forces when they use maximum or lethal force in particular situations where they are confronted by a violent criminal or suspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister for Aviation Support to the current Lions Convention which is being held in Brisbane this week and which is expected to bring 40,000 overseas visitors. Is he aware of the gross inadequacy of the Brisbane International Airport terminal and the need to erect a tent on the tarmac to assist in the processing of these visitors? Is he also aware of a recent Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) survey which showed that Brisbane had the second highest growth rate in Australia for international passengers? Further, has his attention been drawn to talks between the Prime Minister and the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, about the urgency for a new terminal in Brisbane, and will he consider urging the Federal Airports Corporation at this week's board meeting to approve that a new terminal be started without delay?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Bjelke-Petersen did not imply any criticism of the adequacy of the domestic airport terminal in Brisbane. The Federal Airports Corporation has embarked on an extremely ambitious and wide-ranging program of capital improvements to airport infrastructure around Australia. There is in excess of $700m already committed for that infrastructure. That will exceed some $2 billion before 1998. Part of that infrastructure is a new international airport terminal for Brisbane, which will cost in excess of $300m.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the concerns about the Lions Convention in Brisbane. I do not have a recent-that is, within the last week-brief on the stage discussions have reached on that matter, but I am aware that the Federal Airports Corporation has engaged in discussions with the organisers of that convention about temporary facilities should they be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is temporary.

—In response to the honourable senator's interjection, that particular proposal is not yet a firmed-up proposal. Those people who used the temporary facilities made available at Perth airport during the construction of its new terminal will testify to the adequacy of those arrangements. Airports are enormously expensive pieces of fixed infrastructure.
—A one-off.
—Senator Walsh is quite right: we cannot construct an extremely expensive airport on the basis of one function, no matter how important it is.
—You can build a dam for that money.

—Indeed; that is not a responsible use of money. But an extremely large, state of the art international terminal has been commenced to be built in Brisbane, and it will be completed. If there are requirements in the meantime for additional facilities to be made available by the FAC in Brisbane to cope with a one-off event such as this, those facilities will be put in place.

—I refer the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to the recent opening of a family mediation service by the Marriage Guidance Council of Western Australia Inc, which is funded by the Minister's Department. Could the Minister inform the Senate of family mediation and what the Government hopes will be achieved by these services?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Family mediation services are designed to take some of the heat out of conflicts that can occur when couples are separating on the dissolution of a marriage-disputes about financial and property matters and, in particular, custody and access to children. Quite clearly, the danger of emotion overwhelming a sensible discussion between the parties in that situation is very real. For that reason, it has been thought useful to provide an alternative to the court-imposed solutions which are generally given out through the legal processes of the Family Court of Australia, and which can, of course, increase the bitterness between the parties as the court imposes its solution rather than the parties coming to a mediated solution for themselves and an agreement as to how custody or property matters might best be dealt with.

ANSWER.PARA: In this financial year the Government has allocated $1.12m for such family mediation services across Australia. This provides for some 10 services in every State, and it certainly will be maintained in real terms in the future. I have had the pleasure of opening several of those mediation services-in Sydney, Canberra, Hobart and, last week, Perth-and I believe that this process will continue.

It is a very good example of cooperation between the Government and community groups in this area. We provide the funding and clinical oversight. Marriage Guidance Western Australia, which is a superb organisation providing counselling, intervention in family violence situations and inappropriate sexual behaviour within family situations, is one of the most innovative and creative of the marriage counselling organisations around Australia. Certainly, it is an example of a community-based organisation providing the premises and staff. The referrals come from the Family Court of Australia, legal aid commissions, family law practitioners and others.

I believe that mediation services, alternative dispute resolution services, are becoming more accepted and understood throughout the community whereby parties can come to a resolution of often very difficult conflicts-particularly if children are concerned in a custody or access dispute-with the aid of a neutral third party. Separating couples coming to a decision by themselves leads to sensible arrangements which can endure because the parties have actually created the solutions themselves rather than have them imposed on them.

I hope that the mediation services in the family area will continue. They will be guaranteed real funding into the future. I believe that there is every prospect that they will expand as community organisations and counselling groups provide the trained personnel for this important mediation service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to an article in the Australian of 27 May 1991 headed `Steel export opportunity in jeopardy'. It refers to local steel production stagnating at a time when Asian demand is soaring and states that this most needed opportunity to boost exports will be missed. Is the Minister aware of the proposed compact steel mill in the south-west of Western Australia with a start-up target of one million tonnes of finished steel per annum which could help fulfil the demand that Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) is unwilling or unable to take up? Furthermore, is the Government prepared to support this new investment in Western Australia to the same extent it has supported BHP in the past?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the particular article in the Australian. BHP's production at Port Kembla has been reduced in the last few months because the No. 5 blast furnace has been down for repairs. They have now been completed and the blast furnace is apparently operating satisfactorily.

ANSWER.PARA: Nonetheless, approximately 40 per cent of BHP's steel production is now exported-contrary to the desired strategy of the company, which was to export in the order of 20 per cent of its steel output-largely because of the downturn in the domestic economy. Last year, steel exports were valued at something in excess of $1 billion, which is quite a significant achievement for BHP. I have had representations by letter and so on about the compact steel mill proposal. I think that members of my staff have met with representatives of that consortium.

A number of industry measures are in place at present which may be of assistance to that venture. They were not in place at the time BHP received assistance between 1983 and 1988, the five years of the steel plan. The steel plan was introduced because of particular circumstances of the Australian steel industry in 1983, which may well have meant that the steel industry went out of business in Australia, with huge consequent effects for the cities of Wollongong, Newcastle and Whyalla. There is no such analogous situation pertaining now. A number of measures are in place which may be helpful to compact steel. We are certainly prepared to help it within the confines of those existing measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications and concerns media ownership, something that Australians feel strongly about. I remind the Minister of the continued breach by Network 7 of the television audience reach limits of 60 per cent because the normal six months grace period to divest has been stretched beyond three years. Why has the Government not acted on the recent information and expression of concern of the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, Mr Peter Westerway, regarding this persistent breach? Why has the Government allowed Network 7 to remain in breach for so long? What does the Government intend to do to rectify the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have a copy of some advice from the Minister for Transport and Communications which I will give to Senator Kernot. I have also received a copy of a press statement that has been issued by Mr Peter Westerway in which he welcomes the announcement by the receiver for the Seven Network that the lender banks have signed heads of agreement to proceed with the financial restructuring of the network. He goes on to say that this does meet the Tribunal deadlines and that he will be informing the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, of that fact. Perhaps Senator Kernot has not caught up with that. I will give her a copy of it; I have only just received it myself.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister does understand that financial support for the Seven Network has been pledged by lenders to the network. The Tribunal is now waiting on a formal application for approval of a restructuring of the group holding arrangements. I understand that a heads of agreement has actually been signed. The protracted delay in finalising the financial future of the network has been destabilising for all concerned.

The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal recently issued a forthright statement regarding the delays in finalising the financial future of the Seven Network, to which Senator Kernot has just referred. The Tribunal stated that the group licensees and bankers had had plenty of time to remedy the breach of the 60 per cent audience limit and to put the network back on a sound financial basis. The Government supports the Tribunal's action to bring this delay to an end.

As has been reported, the Minister for Transport and Communications, Mr Beazley, wrote to the Tribunal in April assuring it that the Government would not tolerate schemes which tried to evade the Broadcasting Act's ownership rules. The Minister is of the understanding that the Tribunal will write to him if it is not satisfied with the proposed sale of the Seven Network. The Tribunal has been told that if the Broadcasting Act is inadequate to ensure compliance with the spirit of the Act, the Government will legislate to make sure that the spirit and intent of the law are upheld.

The Government's policy remains that there should be three separately owned and controlled commercial television services in metropolitan markets. Like everyone else, television networks must comply with the law of the land. The Government expects the Seven Network to comply with the ownership and control rules and will support any steps which the Tribunal considers necessary to perform its statutory functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Does that mean that banks will be subject to the laws of this Parliament in the way that any other consortium of proposed owners would be?
—Yes. I will provide Senator Kernot with a copy of the statement by Mr Westerway.

—I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to his statement to me in Senate Estimates Committee A on 16 April that the Chairman of Austrade, Mr Bill Ferris, `is not an applicant for the position of Managing Director of that organisation and has not been interviewed'. Will the Minister confirm that the reason for the delay in filling the position of Managing Director is the reason given by Mr Ferris to a recent Austrade board meeting, when he said that none of the applicants was suitable? Is it true that the position is to be readvertised? If so, is it also true that Mr Ferris is to be an applicant, despite the Minister's statement to the Estimates Committee on 16 April?

—What I said on 16 April in the Estimates Committee was correct. In so far as the delay in the appointment of a chief executive is concerned, it is true that the process of obtaining a suitable chief executive is continuing. In so far as the candidature of Mr Ferris is concerned, Mr Ferris cannot be a candidate. He is chairman of the panel responsible for selecting the appointee.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. In the light of that answer, could Senator Button tell me whether or not it is true that Mr Ferris told the same board meeting that, as the applicants were unsatisfactory, he himself would be prepared to be a candidate for that position? Is it true that this process is to be rushed through so that the appointment can be made prior to 1 September, whilst Senator Button remains the Minister instead of that cool customer, Senator Evans?

—There is no question of rushing through the appointment of a new chief executive for Austrade, but I hope the issue will be resolved well before 1 September. Dr Blewett and on some occasions Senator Gareth Evans are the Ministers with whom I have negotiations regarding this issue.
—I don't think he knows.

—Senator Walters interjects to say she does not think I know what Mr Ferris said at the board meeting. For the first time in her life she has it right. I do not monitor every bit of discussion which takes place at a board meeting. There are various views about this issue amongst board members but I certainly do not keep a diary of scuttlebutt or conversations which take place at various board meetings.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 May, Senator Kernot asked me a question about the Cape York spaceport. It involved relations with the Queensland Government. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Button: On 15 May 1991 (Hansard, page 3364) Senator Kernot asked me the following question without notice:

Is it also true that the Queensland Government, in response to this Soviet anxiety, has hastily drawn up Aboriginal land rights legislation to also, coincidentally, be enacted by the end of this year and that that legislation contains a deal with the Cape York Land Council to drop its opposition to the spaceport?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
I have referred your question to my Queensland Government colleagues who have replied as follows;
``The legislation, which has been passed by the Legislative Assembly but awaits Royal Assent, provides for:
(i) Certain lands to be granted for the benefit of the Aboriginal people without a claim being made under the Act. These lands are:
(a) Deed of Grant in Trust land
(ii) Certain lands that may be claimed by, and granted to, a group of Aboriginal people. The lands claimable under this provision are set forth in Division 4 of Part 2 of the Act
(iii) recognition of existing interest in land that is transferred or claimed and subsequently granted. Interest is defined in the Act as:
(a) a legal or equitable estate or interest in the land; or
(b) a right, power or privilege over, or in relation to, the land;
(c) a permit or licence issued in relation to the land; and
Section 2.13 of the Act defines ``interest'' in respect to that section.

The legislation was prepared in response to the Queensland Government's commitment to address the issue of land rights generally and was not initiated on the basis of any spaceport or other project proposals.
The extent to which the preferred sites for the spaceport may be affected by the legislation will be assessed in terms of the provisions of the legislation as summarised above.''

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 February Senator Panizza asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer relating to the so-called luxury car tax. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 February 1991 (Hansard, 909) Senator Panizza asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the sales tax on `luxury' cars.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

Senator Panizza has referred to reports that the sales tax on `luxury' cars has resulted in a revenue shortfall of $350m. Claims like this appear to be based upon an inappropriate comparison of current sales of vehicles with sales in the peak year 1988-89.

The revenue estimate published in the 1990-91 Budget Papers of $97m recognised that the sales volume in 1990-91 would be lower than in 1988-89 and would also be affected by the tax. Also factored into the revenue calculations was a substitution effect resulting from a switch to motor vehicles not subject to the higher tax, together with an estimate of the effect on customs duty.

However, since the estimates were made, the cyclical downturn in the economy has had a particularly marked effect on the luxury car segment of the motor vehicle industry. The extent of the effect was not anticipated by the market or Treasury. Speculation about the future of the tax also generated uncertainty, which would also have affected demand adversely.
The influences mean that revenue would have been lower than the $97m anticipated from the new higher rate of sales tax.

In recognition of the contraction in sales in the luxury car sector and its impact on the overall operations of vehicle importers, a reduction in the rate of sales tax on luxury cars to 30% was announced in the Government's Industry Statement on 12 March. This measure will reduce collections of revenue from luxury cars by $15m in 1990-91.

There is no proposal to replace the higher sales tax on luxury cars with other revenue raising measures to meet the Government's road funding commitments. This expenditure will continue to be met from the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 March Senator Watson asked me a question relating to a shortfall in taxation collections. I have an answer from the Treasurer, whom I represent in this matter, and I seek leave to have that incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 March 1991 (Hansard, page 1631) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning a shortfall in tax collections.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

It is correct that tax collections for the period July to December 1990 were $1100 million lower than expected at Budget-time. It is not correct, however, to imply that the Australian Taxation Office will try to recoup this shortfall by placing even further pressure on pay-as-you-earn taxpayers. While there is evidence suggesting that some employers are failing either to deduct or remit tax instalments, Deputy Commissioners of Taxation in Offices across Australia have merely been asked to ensure that appropriate levels of enforcement are maintained in order to protect the revenue. All taxpayers are treated equally by the Australian Taxation Office and all taxes administered by the Office are administered with the aim of achieving maximum voluntary compliance while ensuring that taxpayers meet their responsibilities. By maintaining a balanced collections policy over all areas of tax collections no undue pressure falls on any one sector. The Treasurer has already indicated that the estimated Budget surplus for 1990-91 has been revised down from $8.1 billion at Budget-time to $1.7 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 April Senator Spindler asked me a question relating to withholding tax. I agreed to obtain an answer from the Treasurer, and I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 April 1991 (Hansard, page 2191) Senator Spindler asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning interest withholding tax. Specifically, he asked whether I would support the proposal to increase the withholding tax on interest paid to foreign lenders.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable Senator's question:
Interest withholding tax involves market sensitivity and the Government will not comment on hypothetical changes to the tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 June Senator Michael Baume asked me a question as Leader of the Government in the Senate relating to youth unemployment figures. I said that I would obtain some further information, and I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Button

TALK.START.PARA: —On 6 June (Hansard, page 4507) Senator Michael Baume asked me as Leader of the Government in the Senate a question without notice about youth unemployment figures.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In seasonally adjusted terms in May 1991, the total unemployment rate fell to 9.4% from 9.9% in April. However, the full-time unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds moved in the opposite direction, rising by 0.5 percentage points to 27.5%. This should not be interpreted to mean that over one quarter of teenagers were unemployed; while it is correct that 27.5% of 15-19 year olds in the full-time labour force were unemployed, these young people represent only 8.5% of all 15-19 year olds.

Since employment peaked in July 1990, the full-time unemployment rate for 15-19 year olds has risen by 8.9 percentage points to 27.5%. The total unemployment rate has risen by 2.4 percentage points to 9.4%.

Clearly, the youth labour market has been hardest hit in this recession. The active labour market programs this Government has in place and our commitment to education and training, together with new initiatives announced in the March Economic Statement, ensure that education, training and employment opportunities are available for young people.
I refer you to my detailed answer to Senator Harradine's question on youth unemployment on 16 May (Hansard, page 3521) for information on these initiatives.

Unemployment should start to fall after the economy begins to recover later this year. It is important that the Government remains farsighted and adopts a long term focus in addressing the unemployment problem. We must protect the skill base of the workforce and ensure that government policies assist sustainable recovery and job creation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 June Senator Boswell asked me a question about the arrangements for the servicing and maintenance of 24 Squadron. I have written to him but I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard for the information of all honourable senators.

ANSWER.PARA: On 3 June 1991 Senator Boswell asked me a question regarding arrangements for servicing and maintenance of 34 Squadron's Special Purpose (SP) Falcon 900 fleet.
Whilst I did respond to Senator Boswell in writing during the recess, I take this opportunity to provide that additional information to the Senate.

Operating level maintenance, which involves routine flight line inspections and on-aircraft rectifications, for the SP fleet is performed by RAAF 34 squadron personnel at RAAF base Fairbairn. All higher level maintenance for the SP fleet is contracted to Hawker Pacific Pty Ltd.

This maintenance effort is conducted primarily at Hawker Pacific's facilities, but for unscheduled occurrences, Hawker Pacific can perform maintenance at RAAF base Fairbairn. Under the contract, Hawker Pacific are also required to supply consumable items, breakdown spares and sufficient repairable components to ensure aircraft availability targets are met.
Lastly, Hawker Pacific are responsible for maintenance of aircraft ground support equipment and management of SP fleet technical publications.

The current Hawker Pacific contract runs until December 1992. However, Hawker Pacific's contract can be extended for additional periods of up to seven years. The current cost of the contract is approximately $A9,700.000 but this amount will increase over time due to unscheduled maintenance arisings. The contract requires the Commonwealth to pay for unscheduled maintenance rectifications on the basis of survey and quotation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicated to Senator Coulter when he raised the question of Exercise Termite Spray that I would come back into the chamber and give a full response. The answer reads:

ANSWER.PARA: In response to a question by Senator Coulter on 6 June 1991 I advised the Senate that I had asked my Department to inquire further into information provided to the Senate regarding a Defence exercise called termite spray conducted on Beecroft Peninsula in May this year. I am now able to provide the results of that inquiry.
I should say at the outset that I am very concerned that misleading advice was provided to my colleague Senator Richardson and also to the Senate.
I do not believe that service officers or Defence officials set out to provide misleading advice or to cover up the facts of the situation.

However, it is apparent that the complexity of the channels of communication between Army, Navy, the Rangers and Defence Canberra exacerbated by their geographic separation and the large numbers of people involved allowed some misunderstandings to occur.
Let me assure the Senate I have indicated to my Department that measures must be put in place urgently to prevent a recurrence.
I turn now to the specific questions which required further explanation.
The first issue relates to whether or not the Army felled casuarina trees in the course of the exercise and the nature and timing of advice provided by my Department on this matter.

On 20 May 1991 a local resident advised the Parks and Conservation Service (PCS) rangers that while walking on Beecroft Peninsula he had come across a number of stumps of felled casuarinas. He also indicated he had seen what he considered to be a number of recently felled casuarina poles on the back of an Army truck.
Following that advice the rangers located the stumps of a number of young trees and saplings, generally less than 20cm in diameter.
While trees have been cut down I must stress that investigations by Army and Navy have yielded no direct evidence that the trees were cut down by Army.

On 21 May Army instigated an inquiry through the commander of the relevant unit. A further inquiry was conducted subsequent to the conclusion of the exercise. On each occasion all members of the unit denied any such action.
There were no operational reasons for Army to fell any trees as Army vehicles on the exercise carried poles specifically provided to support camouflage nets.

The location of the area where trees were felled-close to a main road-and the fact that only casuarina trees were taken, a species which I am advised is used for wood-turning, does raise the possibility that these trees were illegally taken by a third party.
On the question of whether officers adequately responded to earlier advice provided, the sequence of events was as follows.
First advice to Defence that trees had been felled was on 21 May in a minute from the rangers.
The Navy range officer and Army personnel immediately made unsuccessful attempts to locate the stumps.

Defence facilities staff visited the exercise site on 22 May and were informed by the rangers of allegations that trees had been cut down. However, no evidence was shown-nor were they advised that any stumps had been located.

Following media comment on 24 May Navy and Army officers, ACF representatives and the media undertook an inspection of the exercise site. They too were unsuccessful in attempts to find the stumps or to contact the resident who had made the allegation.

On the basis of this advice, Defence in Canberra provided a briefing to my office on 29 May which stated that no evidence of tree cutting had been found. This advice was conveyed to the Senate by Senator Richardson in response to a question by Senator Coulter. At the same time, my office asked the Defence Department to double-check the allegations.

On 30 May Defence Canberra received copies of the rangers minutes indicating the tree trunks had been found. It was not until 31 May that the rangers actually showed Navy officers the location of the stumps.
In summary, the advice that was originally provided to the Senate-that is, that no evidence existed that trees were felled during the exercise-remains the case.
The second issue relates to whether or not new tracks were made by the Army during the exercise.

Although the majority of exercise activity at Beecroft was confined to preexisting access roads, I am advised that some new tracks were put in to facilitate access within the designated harbour area at Long Beach South.

The Department had provided advice to my office on 29 May that no new tracks had been bulldozed. This advice was in direct response to Senator Coulter's assertion in his media release that new tracks had been `bulldozed'.
Except for one small drain-crossing, topsoil was not removed, nor bulldozers used in road making. However, some new tracks were made for the exercise.

Defence officials in Canberra were not aware of this because of the devolved management arrangements and the inspection by Canberra based officers on 21 May did not identify the tracks at Long Beach as being in any way new.
This was a clear breakdown in communications which I have directed my Department to rectify as a matter of urgency.

While it is regrettable that a few incidents occurred which could and should have been avoided, overall I believe that the conduct of the exercise was consistent with the intention of appropriately managing the impact on the environment.
There is a need to review and enhance approval and monitoring procedures, drawing from lessons learnt during this exercise. That activity is already in train.

Lastly I undertook to examine the files with a view to tabling documents relating to termite spray. Accordingly, I now table those documents held by my office relating to the felling of trees or the creation of new tracks during exercise termite spray, as well as a copy of my letter of 4 June 1991 to Senator Coulter which gave a full description of the facts up to that time.

Senators will understand that in an organisation as large and complex as Defence, the occasional communication foul-up will occur. What is relevant in this case is that as soon as the facts became available, Senator Coulter was informed. There was no intention to deliberately mislead and swift action has been taken to prevent a recurrence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Defence (Senator Ray) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter on 6 June, relating to Exercise Termite Bay.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation by honourable senators as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is increasingly unable to fulfil its responsibilities to provide independence, integrity, quality entertainment and commercial-free services.
The Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be funded in such a way for these responsibilities and obligations to be maintained.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
1) Increase the annual funding base of the ABC by a minimum of $32 million;
2) Guarantee adequate and properly indexed funding to the ABC for the next three years on an agreed basis with the ABC;
3) Maintain the legislative prohibition on corporate sponsorship and advertising on the ABC.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, containing a motion passed by the Australian Action Movement with signatures from people who attended the Cootamundra conference of that organisation on 15 and 16 June, which is not in the prescribed form:

SPEECH.PARA: That this conference resolved that it was totally opposed to the proposed Political Broadcast Act as it removes a major area of the right to free speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes that:

(i) on 14 June 1941 the Soviet Union began mass deportation to Siberia of peoples from the Baltic States of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, as a result of which 600 000 people, more than 10 per cent of the total population of the three States, lost their lives,
(ii) Australia does not recognise the forced incorporation of the Baltic States into the Soviet Union,

(iii) the people of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia have voted overwhelmingly by referenda for independence from the Soviet Union, and the governments of the three States have reaffirmed their declarations of independence,
(iv) despite this, the three States have not been allowed to pursue policies which would realise the intent of these votes and declarations,
(v) recent actions by the Soviet Union in the Baltic States are inconsistent with its stated commitment to pursue policies of Glasnost and Perestroika, and

(vi) the Soviet Union has not acted in accord with the Helsinki agreements, which it signed 15 years ago, because it has not allowed the Baltic States to exercise their respective rights to self-determination; and

(b) resolves that 14 June be recognised as an international day of mourning for the 600 000 Baltic peoples who lost their lives as a result of the deportations and trusts that their suffering and sacrifice will strengthen the efforts of all freedom-loving peoples to ensure that Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are soon restored to their rightful place as free and independent nations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the article `A road to recovery from our market led malaise' in the Weekend Australian of Saturday, 15 June 1991;
(b) further notes that the author of the article is Mr C. D. Kemp, the founder and former director of the Institute of Public Affairs;

(c) draws attention to one of the important conclusions of the article that `in a few short years deregulation and the market philosophy have led to a blatantly inequitable distribution of wealth and income entirely foreign to the hitherto strong Australian egalitarian tradition'; and
(d) urges the Coalition parties, and especially Senator Kemp, to consider the mounting evidence which discredits the view of the Opposition that market forces must remain sacrosanct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes:

(i) the enormous pressure being put on Australia's leading athletes to perform at top level by the Government's elite sports funding system whereby athletes in seven selected Olympic sports have been singled out for large-scale additional funding, depending on their potential to win Olympic medals,
(ii) the pressures this imposes on sports administrators, the status, standing and funding of whose sports depend on the performance of their athletes,

(iii) that Martin Vinnicombe, who was receiving $10 000 a year in sports funding from the Federal Government, identified this pressure on him as his justification for taking a banned performance-enhancing steroid drug, leading to his suspension for two years, and

(iv) that allegations concerning Mr Vinnicombe and drugs were investigated by the Australian Sports Commission two years ago resulting in an inconclusive finding, but clearly putting Mr Vinnicombe and cycling authorities on notice about such drugs;

(b) warns that, had this positive drug test occurred at an Olympic Games, Australia's sporting reputation would have been severely damaged at a time when Australia is seeking host status for the year 2000 Olympics; and

(c) calls on all Australian sporting organisations, sports sponsors and sportsmen and women to do their utmost to end the use of performance-enhancing drugs in sport, no matter what the loss of rewards may be, and commends the Australian Sports Drug Agency for its strong and effective drug testing campaign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(a) notes the findings of the recently-released report of the Victorian Council of Social Service entitled No Reason to Wait for Social Security that:
(i) waiting periods for pensions and benefits are a key factor in the huge increase in demand for emergency relief and food vouchers throughout Australia, and
(ii) the wait for benefits is just intensifying the suffering of those people unlucky enough to become unemployed or sick;

(b) calls on the Government to abolish or reduce waiting periods, in particular, the 13-week waiting period for education leavers under 21, the 26-week wait for rent assistance for beneficiaries without children and the 4-week liquid assets test waiting period; and

(c) urges the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) to raise these waiting periods in the Budget discussions to ensure a fair deal for those Australians who are unemployed because of this Government's economic policies.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Foreign Minister Senator Evans' confused interpretation of Australia's national interests, his misplaced priorities and his inability to behave with discretion and courtesy when representing Australia.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Hill, I understand that informal arrangements have been made for speaking times during this discussion as follows: Senator Hill as first Opposition speaker, 15 minutes; the Minister, 20 minutes; the Australian Democrat speaker, 10 minutes; the next Opposition speaker, 5 minutes; the next Government speaker, 5 minutes; final Opposition speaker, 5 minutes. With the concurrence of the Senate, I shall ask the Clerk to set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, these are serious issues and I wish to briefly put them in context. With Australia's economic decline, our capacity to influence events in our national interest has been significantly reduced. Even within our own region, we are not seen as being of the same consequence as we once were. Regrettably, we are becoming increasingly irrelevant.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not yet identify ourselves as being part of Asia, yet Europe does not identify us as part of Europe. In economic terms, we are of the north but located in the south. We are being increasingly isolated on world bodies, whether they be economic blocs or political blocs. In these circumstances, more than ever before, a clear definition, a clear enunciation of our national interests promoted by skilled, professional diplomacy is absolutely vital.

Where does the impatient, arrogant, foul-mouthed posturing by Senator Gareth Evans in South Africa fit into this important national responsibility which faces Australia? His style of diplomacy, apparently calling security guards who are provided for his own safety `F-ing useless'-as we heard today and which was not denied-causes us international embarrassment. His answer to today's question was totally inadequate. There was no justification for abusing an official who had sought to protect Senator Evans's person. Yet because he was frustrated, that is the course of action he adopted and that is to our international embarrassment.

The circumstances by which this remark became public are really irrelevant. Australia should expect more; it has a right to expect better of its Foreign Ministers. In addition, Senator Gareth Evans's clear refusal to listen and learn, but rather to lecture and dictate, reinforces the sort of spoilt brat's image of Australia which those such as the Prime Minister of Malaysia, Dr Mahathir, often identify with us. Senator Evans should know better. We understood that he was going to South Africa to listen and learn, but did he do so? No. Senator Evans, in his usual style, always knows better, and he went to South Africa to tell them so.

His intervention in the domestic affairs of South African politics by supporting one black political movement over other black political movements also reinforces the image that we have the right to choose those who should govern elsewhere. That continues this atmosphere of arrogance. It does Australia no good. We have no right to do such a thing. We have no right to choose between the alternative black forces that might come to the fore in a democratic South Africa, but Senator Evans is of a different view which he portrays personally and in Australia's name-which is the important thing that he does not seem to understand-when representing us in South Africa.
