In this instance, he went one step further and portrayed his view with Australian taxpayers' money, which locks us even further into his personal assessment of which of the black political organisations should be supported. Therefore, not only does he choose his own favourites when out of our country and in another country, but also he indicates that he is prepared to support them, to the exclusion of others, with Australian taxpayers' resources. Even his choice of the African National Congress (ANC) over all others in these circumstances is questionable. His choice of the ANC with its discredited Marxist philosophy and, until recently, its support of use of violent means and the application of violent means to achieve political objectives also tells the world something about Australia. Senator Evans's assessment of the legitimacy of the ANC and the way it operates becomes the assessment that is perceived of Australia.

I remind the Minister-because we are talking of his favourites in this instance-that it was the ANC in the 1980s that got the black kids out of school in South Africa and kept them out of school for years to serve its political objectives, as a result of which a whole generation of black children in South Africa went without education. This is the body that Senator Evans has chosen for the future of South Africa and which he is prepared to support with Australian taxpayers' money.

It is no wonder that the international community is bemused. It is no wonder that most editorial writers in this country were embarrassingly writing last week, `Gareth, please come home'. Australia's relations with South Africa have been poor. That is understandable. We have stood with others in opposition to the abhorrent system of apartheid. Along with others, we applied sporting sanctions, economic sanctions and the like to press the South African Government to reform. We can therefore understand why relations in the past have not been good.

But Senator Evans needs to address the fact that apartheid is now being dismantled. Legislation was passed at the very time Senator Evans was in South Africa. President de Klerk has kept all of his promises. Everyone accepts that the next elections in South Africa will be on a multi-racial basis. Surely, in those circumstances, it is in Australia's interests to support that process of change and to rebuild its relationship with South Africa. Is that not what Australia's interests should dictate-to re-engage South Africa in the international economic community which will contribute more to the well-being of the blacks in terms of jobs, better education and the first steps towards alleviating the awful poverty that we all recognise that Senator Evans saw in the townships in South Africa?

Within our very limited capacity-and I stress that, Mr Deputy President, because it is totally overestimated by some-is it not within our own interests to help build bridges between the races, between the tribes and between the deeply divided society in South Africa which will give the people the best hope for a peaceful, democratic future? If those things are in our national interest-and I cannot see how they could not be-they were not advanced by Senator Evans's visit. He offered very little support to President de Klerk and the white reformers-and I mention the white reformers despite opposition that President de Klerk is still experiencing within South Africa.

Senator Evans opposed lifting the economic sanctions which are now serving no other purpose but entrenching poverty. In his very public promotion of favourites, he contributed to the deepening divisions that already exist in South Africa, rather than contributing to building bridges. That is why this trip was such a diplomatic disaster. That is why it brought no credit upon Australia and that is why it did not even help South Africa.

The Minister has said in his defence-if one could call it that-that this should be treated as a one-off situation, that his record in the past is not such as it was in South Africa and that in some way he should therefore receive the benefit of that fact. During my political involvement, I cannot recall a time when Australia has been in more trouble with so many of its bilateral relationships, particularly within our own region. We are experiencing problems with India, with Malaysia and with Fiji, and one can go on. Regrettably, in all those difficulties in our bilateral relations that exist at the moment and that have not existed in the past, we see a touch of Senator Evans. Senator Evans's style, as well as his confused definition of Australia's national interests and his confused priorities as to what is in our best interest in some ways have contributed to all of these difficulties.

In justification of his South African experience, Senator Evans said that his failure to control his temper and his arrogance should be related to the circumstances of his visit. I remind the Senate that only a few months ago, in October of last year, he attacked the outgoing Indian High Commissioner, Mr Bhutani, at a conference in Melbourne. Those who attended the conference regarded it as an unbelievable performance. India had good reason to complain about Australian policy, which had seen Mirage jet aircraft sold to Pakistan when India was on its highest level of alert and the chance of war in the Kashmir was imminent. Did Senator Evans appreciate that India would be frustrated by that? Of course not. Again, it was its fault. It is always its fault; it is never Senator Evans's fault.

The last retort was the worst of all when, in his exchange with Mr Bhutani, Senator Evans said that Mr Bhutani did not speak for India. To say that of an Indian diplomat or of any other representative of a nation is probably the worst thing that he could say.

Senator Evans has probably forgotten his attack on John Major at the last Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting (CHOGM) at Kuala Lumpur, because again he was tired and frustrated. Interestingly enough, that was over a different perception of the appropriate policies to help South Africa with its problems. What did he say of the then newly appointed Foreign Secretary of Britain? Senator Evans described him as `ungracious to the last'. As it turned out, it was Australia's judgment which was wrong, not Britain's. Australia went into that CHOGM in Kuala Lumpur arguing for more and deeper economic sanctions to try to change the position in South Africa. History has shown that that was unnecessary: South Africa had turned the corner and what it and President de Klerk needed was support. He got it wrong, and then he abused Mr Major because he adopted a different position. It is typical of Senator Evans. Unless one is with him, one is the fool; Senator Evans is never the fool.

To the extent that Senator Evans claims that his intervention in the domestic affairs of another country is limited to South Africa, that is also not so. I remind honourable senators of what happened in the last few weeks in relation to India and his comments on the Hindu Nationalist Party, the BJP. What did he say? When he was in India he volunteered the opinion that a BJP government would be difficult to deal with and a source of concern for Australia and the region because of its aggressive nuclear policy and `enthusiasm for promoting communal tensions'.

In three distinct ways, this was an appalling statement. Firstly, he claimed to speak for other countries in the region, which he had no right to do. Secondly, interestingly, whilst Senator Evans was speaking for other countries in the region, Mr Advani was meeting with the Prime Minister of Pakistan, which showed how ridiculous it was. The statement was appallingly timed, because it was a moment of national mourning, during which political activity had been suspended. Any political comments from Senator Evans were not called for, let alone a direct intervention in internal politics. Thirdly, the statement that other governments would have difficulty working with a BJP government was obviously an insult to the Indian people in their democratic institutions.

I must put on the record the fact that Mr Advani responded with greater grace when he said that Senator Evans's remarks were indiscreet and that this sort of thing was just not done. The press called it a breach of diplomatic tradition or diplomatic protocol. Senator Evans would not even accept that; he never accepts criticism. He compounded the original gaffe by calling the criticism an absurd misunderstanding of diplomatic protocol. I do not think that Senator Evans is qualified to speak on the subject of diplomatic protocol.

Senator Evans intervened in Fiji's domestic politics last year by supporting the Australian Labor Party and by being part of the decision-making process to give funds to the Fijian Labor Party. No wonder he got the response that he did from Ratu Mara. It is not surprising that he is not welcome in Fiji, not only because of that but also because of his appalling misjudgment in going to last year's United Nations General Assembly to abuse and criticise Fiji to the world community-thus losing the opportunity that Australia should have as a neighbour of Fiji of trying to build bridges within communal difficulties rather than picking sides and trying to pick winners and abusing them in international institutions and only losing respect and influence for Australia as a result. So it goes on.

Similar examples abound of Senator Evans's lack of judgment within his field. Senator Teague will speak more on the Cambodian situation. The position that he has got Australia into, which has only benefited the Khmer Rouge, is typical of his style because it is Senator Evans who always knows best. He wrote the Bible, and aptly called it the `Red Book'. He said that this was what was necessary in Cambodia. It is interesting that the pressure is now on to exclude Australia from the process. Honourable senators will have heard of the greater involvement of Indonesia, France, Japan and so forth. He again got it wrong; he again made a misjudgment.

We witnessed Senator Evans's promotion of this new body, the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Asia, for collective security within the region. He knew better; the region did not know better. The whole of the region has criticised him for his naivety, because the region is simply not ready for a form of collective security. There is not sufficient common interest within it. He would do better to help try to build bridges within the region, but that is not the way in which he operates.

I could go on for a lot more than the 15 minutes I have, but the issue is vitally important. His misjudgments, his failure to assess Australia's national interests properly and his appalling use of foul language when he diplomatically represents us overseas are simply not good enough and he ought to do something about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having coped over the last few days with the combined ministrations of the South African security establishment, the South African media and the Australian media, it really was with a quite profound sense of relief that I came to Canberra last night, because Her Majesty's Opposition was always going to be the least of my worries. So it has proved to be the case with these absurd popgun assaults to which we have been listening in Question Time and now in the debate on this particular matter of public importance.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has demonstrated today that it has no understanding of the structure and shape of Australian foreign policy or the principles on which it is conducted. Senator Hill's speech demonstrated that the Opposition has no understanding of the dynamics of the present situation in South Africa, in particular, and what is necessary to complete effectively the reform process there.

The Opposition has also demonstrated that it has no pride and no confidence in its own country in terms of its demonstrated willingness to score cheap political points against me and the Labor Government; to accept at absolute face value, without demur and without any willingness to explore the issues involved, the characterisation of events and incidents given by a combination of the South African security establishment and, as I have said publicly, the most paranoid elements of the South African media. As I will show, the South African media reports, which were so enthusiastically embraced by both the Australian media and the Opposition, did involve a fundamental and systematic distortion of what actually happened. Pik Botha said as much to me at the airport on my departure when he said that the media have got it completely out of perspective.

Let me begin at the beginning with the Opposition's approach to Australian foreign policy generally. The Opposition, and, I have to say, a lot of the Australian press too, seems absolutely captivated by the `Good Relations' approach to foreign policy-the notion that good relations are ends in themselves and the notion that if there is any ripple on the surface of any relationship with any country it must reflect adversely on the conduct of Australian diplomacy. That sort of approach, as I said at Question Time, is a recipe for conducting Australian foreign policy either on one's back or on one's belly rather than on one's own two feet. I think I know-as I think the overwhelming majority of Australians know-which is the more dignified posture.

Of course it is the case that good relations with other countries are important, and I have striven mightily to achieve those good relations in every one of the 27 overseas visits I have made, with results that have been more or less universally acknowledged around the world-the carping of the Opposition always excluded. But good relations are not ends in themselves; they are means to ends. Good relations with other countries are means to ends, and those ends are Australia's national interests.

I have done more-and I think it has been widely acknowledged-to define with systematic precision what exactly Australian national interests are and how they should be prioritised and defined than anyone else who has occupied this particular position. I have sought to systematically articulate them in terms of geopolitical and strategic interests, economic and trade interests and Australia's interests in being and being seen to be a good international citizen. I have sought to explain and to describe the various major world-recognised initiatives that Australia has taken in terms of those interests and in terms of that kind of prioritisation and the principles that underlie it. Cambodia, chemical weapons, Australia's role in the Cairns Group, the Uruguay Round, in pursuing the Antarctic minerals initiative, in inaugurating the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation group, in helping to generate a major new debate on Asia-Pacific security, and South Africa are all initiatives and specific examples of Australian foreign policy at work, not in an ad hoc or unsystematic way, but within a structured framework that has careful regard to what is achievable and what is legitimately to be regarded as the pursuit of our national interest.

It is squarely in that context that we have taken a major interest over the years as a country on the subject of apartheid. It is not a matter of our geopolitical, strategic or security interests being involved-manifestly they are not-nor is it really a matter of our economic or trade interests being involved in any but the most indirect sense. What is involved in terms of the role that we played in relation to South Africa is essentially that characteristic of our foreign policy which I have described as good international citizenship: the capacity we have as a citizen of this region, as a citizen of the Commonwealth and as a citizen of the world to play a role-a particularly significant role in the case of South Africa because of the cultural and sporting ties that exist between us-to try to rid the world of what has been its most lingering and in many ways distasteful human rights problem.

There are fundamental issues at stake here that go to the dignity of us all as human beings, and I make no apology for the significance that this subject has occupied in Australian foreign policy. The Australian Government's policy response to South Africa has been tough, clear, consistent and consistently right. As a country we were the prime mover in the early 1970s in the push for sanctions generally, and sports sanctions in particular, with the latter culminating in the Gleneagles Agreement of 1977. In many ways we have been a prime mover throughout the 1980s in applying and extending those sanctions, especially in more recent years, and in refining, developing and arguing the case around the world for financial sanctions limiting the flow of capital to South Africa in such a way as to inhibit the growth of the economy there-manifestly the most effective of all the different sanctions that have been applied against South Africa, as was unreservedly acknowledged to me by both business and government circles during my visit to South Africa.

Now Australia is playing the role of a prime mover-not the only one-in developing and applying the concepts of, first, the phased relaxation of sanctions generally in response to developments as they occur, not simply commitments as they are promised; and, secondly, in the selective relaxation of the sports boycott, which is a policy involving response to the unification, when achieved, of particular sports and when that unification is recognised by the relevant non-racial sporting bodies. None of that represents a policy approach which is universally liked within South Africa. Foreign Minister Pik Botha has been widely reported as saying that the Australian sanctions policy has made no impact on the South African Government except to make a mess of the country, but as Mandy Rice-Davies was once heard to say, `He would say that, wouldn't he?'. That is not an unusual or unexpected thing; it is entirely consistent with the whole policy approach that the South African Government has been adopting for years.

Chief Buthelezi and Inkatha-that particular group-have never agreed with sanctions, and have always preferred to fight apartheid from the comfort of the executive suites in KwaZulu rather than in the streets in the way that other groups have chosen to do. By contrast-in the case of yet another group in South Africa-the Pan Africanist Congress (PAC) and others perhaps to the left of the African National Congress (ANC), have not liked, from another perspective, the phased relaxation of our policy; they have not liked Australia for promoting that.

It is the case that Australia could hardly expect its sanctions policy to have won universal approval, and it has not. But the truth remains that sanctions have been enormously effective, simply in making apartheid unaffordable, and have been absolutely crucial in producing the reform momentum we now see. Moreover those sanctions have manifestly been supported by the overwhelming majority of black South Africans, notwithstanding the obvious economic pain they have caused. The truth of the matter is also that sanctions go on being supported by the overwhelming majority of black South Africans to the extent that remains necessary to achieve the final destruction of apartheid.

Senator Hill today repeated the common mistake, which is made over and over again, by saying that apartheid is disappearing and all that is necessary is the repeal of those three pieces of legislation that are coming off the statute books in this particular South African parliamentary session. The truth of the matter is that the complete abolition of apartheid cannot and will not be achieved until the South African Constitution itself is rewritten and those 27 million to 28 million black South Africans come on to the voting rolls for the first time and become participating citizens in that country.

The Opposition policy is hopelessly confused on the sanctions issue. It is the case that the former Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, when in government supported sanctions but his successors-Mr Howard and Dr Hewson-have never done so. The policy of the Liberal Party of Australia in opposition as articulated in 1989 makes it absolutely clear that the sanctions policy is regarded as counterproductive, to use the language of that particular platform, which says `the record shows that sanctions have in fact been counterproductive in achieving the desired objective'. Similarly, there is a series of statements in recent times from Dr Hewson. For example, on 14 June he said that I and the Government have been `consistently wrong' on the subject of sanctions.

That is not, however, a view shared by Senator Hill. As the Opposition spokesman on foreign affairs he has made it consistently clear in recent times that sanctions have achieved real change. That is a phrase he has used over and over again, most recently on 16 April when he argued that their continuation now would be counterproductive, but he did not argue about the original effectiveness of them. That is the case the Government continues to put: sanctions have been effective and in our judgment will go on being necessary for some time yet because there is a very real danger of that reform momentum being lost. There is plenty of evidence that a lot of that reform momentum has been lost already over the past six months as the South African Government has positioned and manoeuvred itself to build post-apartheid political constituencies rather than getting on with the main game. The important thing is for the world to ensure that it stays with that main game. I believe that for some time yet-not necessarily until the Constitution itself is enacted-financial sanctions in particular will be a crucial disciplinary mechanism.

So far as support for the ANC is concerned, we dealt with this matter pretty systematically in Question Time today. I make no apology for the political support we have given the ANC and, indeed, for the anti-apartheid movement generally over the many years it has been fighting the apartheid system. I make no apology for regarding Nelson Mandela in particular as a thoroughly decent, dignified, compassionate and moderate man. He is someone who is and who will be a great leader of his people and his nation.

I make no apology for believing that around him in the ANC there exists a large core of mature, intelligent, sophisticated and moderate people who will make splendid leaders of the country, should they be elected to play that role in later times. I make no apology for that part of our development assistance program which involves the expenditure of moneys on projects identified in consultation with the ANC in relation to training and education, the return of exiles and, more recently, some aspects of the project to develop an economic planning capacity within the opposition movement.

None of this represents support for the ANC as a political party or as a political organisation for campaigning purposes against other political parties or organisations. It is, as I said in Question Time, development assistance because South Africa is, so far as its black people are concerned, a developing nation. What we are involved in here is really nothing less than the creation of a wholly new nation out of the imperfect ashes of the old. It is in that context that Australia's support is being directed and it is in that respect that it is being welcomed. We have chosen to work primarily, but not solely, through the ANC as an opposition organisation simply because on all the available evidence it is and remains the most representative black organisation of all.

So far as the circumstances of this visit are concerned that have given rise to the various diatribes we have heard today and the last part of the matter of public importance before us, in the time available and given the number of misrepresentations and sheer falsities that have been involved in various assertions, I would find it difficult to know where to begin in setting the record straight. One way of approaching this question would be to adopt what might be described as the Chief Buthelezi principle-that attack is the best form of defence-and to refer to some of the information I have had about the way in which Dr Hewson conducted his foray into foreign affairs recently in China. I still remember a very senior Chinese official wincing as he told me about the clumsy ineptitude with which Dr Hewson had approached the human rights issue and related matters in the course of his consultations recently with senior Chinese leaders.

I could go down that particular track, and I assure those opposite that I have plenty of ammunition, but I prefer not to do so. I prefer simply to make the point, as I did in Question Time, that there is essentially only one thing that went wrong on that South African trip from which everything else followed when a highly prejudicial version of the incident in question was deliberately released to the South African media. I have described the circumstances of the incident involving the breach of an agreement, reached as recently as the night before with the security police, in circumstances which caused me a great deal of distress, in particular because of the adverse implications for two community workers whose future effectiveness I held as a very important thing to be preserved.

I have made clear that any response I may have made to the security people, given my distress at the situation, was in private. The fact that it became public was none of my doing. Moreover, it is worth saying that in four subsequent township visits I made to Soweto, Alexandra, Soshanguve and Port Elizabeth, the arrangements-lest there be any lingering feeling that there was something odd about the arrangements for that first day-proceeded on exactly the basis that had been originally negotiated and were reconfirmed.

The point remains that, for all the bumps that occurred during that trip, its basic objectives were met. It was highly successful in terms of the various objectives we identified before we left. We wanted to inform ourselves as to the current conditions and political currents running in that country in order to provide an input into the larger policy process within the Commonwealth and elsewhere over the next few months. We wanted to take the opportunity to make clear our and the international community's intense concern that, while major changes were occurring, they should continue through to fruition. We wanted to develop the foundation for a sound bilateral relationship in the future with the likely future leaders of that country, black and white.

I believe that in all those objectives we amply succeeded. Nelson Mandela made it perfectly clear that, so far as he and the ANC were concerned, I had made many more friends among South Africans during my visit than I had had before I arrived. So far as Pik Botha is concerned, in his departure press conference he said, `I believe that relations between the two countries will further improve as a result of this visit'. Perhaps I can offer as further testimony a source that the opposite side would regard as unimpeachable, and that is the South African Ambassador to Australia, Mr David Tothill, who accompanied me for much of this trip. On ABC radio at lunchtime today he said:
I think from our point of view and also from Australia's point of view it was a good visit.
He said that there were diversions but they came with a happy ending. Describing the meeting I had with Ministers, including Ministers Botha and Viljoen and Finance Minister du Plessis, he said this:

. . . the chemistry at that meeting was very good indeed. Senator Evans expounded Australian Government policy as did the South African Ministers South African policy, but they interacted well. I think it was a fruitful meeting. It was the first time that Pik Botha had met Gareth Evans. As you say, both are men of decided views and both are, I think, highly intelligent men -
may Hansard record a blush at this point-
with slightly different styles. I think they sized each other up and came to the conclusion that each was a worthy opponent.

I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the final paragraph of Ambassador Tothill's comments, which is in response to a question about those incidents. It makes the point that from his point of view, from every point of view, it was a very effective visit.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Tothill: I don't really want to get into those incidents because they were quite peripheral to the substance of the visit. I know that the media, both South African and Australian, beat themselves into a frenzy, for them these slight incidents provided entertainment. I think everybody was slightly amused but they didn't interfere with the progress registered during the course of the visit. Senator Evans I think came away from South Africa with his eyes opened to South African realities, and his South African interlocutors, including Pik Botha, obtained off Senator Evans the impression of a highly intelligent, highly able Foreign Minister who articulates Australian Foreign policy very effectively.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —It cannot be said that the trip to South Africa by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) was an unmitigated success, but neither can it be said that it was a disaster. What did we all expect? After 40 years of isolation and vilification by Australian governments of all political persuasions, what were the South Africans going to do? Were they going to welcome with open arms and joyous greetings the first Australian Minister to visit the country after all that time? That is not what I expected. I expected South Africans to have a go at Senator Evans at every possible opportunity, and that is exactly what they did.

SPEECH.PARA: It should have come as no surprise to the Opposition, and to some of the mainstream media also, that this diplomatic visit resulted in controversy. It took place under difficult circumstances. Instead of focusing on those few instances of embarrassment and disorder that arose on the visit, the Australian Democrats believe that the Parliament would have been better served today if we had debated the challenges to Australia-South Africa relations-if we debated anything at all, as this is our last week of sitting in this session-and how best this country is placed to help South Africa back into the world community of nations.

Certainly it would be fair to acknowledge that the Foreign Minister's visit was deserving of greater support from this Parliament. I think I can say that it does reflect the Minister's personal commitment to the issue. It was, of course, the first visit by an Australian Foreign Minister in more than 40 years, and in many ways it was an opportunity we just could not pass up. The Democrats believe that it makes good sense to encourage the South African Government to respond more positively to major reforms as they are introduced. In this context, international recognition and greater acceptance by the world community will play an important part in the changes in South Africa. That is why it is important that the Foreign Minister's visit took place.

Just as Australia played a key role in Commonwealth sanctions being implemented against South Africa, so it is important for this country to be in a strong position to be able to influence Commonwealth opinion about when sanctions should be lifted in response to reforms, and not too soon. The Foreign Minister's visit will now provide him with an excellent opportunity to give a more realistic assessment of Australia's attitude towards the lifting of sanctions at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Zimbabwe in October.

Recent decisions by the United States Administration and the European Community in relation to South Africa also made it important that the Foreign Minister went to South Africa when he did. The decision by the European Community to lift its ban on imports of gold, iron and steel from South Africa put an onus on countries such as Australia and groups such as the Commonwealth to justify why there should be no change to the sanctions policy. Without the information the Foreign Minister has gathered on his mission to South Africa, Australia would quite obviously have been at a disadvantage in both international affairs and trade terms. In other words, it was in Australia's international interests that the visit went ahead and was supported by all Australians.

Senator Evans is not renowned for his even temper, although I must say that, given the circumstances leading to his altercation with a member of the South African security forces after the motorcade through the township, I imagine it would have taken someone with the temperament of a saint not to react very strongly in private. Having the temperament of a saint is another character trait not usually associated with Senator Evans. Mother Theresa might have coped without raising her voice; I do not think I could have and I do not think Senator Hill could have either. It is unfortunate that Senator Evans's language was not a little more temperate, but he was speaking in private and we have to keep that in mind. The unacceptable behaviour in that case was that of the South African security man who went to the media with details of a private conversation.

As for the grant to the African National Congress, it is, I believe, a result of recommendations by a delegation, headed by Professor Garnaut of the Australian National University economics department, which visited South Africa quite recently. That delegation also recommended that the rest of the grant be used to set up an institute of economic planning at a South African university and to pay for scholarships, training and consultancies. Rob Rasche, the correspondent for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation in South Africa, identified some problems with some of that aid. He said on AM last Saturday that there have been early suggestions that some of the aid has been badly spent and, obviously, there was little consultation with other important black movements as to how it would be best applied. Mr Rasche also commented on Australia singling out the ANC. He said:

Senator Evans was rounded on for calling the ANC the most representative organisation in the country, a fact so obvious it's inescapable to any serious observer. That upset Inkatha and the Government, but given their long-term plan to form a coalition to try to secure power, that's to be expected. Senator Evans' assessment was based on plenty of evidence.

The most important and fundamental points of interest about Senator Evans's visit to South Africa are not concerned with yelling at a security officer in private but rather with the details of the Foreign Minister's discussions with black and white leaders and with his own experience in visiting townships. When will the Internal Security Act be amended? How fast are reforms progressing? That is the sort of thing we want to know about.

I will not take up much more of the Senate's time. I will finish with a small piece from today's Australian Financial Review editorial, entitled `No time for diplomatic niceties'. It concludes as follows:

As the trip was predictable and is likely to be forgotten in the coming surge of diplomatic visitors to South Africa, the senator's temper had its uses in ensuring that South Africans, particularly white South Africans, will not easily forget our foreign minister.
As Senator Evans' basic message is not one that white South Africans want to hear, the trip may well have done some good.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The visit of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to South Africa was a disaster and an embarrassment to him personally, to his Government and to Australia. It was ineffective for four reasons. Firstly, he interfered with the internal political affairs of South Africa by selecting only one political party-the African National Congress (ANC). It is a failure of politics. If any country tried to do that in our region we would call it interference, for that is what it is. Secondly, he lectured and abused his host in South Africa to his own and to Australia's discredit. It is an abysmal failure of diplomacy and yet this is the first diplomat of Australia, so-called-the Foreign Minister of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, naively, he failed to ensure that reasonable and sound checks were in place to ensure that the $15m grant to the ANC and the further $2m grant to the ANC that the Minister has just announced would in fact be spent for the purposes that even he has defined. This is a failure of ministerial control. If there is time I will come back to that matter and refer to the review report of the special assistance program for South Africans and Namibians published just three months ago within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade by the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau which shows that there is a failure, that there are insufficient checks and that the Minister's answer to my question during Question Time today is totally inadequate and amounts to a misleading of the Senate.

Fourthly, there was a failure, demonstrated in the media over recent days and in the Senate here today, by Senator Evans to apologise or to see himself as being in any way at fault with regard to any of his activities in South Africa.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has walked out.

—He has walked out; he is no longer in the chamber to hear the Senate's debate on his appalling mistakes and the disaster that his visit has meant for Australian diplomacy in South Africa. He has roundly abused everyone except himself. Mr Deputy President, did you hear his remarks at Question Time? He abused even the Opposition. He abused the Australian media. He abused the other blacks of South Africa who are not members of the ANC and he even abused his host, the South African Government, and the security officials in particular.

SPEECH.PARA: He has failed to be accountable. I am afraid that we have seen such behaviour in his actions in relation to India, Cambodia, Fiji, the Asia-Pacific region and so on. It is yet again demonstrated to the world that it is a trait in Senator Evans's conduct as Foreign Minister to go to a country and offend that country through the kinds of disastrous activities that I have just outlined. To claim, as he did in his speech today, that he was just opposing apartheid and that that was sufficient excuse for all of his mistakes is, frankly, an insufficient excuse. We all oppose apartheid. The question is: what policies have we put in place, what policies do we espouse and in what manner do we, by our personal and government activity, pursue those policies to see the effective end of apartheid? There has been a great gulf between the Opposition's approach to how to end apartheid and this Government's approach. The Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, has rightly described some aspects of Senator Evans's visit to South Africa as an attempt to catch up with the Opposition's more productive approach to see the end of apartheid. It is certainly no excuse for Senator Evans just to claim that he was doing all of these things and making all of these errors in the name of opposing apartheid.

I have referred to the case of Senator Evans offending India. In August last year he went to India and not only offended the Government of that country but also the journalists of both Delhi and Islamabad. When he was corrected in Australia over the way he had misled both India and Pakistan, he again blamed the journalists and the Government. When I asked him in November last year whether he had received a letter of complaint from the Foreign Minister of India he replied, `I do not recall'. The kind of behaviour that we have seen from Senator Evans in South Africa is the kind of behaviour we saw from him in India last year and which he has demonstrated in so many other instances. He has become an embarrassment to the Hawke Labor Government and I believe--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Teague, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the matter of public importance put forward by Senator Hill. It is not surprising that this has come from the Opposition. Those opposite have been apologists for South Africa for longer than many of us can remember-with the honourable exception of the former Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, who, if most of them could get their way, they would expel from the Liberal Party forthwith because he has been the only Liberal in 30 years who has had the guts to stand up to South Africa on the issue of apartheid. The rest of those opposite have ummed and ahed and nibbled and nitpicked, but none of them have had the guts to put squarely on the record their opposition to apartheid with sanctions that count. All they have done is whinge and whine and complain about Malcolm Fraser. It has been a disgrace to the Liberal Party, and to many Liberals who campaign openly against apartheid, that their parliamentary representatives have consistently run away from taking some tough action against South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not claim to be an expert on South Africa although I did have an opportunity to visit that country briefly earlier this year. I am not surprised that Senator Evans got the reception he did. When we are dealing with an absolutely abnormal society, we will get an abnormal response when we are honest and tell those people that their society is rotten and corrupt. I made my views known very well but I was not the Foreign Minister. I have no doubt that the South African Government saw me as very small fry indeed compared with a Foreign Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —So Foreign Ministers have to swear.

—I must say that I did swear on several occasions when I visited the black townships and saw the appalling conditions in which a majority of South African citizens have to live. I think even you, Senator Bishop, if you walked through Soweto and saw those conditions, would show some emotion and some ability to say, `This is terrible'. Even you might swear at the conditions in which people have been forced to live for 40 years.
—Order! Senator Schacht, I would ask you to address your remarks through the Chair, please.

—I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. I certainly will. As I say, when we are dealing with an abnormal society, we are going to get abnormal responses. When we deal with people who have justified the most racist society in the twentieth century, of course they are going to take every opportunity to abuse those people who, in the international forums, have opposed that system, have proselytised against it and who have put forward processes of direct action to bring that system down.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us make no bones about it: if it were not for the international sanctions, apartheid would not now be in the process of being dismantled in South Africa. It is because of international sanctions that the system has fallen down. Members of the white society in South Africa will admit that quietly and privately but they will not say it publicly. Their economy was being wrecked by sanctions. They have had to give up the system for purely economic, not altruistic, motives. They could see that in the end even their standard of living was going to go down the gurgler. I think we ought to understand and not beat around the bush with the apologists opposite who scream all the time for the end of sanctions, that international sanctions have brought the end to the apartheid system.

It also has to be remembered that tens of millions of black people have bravely and with great dignity, despite the fact that they have had to exist under one of the worst governmental systems in modern history, been able to conduct a protest campaign, even if at times there has been violence because of the violence directed against them, to help to bring that system down. It is true that a number of white people dislike what Gareth Evans said and it is true that some black people dislike what he said. But there is no doubt that the overwhelming majority of black people cheered Gareth Evans to the echo for his strong remarks in attacking apartheid in South Africa. He is a hero of the black majority-the majority of South Africa-in the black townships.

Therefore, I think this matter of public importance is a mealy-mouthed typical piece of liberal wimpishness from people who think that the only way we can conduct foreign affairs is by doing nothing. That is not the way we achieve change in the world. We have to be active and at times take a risk in getting those changes made. We could be like Senator Hill and all the other Liberal shadow Ministers of foreign affairs who have sunk without trace in the last couple of years and have not achieved anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter we are discussing concerns three things: the confused interpretation by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) of Australia's national interest; his misplaced priorities as Foreign Minister; and his inability to behave and, thus, his ability to bring shame on Australia as a nation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the reply that we have heard from the Government, not one of those issues has been addressed. In the diatribe from Senator Schacht, all we heard was a simple smear campaign launched at the Opposition to somehow avoid the issue that we have been shamed as a nation by the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Senator Schacht then further attempted to misrepresent the position of the Opposition in relation to our stance on apartheid, including an assertion that only his side of politics somehow has a right to compassion. Further, he misrepresented my position and that of members of this Opposition in our attitude to those who are suffering. Shame upon you, Senator Schacht! I once thought that you would do a better job than Senator Evans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop, would you address your remarks through the Chair, please?

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I would be delighted to. Let us then examine the sorts of things that Senator Evans has done to shame this nation. It could well be said that Senator Evans marches to the beat of a different drummer. He certainly is not in step with the rest of the people of this nation who find his behaviour absolutely contemptible. Even members of his own Party were not in the chamber to give him any backing until the Whip sent out the message, `Bring some people in here at least to pretend we are supporting him'. As a Foreign Minister, he is supposed to ensure good relations with our neighbours and our trading partners and safeguard the interests of Australia and her citizens. What is his record? In his so-called defence he said to the nation at large, `Of course good relations with other countries are important but what I think and what I `-that is, Senator Gareth Evans, otherwise known as `Biggles-goes-to-Africa'- `want to impose is more important'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Deputy President had to ask that the Minister be heard in silence. Silence he can command; respect he cannot and will not. The brash nature of his self-defence was no answer at all. His behaviour is simply indefensible.

Let us look at the question of the Minister's confused interpretation of the Australian national interest. The Minister can rage upon the stage as he will. He can promote his own self-imagine as he will.-But let us look at a country close to us, a country with which our relationship is in tatters-and I refer to Malaysia. Last week in that country Malaysian television was running an anti-Australian campaign, the like of which has probably not been seen since the campaign to buy British last. We have seen a complete insensitivity by this Minister in respect of the handling of Malaysia. Not only have we re-run the second series of Embassy, which on 13 November Senator Evans admitted was a major component in our bad relations with that nation, but also the fight between Hawke and Keating has led to the Prime Minister cancelling his London meeting, which was to have included a meeting with Prime Minister Mahathir. That meeting having been cancelled as the result of an internal brawl, our relations have suffered.

The anti-Australian campaign has resulted in major setbacks to Australian trade patterns. A major contract worth some $160m has been lost simply because of the attitude that Malaysia presently has to Australia. Senator Hill made the point that the behaviour of Senator Evans is that of a spoilt brat and that is exactly the way that Malaysia presently portrays Australia's attitudes. Last year and during the course of this year I have mentioned the behaviour of the Australian Customs Service. I have spoken about the way in which two of its officers behaved in relation to seizing and keeping documents in the face of a High Court of Malaysia order. This almost resulted in extradition proceedings and damage to the five-power defence arrangement. Senator Walters said, by way of interjection when Senator Evans was speaking, that his defence was the kind that we were used to hearing from our children: `They made me do it, mummy; it wasn't my fault'. Senator Evans, out of his own mouth said, `None of it was my doing. Somebody told on me'. He then went on to quote the Ambassador to South Africa as somehow defending his honour-what an extraordinary thing for a man to do! The Ambassador to South Africa was showing up the Foreign Affairs Minister. Indeed, he demonstrated that he knew how to behave and how to try to salvage something out of the ruin that was the visit to South Africa.

Time and again we see the manner in which foreign affairs are conducted being reflected in the way the whole Department is administered. Not only do we see the behaviour of some of our ambassadors reflecting the high-handed attitude of the Minister but also we see our relations deteriorating in our own region.

At the beginning of his address Senator Hill pointed out our geographical situation, how we live in the Pacific region, and how we need to have good relations with our neighbours. He dealt with the current visit to South Africa as what had become the epitome of the behaviour of the Foreign Affairs Minister. Senator Teague has dealt with the ramifications of that behaviour in India, and I am now dealing with the ramifications of that behaviour in Malaysia. Yet what we hear from those opposite are interjections that somehow it does not matter, that somehow it is all right.

When questions are asked of the Foreign Minister about the seriousness of the situation and the way in which these problems are being tackled, we get a glib answer, `We sweep it under the carpet and pretend it does not matter'. Perhaps Senator Evans thinks he ought to be conducting the Senator Evans Charm School of Good Diplomacy. I would have thought the things he ought to learn-and needs to learn-are patience, tolerance, good manners and negotiating skills. In his defence today, the Foreign Minister showed quite clearly that, firstly, he possesses none of those attributes, secondly, aspires to none of them and, thirdly, does not mind very much whether others follow him or not--

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we both have the same flu.

—Senator Schacht, it is that time of the year when I am afraid coughs and colds are indeed with us. One could hope and wish that Senator Evans had gone to South Africa with such a complaint and been afflicted with laryngitis, and then this country may have been saved the embarrassment of a Foreign Minister swearing at foreign nationals-indeed, I believe throwing things at them-and coming back here saying that it is really okay. I suppose in this chamber we ought to be profoundly relieved that Senator Evans has not taken to throwing things at other senators. Perhaps we ought to be particularly relieved that there is no smoking in this chamber so that he does not have access to a heavy ash tray which he could throw across at a senator or two, as perhaps he has been known to do at other folk--
—If his aim were accurate, it would be okay.

—The interjection from Senator Schacht that it is okay as long as it is accurate is really pathetic. For those opposite to condone the behaviour of a Foreign Minister who swears at foreign nationals, who throws things, who loses his temper and has no idea of the way to conduct and to disport himself is indeed an indictment of the entire Government. One could say that he said today that the end justifies the means. The end of his diplomatic foray would justify his either being sacked or resigning. It certainly does not justify his remaining in office. He owes an apology not only to those people whom he insulted but also to the Australian people because he has brought them into ill repute. Other people in the region see that he is the man who represents this nation. I, for one, and others, will say that his behaviour, and his conduct of that portfolio, in no way reflects the opinions of other Australians.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented. The first misrepresentation was that of Senator Schacht in which he defamed not only me but also my colleagues by referring to us as `apologists for apartheid'. He had no basis for saying that. My Party has fought against apartheid ever since its implementation. I regard the accusation as highly offensive; it is untrue. Apartheid is an abhorrent system and I am pleased that it is being dismantled. I have demonstrated that in the past by my actions. I have been in the same townships that Senator Evans visited and I have seen the appalling conditions; it is just that I think I behaved differently when I was there.

SPEECH.PARA: The other misrepresentation was that of Senator Evans when he said that on 16 April I said that sanctions had worked. I did not say that. What he was referring to was a press release in which I referred to the European Community's changed position in which it had decided to abandon its position on economic sanctions. It said it believed that sanctions had been successful to date, but further implementation of them would be counterproductive. I expressed that in that press release and did not express my personal views at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —That concludes the matter of public importance debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADVANCE TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE-MAY 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In speaking to this document, Advance to the Minister for Finance-May 1991, I would also address the second document, the Supporting Applications from the Advances to the Minister for Finance-May 1991 because the two are essentially related. The Advance to the Minister for Finance is always presented monthly in this place and is a fascinating document. This month it contains more than its fair share of fascination. It is a very lengthy document with numerous advances as we approach the end of the financial year. There are four or five that I wish to mention in the very limited time available to me.

At least two of the advances highlight the significance and depth of the recession that we were not going to have-the engineered recession that the former discredited Treasurer, Mr Keating, brought upon us. One of those relates to an additional requirement for child-care fee relief. The other relates to additional payments required for vocational training and income support for persons affected by structural change in particular industries or regions.

The first one, dealing with child-care, seeks an additional $2.9m by way of additional urgent and unforeseen expenditure to cover late advances and additional adjustments for the period April 1991 to June 1991. The main reason why it was unforeseen-according to the Department-is the strong evidence that the amounts required are the direct outcomes of this recession. The Department of Community Services and Health says that the trend of reduced incomes of families using child-care and the increased utilisation of family day care could be direct effects of the recession. This is not the first month in which similar additional payments have been required for this purpose, if my memory serves me correctly.

It is a very significant indicator of the depth of the recession, as is the fact that an additional $0.5m is being required by the Department of Employment, Education and Training, as I said earlier, for vocational training and income support for persons affected by structural change in particular industries or regions.

Despite having three goes at getting this figure right this financial year, this late in the year requirement has been brought forward, according to the Department, because the earlier attempts to get the figure right did not foresee the large numbers of retrenchments in industry-particularly those in the passenger motor vehicle industry-that have occurred in recent months. There is much more one could say on those but they are both significant indicators of the extent of the recession.

The third advance I want to comment on-and I think the Senate will be hearing a lot more of this because it is a classic example of a waste of government money-is a requirement for an additional $1.8m to meet the costs of the compilation and distribution of the energy guide to every household in Australia. I will not go into the details, but people will remember getting this guide in their letterbox in recent times. It was an absolute waste of money. It was trying to show people how to save energy. That is a desirable thing in its own right but the involvement of the Government in this was just extraordinary. That figure, I might point out, is not a final cost, nor does it appear to include the cost of postage to 5 1/2 million households in Victoria. At something like 80c a stamp, that is a very significant additional amount.

Finally, I refer to two items relating to the payments to meat inspectors in Victoria who have been made redundant. The first is a payment of $450,000 to 10 Victorian meat inspectors who have been made redundant. The second is a figure of $890m which the Commonwealth of Australia is loaning to the Government of Victoria to enable it to make the appropriate separation payments to those 10 officers. I doubt whether we have ever had a more classic example of how broke the Kirner Government has made the State of Victoria. The Victorian Government has to borrow $890,000 from the Commonwealth to enable it to meet its superannuation redundancy pay-outs. That is absolutely extraordinary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Short, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Advance to the Minister for Finance document, as did my colleague Senator Short. I make reference particularly to the last item he raised-that is, the superannuation pay-outs to the redundant Victorian meat inspectors-and also to the loan arrangements that have been put in place for the Victorian Government. The activities occurring in that State are a classic example of the misuse of funds into an industry that has been continually abused and downgraded. We find the Commonwealth being forced to lend moneys to a State government when I believe, if that is the track that has to be gone down, the responsibility should be that of the State Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look for a moment at what is happening in the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service (AQIS). When we examine what is occurring there, we find that the workload in the meat industry has been significantly reduced as a result of the blatant abuse of both the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, resulting in the drop-off in Australian exports and the very significant cuts in export revenue to this country from the lack of exports from this great country of ours. That figure now is in excess of $200m.

Setting aside for the moment the problems that exist within AQIS and the need to restructure and commercialise that organisation-in fact, I would go one step further and privatise it-had those losses not occurred, and had there not been the abuse that has occurred consistently in the meat industry, I believe that under the current structure it would not have been necessary to make these people redundant. This is a side effect of a show that has been running for some 15 to 18 months.

When are we going to get a positive policy statement from the Government for the future direction of the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service? Are we going to see the roles of quarantine and inspection separated and run as separate operations? Is it going to continue as the muddled operation that it is at present? What happens now in that industry? For example, in my State of Western Australia, where the domestic inspection and the export inspection are separated, for domestic inspection the cost is $44,000 gross per year per man whereas for export inspection done through the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service it is $65,000-in effect, another $21,000 per man doing the same job to provide a service.

In the limited time I have to speak, I emphasise the point that I think it is an absolute disgrace how broke a number of the State governments in this country are. In this case it is Victoria, but the situation existing in Western Australia, which we will be talking about shortly, is no different to that which exists there. I find it totally untenable that we find, slid in here under this allocation to the portfolio of Primary Industries and Energy, a loan to a State government to carry out a responsibility which is essentially the responsibility of that government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to only one item in this back-up document supporting the applications for the issue of Advances to the Minister for Finance (AMF). It is in line with comments that I have made about the use of the Advance on previous occasions.
—Senator Bishop, are you intending to speak to document 1 or 2?

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I can say, if you like, that I am speaking on item 1, but the documents are entwined in a way in which they really cannot be separated. So I will speak to document No.1 and have another go on document No. 2.

SPEECH.PARA: Document No. 1 lists that there is an allocation of moneys to the Australian Federal Police sought. The reason given is:
An additional $207,000 is urgently required to meet expenses expected to be incurred within the next month.
The application is dated 23 May. I continue:
This amount includes claims on hand and further compensation and legal claims expected to be received and become due for payment before 6 June.
In the explanation as to why the requirement from the AMF is required, it says:

The level of expenditure in the compensation and legal item in the year to date has been greater than anticipated. Historically, this has been a difficult item in which to forecast the level and timing of payments.

There is something rather inconsistent about those two statements. The first is that we urgently require money to meet expenses which we expect to be incurred within the next month-not that we know we have incurred or that we have received but that we think we might incur.

Over the page it says that it is desperate that we get the money because it is really rather difficult to calculate. None of those reasons are acceptable reasons for an Advance to the Minister for Finance to be drawn upon. If I look at some of the other applications and the reasons why these matters are either urgent and unexpected or in one of the other categories acceptable, at a cursory glance-and we only get these documents a little while before we have to speak on them-the payments seem to be becoming easier to get. I find it very worrying to think that such a practice might be slipping in.

In Estimates I asked whether we could have a list of all the unsuccessful applications for Advances to the Minister for Finance to be drawn down so that we could see those departments which are able to properly prepare their accounts, both for the Budget Session and the Supplementary Estimates hearings. I think a practice that ought not to be countenanced, nor tolerated, is departments thinking that they can improperly prepare their Budget forecasts and get away with making applications to the Advance to the Minister for Finance. It is important that all members maintain the scrutiny of these documents on a regular basis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw attention to two matters in the Advance to the Minister for Finance. The first, relating to the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories portfolio, is the Australian Sports Drug Agency. Additional funding is required because it was not expected by the Government that this agency would be operating on its own account at the time of the Budget. But, as a result of pressure from the Opposition, that agency is now in place, and legislation which was not ready to go through the Parliament was hurried through at the end of last year on the Opposition's insistence.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention this matter because of the news at the weekend that Mr Martin Vinnicombe, an Australian cyclist, claimed that he had been harassed by the Australian Sports Drug Agency in respect of his drug testing, which provided a positive result and resulted in his being suspended for two years and turning professional. I understand that it is not correct for him to claim that he had been subjected to unfair testing by the Australian Sports Drug Agency. On the contrary, I understand that normal testing has proceeded and that there are automatic requirements for testing when a world time is involved.

In terms of the random testing that the Australian Sports Drug Agency undertakes, I am assured that there has been no harassment and no unfair concentration on Mr Vinnicombe whatsoever. The Australian Sports Drug Agency has been behaving in an entirely proper way in this matter and should be commended for ensuring that people who seek to cheat on their country and their competitors should not be allowed to get away with it, no matter how high their status has been in a sport.

The second matter I want to refer to relates to the Antarctic Division of that same Department. Mr Acting Deputy President, you have raised this matter consistently and are to be commended for your continual criticism of the contracts entered into by this division relating to the Aurora Australis and the general polar research program. The Additional Estimates indicate that another $74,043.35 is to be paid to P& Polar Australia Pty Ltd by the division for lay-up costs. This is the first time such a charge has been required to be paid by the Commonwealth. I believe that it is a disgrace that the Commonwealth is paying this. It indicates the sloppy way this contract was entered into and it confirms everything that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, have said on this matter. It follows the extra $34,000 that, as I recall, you have pointed out is required to pay for the ice pilot that was not provided for in the original tendering. According to the back-up papers:

. . . the Division is liable for ``lay up'' costs should the P& Polar Australia Pty Ltd not be able to charter the vessel in the winter season. As no work has been found for the RSV Aurora Australis during the 1990-91 winter season P& Polar has requested payment of $74,043.35 in lay-up costs for the period up to 30 April 1991. This payment was due for payment on 14 May but was delayed because of negotiations concerning the amount to be charged. Payment, however, is now due. Lay-up costs were not included in the 1990-91 Budget as there was considerable uncertainty as to the amount that would be required should the RSV Aurora Australis not be not chartered.

Quite frankly, it is unacceptable for the Government to behave in this way if it does not know what it is doing when it enters into contracts like this. If it does not provide for appropriate losses in the Budget, it is pretty tawdry management to come along here and fang another $74,000 out of the taxpayers of Australia to cover up for incompetent contracting. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPPORTING APPLICATIONS FROM THE ADVANCES TO THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In speaking to this document, the Supporting Applications from the Advances to the Minister for Finance, I want to elaborate a little more on the final issue that I was talking about in the Advance to the Minister for Finance, to which Senator Crane also referred-namely, the loan to Victoria of $890,000 to finance that State's payment of redundancy payments to 10 Victorian meat export inspectors. As Senator Crane said, it is due essentially to the fact that the industry in Victoria has been run down to an unbelievable extent, a run-down that has been caused almost entirely by the actions of one man, Mr Wally Curran, and his union, the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union.

I reiterate the extraordinary situation whereby the Commonwealth Government has decided to make a loan to the State Government of Victoria of $890,000 to enable it to meet some superannuation or redundancy payments. The fact that the State of Victoria is so broke that it has to go to the Commonwealth to find that amount of money for that purpose is, I believe, without precedent in Commonwealth history.

I will just say a couple of words about the meat industry. In doing so, I compliment my colleague Senator Winston Crane for the way in which he has been following this issue and pursuing it in the Parliament. I believe that the situation with the meat industry dispute in Victoria is the most extreme example of deliberate bloody-minded chaos caused by a union that we have had in Australia for a long time.

Only 18 months ago, Victoria had 27 operators servicing one of the Australia's biggest export markets-namely, the meat industry. At last count, that figure is down to six and there are some real doubts as to how long they will be able to continue. In the last 12 to 18 months, strikes in the industry have averaged one working day in every three. The cost to the country is more than $1m in lost exports from Victoria alone. The situation is such that, with bizarre working practices-which include a five-hour working day because of the tally system and a range of other activities which greatly inhibit the operations of the industry, once one of Australia's most thriving, vital industries and a vital industry for our future-that industry has been brought to its knees by the activities of that union in Victoria.

There is much more one could say about that matter, including, in particular, the very close relationship that Mr Curran has with the Premier of Victoria, Mrs Kirner. Allegations have been made in the Victorian Parliament that have not been refuted. The Victorian Government's submission to the Harrison inquiry into meat industry reform was shown to the union before it was submitted to the inquiry. The union made 13 or 15 proposed amendments to the Victorian Government's draft submission, virtually all of which were accepted so that the industry would appear in a whitewash situation. They are very serious allegations and have never been denied. They are indicative of the clandestine nature of the relationship between people like Mr Curran and the Victorian Government, which are a major source of the problems confronting that State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer, once again, to the $890,000 which the Commonwealth is lending to the Government of Victoria. I will also refer to what has been happening to the meat industry and its extension in a large way into Western Australia. This $890,000 is really just the tip of the iceberg in terms of the money that it has cost because of the continuing abuse of the legal processes which exist in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the abuse, I refer particularly to the Harrison inquiry into meat industry reform and will point out where we are now. I request the Government to come clean as to its position. It is all very well to slide an $890,000 loan under the back door to enable the Victorian Government to clean up some of its mess. Prior to leaving for overseas the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) wrote to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and requested that it adjourn the hearing to allow the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union (AMIEU) to come back in. At the same time, Martin Ferguson, the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), said that the Victorian Government and the Australian Government are supporting its position, which is to operate outside the Industrial Relations Commission.

It is worth noting that the ACTU requested this inquiry. It has been running over a period of 15 months or so-months and months of hearings costing taxpayers hundreds of thousands of dollars. Both the ACTU and the AMIEU have breached their agreement not to become involved in industrial action during the term of this inquiry. Union officials have been on an around the world junket-once again at the cost of taxpayers-to collect evidence about best world practices when that information is already well documented and available in this country.

Both the ACTU and the AMIEU walked out of the inquiry with just three days to go. The Government is trying to intervene to have the inquiry adjourned when there is just a short time to go before the inquiry brings down its report. At the same time the ACTU, which requested the inquiry in the first place, is operating on the outside.

I believe that this advance is supplementing quite disgracefully the position of the Victorian Government. The point I make is that it is really the tip of the iceberg of costs that have been foisted upon Australian taxpayers. This dispute extended last week in a large way into my State of Western Australia. Lambs were yarded in Perth for five days, purely and simply because the people involved at Robb's Jetty decided to adopt the same tactics that have been consistently adopted in Victoria. So the costs go on and on.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the animal welfare aspect?

—And animal welfare, absolutely. They have no respect for animal welfare and the suffering of the animals. There now is a flow on from what has been occurring for a significant period in the meat industry, not just in Victoria but across other States. This $890,000 is a giveaway to a government that sought, with the aid of Wally Curran, to undermine the Harrison inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL BOARD OF EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING: AUSTRALIAN RESEARCH COUNCIL REPORT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —That concludes the consideration of Government documents.

—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following reports of the Auditor-General: report No. 29 of 1990-91, Department of Employment, Education and Training-Jobtrain; report No. 35 of 1990-91, Potential Erosion of Accountability to the Parliament-Australian Wool Realisation Commission and Australian Wool Corporation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of Report No. 29.

I shall speak very briefly to this motion. It is important, even though we have a great deal of legislation on hand, to note that the Auditor-General has found considerable scope for criticism of this program on which, by the way, the Government has relied heavily in its propaganda about how it is allegedly resolving the problems of the unemployed in the recession we had to have and the unemployment we apparently also had to have.

The fact is that these schemes are not meeting the demands that have been created by the Government's incompetent economic management. The Auditor, briefly, has made these findings as a result of his investigation of this scheme. While the Audit Office found that Jobtrain improves the employment prospects of disadvantaged job seekers, the report states:
However, the extent of Jobtrain's contribution to improved employment prospects is uncertain at present.

This is the much vaunted Government program that was going to fix everything: it is uncertain at present. There is considerable scope for improving the efficiency and effectiveness of program administration. One of the key findings of the audit states:

The decentralised administration of Jobtrain has not been supported adequately with guidelines and advice to the CES network. There is significant variation in practices between States and Areas, and scope to improve administration based on best practice principles.
Other findings state:
While the program design, which integrates Jobtrain with other labour market programs, is sound, limited flexibility of targets and budgets restricts performance.
Target setting for Jobtrain activities is not directly linked to desired outcomes.
Course acquisition processes, including forward planning, specification of requirements, tendering and selection procedures all need to be strengthened.
The report continues:
. . . over half the Jobtrain participants were unemployed for less than six months prior to their selection for courses. Better targeting is needed.
This was supposed to fix up problems for the long term unemployed; yet we see that over half of the participants were unemployed for less than six months. The Auditor further found:
Linking of courses to meet the skills needs of individual jobseekers is rare, and post-course assistance is not provided in most cases.
This is the `dramatically successful' scheme the Government has trumpeted about so much. The Auditor does note:
Recommendations arising from Departmental reviews of Jobtrain have not been adequately addressed.
There is scope for better evaluation of program outcomes, including comparisons with other labour market programs.

I am particularly concerned about that last point. I think it was in 1987 or 1988 that the youth scheme was incorporated into this new scheme. According to the Auditor-General, this was apparently done without any detailed Government guidance at all. The Auditor-General makes the point that policy guidance for Jobtrain is incomplete.

If the Government is to have major unemployment in a major recession that we had to have and that was all engineered, could it not have engineered its job schemes a little better?
