Does it have to engineer such high levels of unemployment anyway? It seems to me that the findings of this Auditor-General's report are matters of major concern. I am glad to see that the Department of Employment, Education and Training agrees with the Auditor-General in many areas and that it will pursue these faults that have been pointed out.

I mention in passing that when we look at schemes such as this we very much need the Auditor-General's advice. He points out, for example, that the published running cost data of Jobtrain underestimates the cost of administering the scheme since resource expenditure by the CES network in support of Jobtrain is omitted. He establishes that the cost is several million dollars higher than outlined by the Government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of Report No. 35.

I wish to address one particular aspect of the Auditor-General's Report No. 35-the potential erosion of accountability to the Parliament-presented to the Parliament today. I share the concerns of the Auditor-General about the removal of accountability and the weakening of Parliament's role in the scrutiny and reporting on activities of public sector enterprises. I agree with him that this removal of public scrutiny appears to be gaining strength under this Australian Labor Party Government.

I remind the Senate of the recommendation of a famous report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, report No. 296, which the Government accepted. It was endorsed not only by the Committee but also by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, by a subsequent review of the Auditor-General's office by Mr T.A. Sheridan and by the independent auditor appointed by the Government. In its report No. 296, the Committee said:

The Audit Act 1901 be amended to require the Auditor-General to be appointed the external auditor of all Government companies. Private sector audit firms and partnerships which are the external auditors of Government companies would continue until their appointments expire, whereupon the Auditor-General would become the company's external auditor.

The matter at issue is significant. We are looking at the audit of a $2.7 billion debt involving a 4.7 million bale stockpile. We were led to believe that, where the Auditor-General is not the appointed auditor of such government business enterprises (GBEs) as the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wool Corporation, there would be special circumstances which would be explained, firstly, to the Auditor-General and, secondly, to this Parliament. None of those obligations was met by this Government.

It appears to be very much a shady deal because we are told by the Auditor-General that in the early hours of 31 May 1991, without consultation with the Australian National Audit Office, the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill and the Australian Wool Corporation Bill were introduced into the House of Representatives without an opportunity for the Auditor-General to comment or make an input. If we look at those Bills carefully we will note that a deliberate attempt has been made to circumvent the audit by the Australian National Audit Office of those particular authorities. That is just not good enough. We are interested as a Parliament and as a Senate in restoring the mandate of the Auditor-General. It is very important that where there are special circumstances they are communicated to the Parliament. This has not been done.

It is significant concerning the accountability of all government business enterprises that this Parliament has a significant input in their reporting. The Auditor-General is an essential link between this Parliament and government business enterprises. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts is seeking mechanisms to try to strengthen the relationship between the Parliament, the people and the GBEs. One of its current inquiries concerns the social responsibilities of government business enterprises and their community service obligations. It is a dereliction of the duty of the Government to go behind the back of the Auditor-General and seek to appoint private sector auditors. It could be construed, incorrectly in some quarters, that the Auditor-General does not have the skill to conduct such an audit.

I have great confidence in the professionalism of the Australian National Audit Office and its officers. They have the skills, and this has been demonstrated in the various reports that the Auditor-General brings to parliament. Perhaps his comments are cutting too close to the bone and the Government is suffering. If that is the reason, it is a further condemnation of this Government's seeking avenues and methods to escape proper reporting and accountability to this Parliament. These issues will be raised again when the wool Bills come before the Parliament, but I should like to take this opportunity to endorse the statements and the action taken by the Australian National Audit Office in bringing this matter to our attention. I ask the Minister at the table, the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), whether today he can tell us those special circumstances, because this Parliament has a right to know why the Australian Audit Office was not appointed under these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the record my wholehearted support for the use of the Auditor-General for the auditing of Commonwealth bodies. I do so on two main grounds: firstly, on the ground of proper accountability and, secondly, on the ground that not to do so is a further erosion of the public sector. I indicate on the record my support for the use of the Auditor-General, which of course is in accordance with the statement of the Minister for Finance last year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too want to comment on the Auditor-General's report No. 35 on the potential erosion of the accountability to the Parliament in relation to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill and the Australian Wool Corporation Bill. As Senator Watson has said, both these Bills were introduced into the House of Representatives on 31 May. They are important Bills. The Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill establishes the Commission that will take over the $2.7 billion debt and the 4.7 million bale stockpile presently held by the Australian Wool Corporation. It will also be responsible for the discharge of the debt and the disposal of the stockpile and other assets. That is a major task facing the Wool Realisation Commission. Therefore, that Bill is a major Bill, as is the Australian Wool Corporation Bill, which establishes the new Corporation which will facilitate the adoption of appropriate strategies for the promotion of wool, the efficient marketing of Australian wool and proper measures to ensure a high quality for Australian wool. It is very significant, as the Auditor-General makes clear in his report, that these Bills were introduced into the Parliament without any consultation at all with the Auditor-General or his office.

SPEECH.PARA: It is quite obvious that the Bills are of such magnitude and significance that the audit function is of the utmost importance. I congratulate the Auditor-General, Mr Taylor, on bringing this matter so quickly to the attention of the Parliament. It is obviously a report that he has had to prepare in considerable haste. It is a compliment to him that he has done it in the time available. I draw the attention of the Senate to the Auditor-General's covering letter to Mr President and Mr Speaker, where he says:
The Bills proposing the creation of the above Commission and Corporation have serious implications for accountability to Parliament.
The Bills are still to go through the Parliament-although they have gone through the House, they are to be debated in the Senate later this week. As the Auditor-General says:

I would be most grateful if this report could be tabled at the earliest opportunity, to allow Senators to consider their position with respect to my report before the Bills are debated, and so that members may be informed of my concern.

This has great topicality for this Senate because it relates to important issues in Bills that are to be debated and voted on later this week, the last week of the parliamentary session. As the Auditor-General says, from his point of view the major issue in both Bills is the potential for the erosion of accountability to the Parliament. That is an issue which I believe everyone in this chamber, from whatever side of politics, would endorse absolutely and heartily.

According to the Auditor-General-and I agree with him-the Bills bias the audit function away from the Auditor-General. The Bills require that the Minister for Finance explain in writing his reasons for declining to approve the appointment of a recommended private sector auditor. But no such requirement exists if the Minister agrees to the appointment of a private sector auditor. The appointment of a private sector auditor thereby weakens parliamentary scrutiny because it excludes the Auditor-General's requirement that he has to report directly to the Parliament-and this is the great virtue of the Auditor-General's role. So, the appointment of a private sector auditor would automatically weaken parliamentary scrutiny.

Under the Bills, the Minister is not required to explain what `special circumstances dictate' the granting of an exemption. As has already been said, the Government, when it tabled its response to report No. 296 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on the reform of the Audit Office, recognised that the Auditor-General is a major vehicle for the accountability of government enterprises to the Parliament.

The Government indicated at that time that the Auditor-General is to be the sole auditor of all government owned or controlled entities. However, the Government also agreed that the Minister for Finance may provide exemptions in the case of statutory marketing authorities and government business enterprises where special circumstances dictate. It foreshadowed, though, at that time that the legislative amendments to implement that change would be included in the new legislation to replace the existing Audit Act 1901-that is, the audit provisions would be in a simplified central Act and not in individual Acts with their potential for variation in approach.

The Auditor-General is concerned that under these Bills-and, indeed, in any situation-a private sector auditor will not have responsibility to the Parliament. To provide for a private sector auditor, unless there are very special circumstances, really would turn the Westminster system on its head.

It might be argued that, unless the Minister for Finance agrees to an exemption, the Auditor-General is automatically the auditor. The Government may well argue that point. But, if it is unlikely that other than the Auditor-General would be the auditor, why is the provision for exemption included, particularly in a Bill for which anyone would be hard pressed to explain away the direct taxpayers involvement and interest in it? We are talking about $2.7 billion of debt for which potentially the Australian taxpayer is at risk. It is just not comprehensible for anyone to say that the taxpayer does not have a very vested interest in this situation.

The mere inclusion of the potential exemption from the Auditor-General's mandate to audit is an open invitation for political pressures to be applied to the Minister for Finance to grant the exemption. There are no countervailing clauses in this Bill to require such an exemption to be justified. When we come to debate these Bills later in the week it will be obligatory for the Government to provide reasons for this.

I understand-and my colleagues Senator Bishop and Senator Watson, as members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, would know better than I-that the legislative provisions in the proposed new legislation to replace the Audit Act 1901 include a provision which reads as follows:

The Auditor-General is to be the sole external auditor of all Commonwealth agencies and entities, except where the Minister for Finance has determined that an entity may make other audit arrangements. The Minister for Finance may not make a determination to grant an exemption unless he has first consulted the Auditor-General.

That is a markedly different emphasis from the drafting in the current Bills, which completely changes the onus of responsibility and the onus of decision making as between the Auditor-General and a private auditor. The key to whether this provision in the new legislation to replace the Audit Act represents a real restoration of parliamentary accountability and of the mandate of the Auditor-General depends upon the exemptions allowed.

The wool Bills before the Parliament do nothing at all-indeed, the contrary is the case-to reassure the Parliament in this regard. If the potential is seen by the Government for an exemption in a Bill dealing with $2.7 billion of debt and a 4.7 million bale stockpile shouldered by the taxpayer, where would the Auditor-General be accepted as having a clear mandate? If there is a doubt in this case, where on earth are we ever going to get a clearer example of where there should be an absolute and clear mandate for the Auditor-General? Is the Parliament prepared to leave matters such as this to ministerial discretion, which is really what the Bill involves? The answer to that surely must be, no.

In the Auditor-General's view-and it is one with which I totally concur-the only ground for cutting the Auditor-General out of the accountability loop and thereby eroding parliamentary scrutiny would be the complete privatisation of a government entity, in which case there would be no government involvement. If that is not the case, the Auditor-General must still have a mandate. If he is not to be given a mandate, there must be the very clearest reasons given as to why.

I again congratulate the Auditor-General on his strength of purpose in bringing this report forward to the Parliament. Two points must be cleared up before we debate the wool Bills on Thursday: first, the Government must spell out clearly the criteria of exemption from scrutiny by the Auditor-General; and, secondly, it must give us some examples of the sorts of special circumstances that could conceivably dictate the appointment of outside auditors.

In my view, there is no doubt that the wool Bills, about which the Auditor-General has expressed such concern, do not fall-certainly not prima facie and I find it hard to believe in other circumstances either-in the special circumstances category. Large amounts of taxpayers' funds-up to almost $3 billion of taxpayers' funds-are potentially involved in this.

As I said earlier, if the Auditor-General does not have a total mandate in respect of a Bill like that, where on earth is he going to have such a mandate? If this Government will not give him such a mandate on an ongoing basis, then one can only have the gravest of doubts about the Government's bona fides and motivation in this matter. It does seem clear, on the face of it, that a deliberate attempt is being made to weaken the mandate, the role and the authority of the AuditorGeneral. If that is a matter of fact, then it is not only a matter of concern for the Parliament-and that is concern enough-but also it is also a matter of great concern for each and every Australian.

I hope that very quickly, certainly before these wool Bills are debated later in the week, we will have a response from the Government on this matter. Even beyond that, the whole question of the role of the Auditor-General and the mandate which he should be given and to which he is entitled is something that must be debated much more thoroughly and much more satisfyingly in this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion that the Senate take note of this document. It is for the very reasons that Senator Baume gave with regard to the previous report that we should take very careful note of this report by the Auditor-General. In the previous report, the Auditor-General examined the Department of Employment, Education and Training, made an efficiency audit and reported to the Parliament, thus enabling us to examine and comment upon a fundamental component of democracy, which is a fundamental role of elected members of this Parliament. For that reason, we should be most concerned about what the Auditor-General has written in this report with regard to the potential erosion of accountability to the Parliament in relation to the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wool Corporation.

SPEECH.PARA: I emphasise the point which was made in the Auditor-General's covering letter, to which Senator Short referred, especially the paragraph which reads:
The Bills proposing the creation of the above Commission and Corporation have serious implications for the accountability to Parliament. They are at present in the Senate.

I emphasise that point, not to increase the level of disinterest, but to try to point out that that covering letter was written with a direct concern about what was contained in these wool Bills that are soon to come before the Senate.
The level of concern that the Auditor-General has is expressed on page 2 of his report where he states:
In the early hours of 31 May 1991, without consultation with the ANAO, the above Bills-
they are the Bills with regard to the Wool Realisation Commission-
were introduced into the House of Representatives which I believe could tilt the balance against Parliamentary scrutiny of public sector entities.
I will quote further from this report. I know that we can read it, but I think that it requires emphasis. Further, the Auditor-General states:

This action was despite the Government's decision that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities announced in a statement by the Government on 6 December 1990 . . .

So the response that Senator Short has been asking for and hoping will come has already been made. The Government has already responded on 6 December 1990 that the Auditor-General shall be the sole external auditor. I think that we should emphasise that point. Perhaps we do need a restatement of that. Perhaps we need to remind the Government that that statement has already been made. We are reminded of it by the Auditor-General in his report. As he tells us, that statement was made in response to the examination by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts of the Audit Office and the Sheridan Review.

This decision was qualified, however, in respect of statutory marketing authorities and government business enterprises in that it allowed the Minister for Finance to provide exemptions to the requirement that the Auditor-General be the sole external auditor where special circumstances dictate. Again, I agree with Senator Short; we have had no enumeration of those special circumstances in this case. If anything should be scrutinised by the Auditor-General, it is this very situation of the Wool Realisation Commission and its mandate to manage the wool debt and the stockpile.

I hope that listeners to this debate were able to distil from Senator Short's contribution the words `potential taxpayer debt'; it is not in fact a debt of close to $3 billion which is owed to the taxpayers at the moment. The word is `potential'. I acknowledge that that is the reason for his concern and our concern as well.
Another point from the Auditor-General's introduction to his report which I think it is necessary to emphasise is at paragraph 1.2.10 where he states:

The fact that some States have found it necessary to tighten accountability by strengthening the roles of the Auditors-General in the light of recent history should be sufficient warning against the dilution of the Parliament's and the Auditor-General's role, e.g. the report of the Commission on Accountability (the Burt Commission) to the Western Australian Premier . . .

We can take it that that is a fairly good example of the very needs that we are talking about. I also turn to Appendix 5 on page 33 of this report which I think it is important to quote from. Appendix 5 relates to accountability, independence and objectivity. It is a response to Report No. 296 of the Parliamentary Joint Committee of Public Accounts from September 1989. The appendix is headed `Audit Mandate'. It starts with a quote which reads:
The Auditor-General has an important role in upholding the interests of Parliament and taxpayers . . .
That is a statement made in Report No. 296 by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Following that, the appendix reads:

Necessarily, an accountability relationship exists between the Parliament and the Executive. This relationship is reinforced by the presence of a public sector auditor whose prime responsibility is to the Parliament, which has granted public funds to be used for specific purposes, and whose main task is to advise the Parliament whether such funds have been properly used.
A threshold question is why this accountability relationship requires a public sector auditor rather than a private sector auditor.
This is the very question relating to this whole business. The appendix further reads:
The Committee answered this question by indicating that:
* the Parliament can rely on the Auditor-General to identify or to filter the most important audit issues, and

* the Parliament would receive very large numbers of individual reports if the AAO was abolished and the tasks allocated to private sector audit firms, and would then have the complex task of identifying the most important issues.

There is more to the matter than that, but rather than stand here and highlight obvious points, I say that it was with a considerable degree of surprise that I came across this document. I thought that consultation would have taken place as was required, that consultation would have taken place before any of the wool Bills saw the light of day and that the Auditor-General would have been well informed of the ramifications of them. To have this sort of response come before us in this way is something which is most surprising to me. Having the document before us, I support the motion that we take note of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Several things are quite significant about this debate and the motion that we take note of this Auditor-General's report. The first is that all the speakers are constant in their criticism of the action that the Government has taken to remove the mandate of the Auditor-General from the oversight of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission and the Australian Wool Corporation. The second thing that is most significant is that the Auditor-General has seen fit to put out a media release highlighting his concern about this matter. On many occasions those of us who are concerned with public administration have gone on the record and said that the Auditor-General is the linchpin in the question of public administration; that, if the system of auditing by the Auditor-General breaks down, the system of accountability breaks down.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Joint Committee of Public Accounts brought down its report No. 296, to which all honourable senators have referred, we deliberately gave it the title The Auditor-General: Ally of the People and Parliament to highlight the importance of the role of the Auditor-General and the recommendations that we made. One recommendation was:
The Auditor-General should be reinstated as the external auditor of Statutory Marketing Authorities, considering their strategic importance in the Australian economy.
Another recommendation was:

Where the services of a private audit firm are considered necessary by a Statutory Marketing Authority and the Auditor-General agrees, then the Auditor-General appoint a private audit firm as a contract auditor under section 11 of the Audit Act 1901.

Importantly it was realised that there was a place for the private sector to act in the audit process but that the contractor auditor should only ever act as the agent for the Auditor-General so that the Auditor-General never lost his overriding mandate to perform that audit. Indeed, it was to be the Auditor-General's decision as to whether a private audit firm was engaged. Certainly, it was never contemplated that a Minister ought to have that very serious power to exercise at his discretion.

We waited for some considerable time for a suitable response from the Department of Finance to the recommendations that came down in report No. 296. We got that response, as others have said, on 6 December 1990. We have also had other committees consider this important function. The November 1989 report of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration into government companies had some important things to say on the nature and function of audit. I quote from its report, where it makes the following statement under the heading `Audit is not a service to management':

Much of the fashion for a move away from audit by the Auditor-General appears to be based on a misunderstanding of the role of an auditor. The purpose of audit is to provide an independent report on management, not a service to it. Management freedom should apply to management functions but the appointment of the auditor is the prerogative of the owners, not managers.

The owners in the public arena are the taxpayers. The degree and the standard of scrutiny will remain and is constantly different between the private and the public sectors. In the public sector, there is no discretion on behalf of the taxpayer whether or not he pays taxation and then how the Executive chooses to use it. The Executive may choose through policy how money is expended; the Parliament appropriates it. The Auditor-General oversights the proper expenditure and reports directly to the Parliament. That is the method of scrutiny. We have various committees which assist the Parliament in that scrutiny. But at the end of the day all those committees report here in this chamber and to the Parliament.

By the time the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) got around to replying to many of our responses, a significant supplementary response came down, as others have said, on 6 December. In that, we got a partial acceptance of the recommendations of the Public Accounts Committee. Others have quoted it, but it is worth quoting again:

It is the Government's view that all public enterprises are ultimately accountable to Parliament, and that a major vehicle for this accountability is the Auditor-General. Consequently, the Government has decided that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor for all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities.
This is where it made its exception, which was not acceptable in the original report:

. . . the Government has also agreed that the Minister for Finance may provide exemptions in the case of statutory marketing authorities and Government business enterprises where special circumstances dictate.

I have two things to say about that. The original Public Accounts Committee report No. 296 said that it was important that the Auditor-General should always maintain his independence. We were keen to see that the resources which the Auditor-General had were not determined by the Minister for Finance but should be determined by a committee of members of the Parliament chaired by a presiding officer. Indeed, this is the system which the New Zealand Parliament has finally agreed to. We did that because we felt that the Minister for Finance could curtail the work of the Auditor-General by curtailing the amount of resources available to him. After we brought down the report it was significant that the Minister for Finance did find additional resources for the Auditor-General to increase his workload.

By giving the discretion to the Minister for Finance to determine exemptions, we are again curtailing the independence of the Auditor-General, and the requirement that there be special circumstances-special circumstances would have to be made out-of course has been totally overridden by the two Bills that will come before us later this week, namely, the Australian Wool Corporation Bill and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill. In each case, the decision to appoint or not appoint a private firm, and therefore deprive the Auditor-General of his overriding mandate, is to be an arbitrary one; and it is simply not good enough. All senators who have spoken have said that the potential amount of money is somewhere near $3 billion of taxpayers' money, certainly never to be called an inconsequential sum. The principle remains resolute: it must be the Auditor-General who has the oversight of the appropriate and proper expenditure of that money.

As we come into the debate on those Bills, it will be most unfortunate if we find ourselves in the situation where a guillotine were to be applied simply to get the legislation through without these important points being resolved. I put it to the Government that it would be most sensible to reconsider the provisions in these two Bills in the two days that remain before we come to a full debate of these Bills and for the Government to move an amendment to each of those Bills to provide for the Auditor-General to hold the mandate to conduct the audit of these two corporations. Not to do so will make the debate more difficult and complicate the issues before us.

It is also quite significant that support for the proposition that the Auditor-General must maintain his mandate came not only from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and from the Committee on Finance and Public Administration but also from the independent review conducted by Mr Sheridan, the then Auditor-General of South Australia-some of us thought the Government was trying to get another view which might have disagreed with the view of the Public Accounts Committee; in fact, it did not-and from the Waitangi statement of March 1988 from the Australian Area Auditors-General. The report of the independent auditor, Mr Michael Sharpe of Coopers and Lybrand, again supported our proposition.

Certainly, we have not only moral authority but also pragmatic authority. There is, as I said, within the recommendations made by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, provision for private firms to be used, but the private firms would be used on a contractual basis and would be subject to the overriding mandate of the Auditor-General.

As I said at the beginning, it is most significant that honourable senators from all sides of the chamber-Senator Coates on the Government side; Senator Watson, who is the Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, Senator Short, Senator Crane and I on behalf of the coalition, and Senator Bell speaking for the Australian Democrats-have come to the unanimous conclusion that the Government has erred in making these provisions to give a discretion to the Minister for Finance to avoid the Auditor-General. It is with a sense of unity that so many honourable senators who would disagree with each other on other issues can come together to plead with the Government to reconsider the clauses in these Bills so that when we come to debate the legislation we will not be diverted from other issues that must be debated to again fight this argument to keep the place of the Auditor-General in the whole scheme of scrutiny, which finally means that the taxpayers get proper accountability for the expenditure of their money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak to the Auditor-General's report No. 35, I first congratulate the Auditor-General on the speed with which he has delivered this report to the Parliament and on its precision and clarity.

SPEECH.PARA: If one analyses the proposition that the Auditor-General has put before us, one can only conclude that it is a damning epitaph for the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in that portfolio. I will spend a couple of minutes discussing that aspect of the matter even though Minister Kerin has now left that portfolio. He is responsible not only for the Australian Wool Corporation Bill and the Australian Wool Realisation Commission Bill, but also for the 1987 legislation that removed section 41 from the principal Act and took away the role of the Australian Wool Corporation to report back to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Treasurer, and hence the Parliament of this country.

The Opposition sees that in effect the emphasis of these two Bills, as outlined in appendices Nos 1 and 2, is on ensuring that the reporting process is not back to this Parliament and is not done by Auditor-General, but by a private auditing operation. I invite honourable senators to read carefully appendices Nos 1 and 2 in this report. I emphasise that this is not the first time, in relation to the wool industry and the mess it is in today, that we have had a slack or inconsistent approach adopted to the financial responsibilities and the reporting process. In respect of the debt and the present size of the wool stockpile, it ought never be forgotten that it is essential that the realisation from that stockpile be maximised because growers have also had $1.8 billion-worth of levies taken from them in a revolving levy fund. Not much mention is made of that, but we are not really talking about $2.6 billion or just under $3 billion, we are talking about something like $4.5 billion tied up in the stockpile. It is absolutely essential, as other speakers have outlined, that this legislation is amended before it comes back here to be debated on Wednesday night, otherwise we will be dealing with an issue that should never have been brought before us.
I would like to make a couple of points in respect of paragraph 1.2.1 of the report, where the Auditor-General says:
I am very concerned that a continuing effort to weaken the Parliament's role in the scrutiny and reporting on the activities of all public-sector entities appears to be gaining strength.

However, we have heard a number of speakers today, including Senator Coates from the Government side, say just the opposite. Where is that continuing effort coming from? One must question the commitment and credibility of the Government when we deal with various aspects of this report and the report delivered on 6 December 1990, to which other speakers have referred. The Auditor-General further says that there is no reassurance in terms of reporting back to parliament. The Auditor-General refers specifically to `special circumstances'. Those special circumstances should be spelled out clearly. I believe there should be no special circumstances when it comes to holding or operating public funds, and it should be the responsibility of the Auditor-General to report back to parliament. In paragraph 1.2.6, the Auditor-General says:
These Bills pay lip service to words to the principle that the Auditor-General should be the sole external auditor of all Commonwealth owned or controlled entities.
Further he says:
The bias is against the Auditor-General.
As one works through the various points, one gets the same line of thought and the same statement of fact. In the last two paragraphs-paragraphs 1.2.11 and 1.2.12-the Auditor-General says:
I hope this is an oversight which will be corrected, rather than a reflection of a change in Government attitude to the role of the Parliament and the ANAO.
I ask that the Parliament consider the implications of these Bills for its future ability to scrutinise what has been done in its name.

I refer particularly to paragraphs 3.9 and 3.22, which refer to the Burt Commission on Accountability in Western Australia where the role of the Auditor-General in that Parliament has been enhanced, not decreased or undermined.

I conclude by reiterating what I said at the start: one must come back to the mess we have in the wool industry, and it is in a mess. In relation to this report, Minister Kerin should not go unscathed at the end of the day because in 1987 he, as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, had section 41 taken out of the Act; he was the Minister who appointed the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation and he appointed the Government representative on the board. As his epitaph as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy he presented two Bills to the Parliament which will in effect bypass the Auditor-General. However, today he is the Treasurer of this country and I pose the question: is he going to adopt the same process and attitude and present us with a similar situation when carrying out his functions as Treasurer?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the establishment of an industry council for the wool industry. The Council will replace the interim wool industry policy council established in September last year.

This Bill replaces the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill which had proposed a legislative framework under which industry councils could be established by regulation for particular primary industries. However, that Bill has been withdrawn due to Opposition concerns about legislation by regulation and the need for the legislation to be passed establishing a Wool Industry Council on 1 July 1991, which is the same date as the other new wool industry institutional arrangements are to come into force.

This Bill follows closely on the provisions of the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill except that it has been made specific to the wool industry and spells out the membership of the Council in clause 14.

The second reading speech for the Primary Industries (Industry Councils) Bill outlined the functions, powers, meeting arrangements and establishment of committees and working parties. Those principles are the same for this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: 11. Clause 63, page 28, after paragraph 4(1), add the following paragraph:

``(m) a condition that the holder must as soon as practicable and in association with other carriers, enter into an Ombudsman scheme, providing for investigation and report to AUSTEL in relation to complaints by consumers about all matters relating to service, billing and the manner of charging for telecommunications services;''.

This amendment introduces a condition on the licence which requires the carriers to enter into and agree to an ombudsman scheme. We know that the Australian Telecommunications Authority already has the power to investigate consumer complaints but the Australian Democrats believe that an industry ombudsman, although not necessarily of the banking industry type, will be of advantage to the industry in its attempts to monitor complaints, to investigate the carriers' own failings, and generally to ensure a higher standard of service to consumers. The Commonwealth Ombudsman, who currently handles most of the complaints against Telecom, will cease to exist after a transitional phase.

With their own ombudsman, we argue that the carrier services can bypass any cumbersome complaints reporting procedure and deal with minor complaints quickly and efficiently. We think the type of ombudsman should be determined by the carriers. At this stage it would be difficult to determine which scheme would be the most suitable, but the banking industry ombudsman is not really the sort of example that ought be emulated and that the carriers ought to follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be opposing this amendment. It is designed to provide a basis for an industry ombudsman scheme. More detail in relation to the scheme will need to be developed in the future, and perhaps future amendments will be needed when the industry comes up with the details of how the scheme is to work. The amendment on its own is insufficient as there is no indication of what Austel is to do following receipt of a report, but it does signal the basis of an approach which as far as the Government is concerned can be followed.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 12. Clause 63, page 28, after paragraph (4)(l), insert the following paragraph and subclause:
``; and (n) a condition that the holder must wherever reasonably possible, make arrangements to obtain technical services, equipment, parts or products from an Australian owned supplier.
(4a) The reasonableness of supply arrangements for the purposes of a condition of a kind referred to in paragraph (4)(n) shall be determined by reference to:
(a) the comparative cost of supply by an Australian owned supplier;
(b) the comparable quality of the services, equipment, parts or products;
(c) the availability of the services, equipment, parts or products; and
(d) any declarations, licence conditions, technical standards or other directives made by AUSTEL or the Minister.''.

This amendment seeks to insert a new licence condition (n). We want to protect Australia's embryonic telecommunications equipment capabilities and skills industry. Despite all the protestations and assurances to date by the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins), I still believe there is a very real danger that this industry, like the indigenous New Zealand telecommunications equipment manufacture, will disappear after deregulation.

In moving this amendment, I wish to redress some of the balance in the legislation, which asks what the industry can do for the carriers rather than what the carriers can do for the home-grown equipment industry. I acknowledge that most of Australia's equipment manufacturers have overseas parent companies and so in that stricter sense are not Australian-owned, but we have ample evidence of the commitment of these companies to research and development in Australia.

The amendment does not say that we cannot import; it simply says that, where there is an Australian product that is comparable in quality and availability, the carriers be required to show favour towards the Australian industry. I know that this amendment incorporates everything the free marketeers in both the Government and the Opposition do not like, but I believe in selective intervention and so do the Democrats. I believe that this industry requires some protection against the cheap foreign imports that will flood this country in response to deregulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not a free marketeer; I am a highly qualified marketeer. I do not think even Senator Alston is a laissez-faire, hands off, free marketeer either. The Government will be opposing this amendment basically because we do not think it will work in any way at all in practice. What it seems to do is impose on all classes of licence holders a requirement to give preference to Australian suppliers.
—Is that a bad thing?

—It is not, and of course we support that being done. I point out that, in the same kind of involved technology, considerable concern is being expressed about the involvement of Australian suppliers with air traffic control systems. I see Senator Kernot nodding her head and that is why I used it as an example; it is her area of portfolio responsibility as well. The difficulty is that, being a small aviation industry, we do not have the kinds of firms in Australia that are world leaders in the application of this kind of technology.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty is that clause 63(4c) in the Bill already covers what a licensee must do in connection with developing the telecommunications industry in Australia. The conditions that are laid down in this amendment are simply too prescriptive. They lock the industry arrangements into a prearranged structure before any kind of negotiations have actually taken place. If one goes to the subclauses in the amendment, who is to make the price and quality comparisons that are required by this amendment, especially where highly complex equipment is involved? It is not like buying produce on the open market. What price-quality differentials, as referred to here, are sufficient to force a carrier to then choose an Australian product over one that is available that might be better or cheaper or more efficient?

Does the amendment take into account the very significant matter-and I refer again to the air traffic control system-of the delivery times that are provided by various suppliers for this equipment? For example, a firm that is perhaps not up to the mark might want to write in 12 months for research and development on top of the delivery contract. It does not even take that into account. I just do not think this amendment has been sufficiently worked through, and for that reason the Government will not be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the Democrats simply proposing a condition that the holder must wherever possible make arrangements to obtain effectively Australian input. At least it would be on the table and we would know where people were coming from. But amendment No. 4A seems to me to make a nonsense of what precedes it because, by attempting to define reasonableness, it is in fact writing in the very sorts of things that people in a free market would want to take into account. They would probably, on the merits-as we would require them to do, in a sense-choose the foreign product if it was more than cost competitive.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think it makes any sense at all to take it together. Even if we were to take the hardline position, it would again be flying in the face of what is now I think almost orthodoxy-apart from the Democrats-that if one is to have a lower tariff regime, reduce protection and make industries more efficient, one cannot at the same time guarantee free kicks and free rides for what are often simply Australian subsidiaries of multinationals in any event. It is not as if the profits are staying here and it is not as if we are ensuring any more efficiencies. All we are doing is getting back to the bad old days of allowing people to have a guarantee of a source of income and a job, which is not a guarantee available to most other citizens in this country. The Opposition is opposing the amendment.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 7. Clause 63, page 28, after subclause (7), add the following subclause:
``(8) As soon as practicable after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, the Minister shall cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament a copy of the form of a licence''.

This amendment would require the Minister to lay on the table of each House of the Parliament a copy of the form of licence. TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

-What we have in mind with this amendment is simply to enable the public at large to have access to the form of document before it is signed. TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

To have to provide the pro forma of the licence is a fairly meaningless obligation. We have already agreed to table the licences to enable debate in any case, and we just do not see the need for this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston probably will not be surprised to know that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting this amendment. We, in fact, favour the retention of the duopoly. TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing this amendment which would do precisely what Senator Alston says, and that is permit a Minister to vary the term of the licence for particular classes at that Minister's whim. This will create uncertainty among applicants for the licence who will lack any security of tenure. It will, in fact, create a degree of uncertainty which we do not think is desirable, and we will be opposing the amendment.

6.18 p.m.)-I should indicate that we regard this as a very important provision in this clause-it is sufficiently important to divide on. We certainly take the view that the carrier would be given a power of veto to maintain the duopoly in the marketplace to a point which would seem quite unsustainable. For a Minister acting properly, as he or she is required to do, it would seem a nonsense where everyone is in heated agreement except the carrier with an acute vested interest in perpetuating the duopoly, to allow that carrier in effect to say, `Well, I'm going to determine the shape of telecommunications policy in this country'. We do not believe that is appropriate and we, therefore, believe this clause must be opposed.

—Mr Chairman, I wonder whether I could ask a question. I am a little bit confused as to exactly what this clause means. Does it mean that the Minister must obtain written consent of each carrier to make a declaration in accordance with clause 64, or must the Minister obtain from each carrier an agreement to the actual terms of the conditions which will be written into that declaration? If the latter is the case, it seems that there may just be some substance in what the Opposition is actually saying. But if it is simply permission to make a declaration, of course we would have to agree with the Government.
—I am not clear who was being asked for advice on this matter.
—I was afraid that I was being asked for advice.

—I suppose I am the bunny. The explanatory memorandum in respect of clause 67 says that the clause requires the Minister to obtain the consent of each carrier affected before imposing or varying a condition about the term the licence is in force. Therefore, I think the answer to Senator Coulter's question is that it is not in respect of each licence condition but only a subsequent attempt to vary a licence condition and, to the extent that it might want to cut short or vary the term of a licence, the carrier would have a power of veto. So, in that respect, it is simply saying that it is a matter for the carrier to decide whether the Government ought to be in a position to cut short the term of the licence.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I confess that my confusion was also caused by the fact that I was not sure where the question was being directed. I can understand why the Opposition wants to divide on this amendment, but I wish to assure Senator Coulter that we will be dividing on it, hopefully with the Democrats support, in an equally trenchant manner because this applies in section 67 only to the time for which a licence is granted. If it is done without the written consent of each carrier it means that an agreement can be entered into to give someone a licence for 10 years, and then at the whim of a Minister it can be changed from 10 years to six months, or one week. For that reason, I hope that such an amendment will be totally insupportable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would assume good faith on the part of a Minister, and to the extent that that is lacking, it can certainly be challenged in all the tribunals and courts in the land. One would think that if ever there were litigants able to afford that, it would be carriers whose interests might be adversely affected. What we are talking about is whether the Government should be able, by entering into a long term agreement, to effectively freeze the shape of the industry for a much longer period than even the Government itself might want to do, on reflection.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, Senator Collins in a fit of gusto may believe that five years of protection is fair and reasonable. But when his successor comes along he may say, `That is quite crazy. Everyone else in the industry takes a different view. So do we. Unfortunately, we are beholden to the other party to this agreement and nothing can be done'. That is a nonsense and one would have thought that we could ensure in all sorts of ways that the power is not exercised capriciously, but also, we should not become hostage to the whim of the Minister of the day determining policy for years into the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister: is it not true that, conversely, with a Minister of an incoming government-say, a coalition government-not needing the carrier's written consent, we can have de facto, post haste deregulation, which is indeed the agenda of the Opposition in proposing this amendment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only is that precisely correct, it is precisely why the Opposition wants to divide on this amendment.

—I have a question for the Minister. Is it true that if the Opposition became the Government with this clause still standing and it wanted to implement its policy, it would have to introduce legislation to amend clause 67, as it is now being proposed, so that its proposals would mean an Act of Parliament rather than allowing it to happen by ministerial decree?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. It is axiomatic that legislation that is made can be unmade. We do not support philosophically the direction from which the Opposition is transparently coming. We will be opposing the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the Government in opposing this amendment is nailing its flag to the mast of parliamentary scrutiny and the rights of Parliament rather than the Minister to determine matters of this nature. That really is a refreshing view for a government to adopt. I suppose what is also exercising the minds of the Opposition is that there may be a number of situations arising in the telecommunications networks and systems which have been developed by a carrier which might raise widespread concern among the community so that a Minister of the day is lobbied and urged by constituents and by the parties to do something about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the answer to that would be to make sure that the penalties that applied to carriers were sufficient to bring them into line. As we are going through this Bill I will be having a look at the question of penalties and whether they are sufficient to require the carriers to be brought into line. At this juncture I am happy to support the principle that the Parliament itself should have responsibility in matters of this nature. I will be supporting the clause as it stands.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Sitting suspended from 6.33 to 8 p.m.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 68 agreed to.
Clause 69.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 14. Clause 69, page 30, lines 27 and 28, omit all words from ``Minister'' to ``proposes'' substitute the following:
Reports by AUSTEL on proposed instruments about licence conditions
``69(1) Where the Minister proposes:
(a) to make an instrument under subsection 71(3); or
(b) to make under section 64 or 65 an instrument that would have the effect of varying or removing a prescribed carrier obligation of a carrier;

the Minister must by writing request AUSTEL to give a written report about the question whether, having regard to such matters (if any) as are specified in the request, it is in the public interest to make the proposed instrument.
``(1A) Subject to subsection (1), where the Minister proposes:''.

In speaking to the amendment, I need to make a few comments on the proposed Opposition amendment No. 10 which would go through if our amendment were not agreed to. Our amendment requires only that the Minister must seek a report from Austel where an instrument involves changing a prescribed carrier obligation. We support the intention of the Opposition's amendment in requiring Austel to make a report in the public interest in all licence conditions, but the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills assures us that the headline does not count as part of the legislation and changing the headline will have very little effect.

While we think it is necessary that Austel prepare a report, we do not think it is necessary that it do so on each and every licence condition, because many of these licence conditions are quite technical. If Austel were forced to investigate each and every licence condition, I believe there is a danger that it would become overloaded with technical conditions and other important areas, such as the prescribed carrier obligations, may not be investigated as thoroughly as we would like. We need to look at what is to happen with these prescribed carrier obligations-and I have made this point before-because, with deregulation, there is the very real danger that the least profitable segments will be neglected in the pursuit of competition for competition's sake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kernot has made the points that I would have made. The Government will be supporting the Australian Democrats' amendment. I have a note similar to the one on Senator Kernot's amendment schedule that the Opposition may not be pursuing its amendment if the Democrat amendment is supported. However, if it does pursue the amendment, we will be opposing it and supporting the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston, will you be proceeding with the Opposition's amendment?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Alston

TALK.START.PARA: —No, Mr Chairman.

INTERJECT.PARA: Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 70.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 11. Clause 70, page 31, subclause (3), lines 23 to 27, omit the subclause.
12. Clause 70, pages 31 and 32, subclause (7), line 39 (page 31) to line 5 (page 32), omit the subclause.

This is the infamous provision that empowers the Minister to make a written agreement with a carrier about the exercise of his power which provides that the Commonwealth can pay a specified amount to a carrier if it contravenes the agreement. The vice of this arrangement is that the government can effectively raise the stakes against an incoming government to the point where huge amounts of money could be required to be paid which have no connection with the damage that might have flowed from any change to the rules.
We therefore take the view that this is an offensive clause. I refer by way of example to subclause 7, which provides:
Where an agreement in force under this section provides as mentioned in subsection (3):
(a) an amount may become payable under the provision whether or not the amount represents a reasonable estimate of the loss or damage that the carrier is likely to suffer . . .

That is what the law always regards as a penalty, which is not in any form an attempt to provide liquidated damages or make any sensible assessment of the loss, but simply to preclude any attempt at alteration. Therefore, we take the view that this is an offensive provision; it could allow for penalties about which no-one would know until they were sprung on a government that sought to vary the arrangements. There is no requirement for the agreement to be made public and we therefore vigorously oppose the subclause.
Amendment No. 12 would delete subclause 7; if that were the case, then people would at least know where they stood and would not be faced with this in terrorem arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats see these amendments as just two more attempts to break the duopoly. Consistent with the reasons I have given previously, we prefer the duopoly as the fall back position which we are prepared to accept. We do not think it is right that, if the Liberal Party in government wanted to break the duopoly agreement with the carrier, it would have to pay enormous sums of compensation to the carrier. We are not prepared to assist the Opposition in that respect.

—By way of clarification, I want to say for the benefit of Senator Kernot that this is precisely the point; the provision is not providing for compensation. Compensation is an assessment of the damage that flows from a breach. That is not what subclause 7 does; subclause 7 says that we can provide that in the event of any breach a carrier gets $50m, and gets that even if it has not suffered at all. In many respects it would be very difficult for either of the two carriers to demonstrate loss. We may well find, for example, that the market, if it were opened up, would expand quite significantly, and no carrier would suffer financially. But we would be giving a huge windfall gain which would be totally unrelated to any loss that a carrier might have suffered and therefore would be unrelated to any compensation it might deserve. That is the real vice of subclause 7. I invite Senator Kernot to re-read it and comment on it if she will. I understand that she will not support it, but she should at least acknowledge that it is as I have described.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Proposed amendment No. 12 is in line with earlier amendments the Opposition has wanted to move because of the philosophical direction it is coming from, which is not that of the Government. That is, the Opposition wants to open up the market to a much wider degree than the Government wants. It is as transparent as with the original amendments that were moved and I would think that the Opposition would not want it to be seen in any other way. For that reason, the Government will be opposing the amendment.

—I invite the Minister to explain why subclause 7 is couched in such draconian terms. Why does the Government simply not take the view that, in the event of breach, one ought to be entitled to reasonable compensation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite simply, the explanation is that it would be extremely difficult for the Government to proceed with its proposals-that is, to sell Aussat Pty Ltd and form this new arrangement. It would be very difficult to conclude that arrangement unless the buyer was able to gain some certainty about compensation by the Commonwealth if the competitive environment that that buyer was coming into was then changed. If that process is delayed, I would have thought, inasmuch as the Opposition does not like what is happening and wants to go further, that it would also delay the advent of competition in the industry.

—I will make the point plain: I can understand the proposition that, in the event of a premature termination of the agreement or a breach of contract, one is entitled to damages-that is not a terribly exceptional proposition-but that is not what this subclause provides. I am interested to know on what basis the Government would proceed. If there is a provision that says that the Government can provide for an amount to be payable irrespective of any loss or damage, how does it determine the quantum of that amount? Does it simply make it so large that it will terrorise someone out of seeking to breach it? In that case, it is a penalty.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not argue that it will be an easy matter to resolve-it will be a difficult matter to resolve-but it is one that does have to be resolved by negotiation between the Government and that second carrier. It is a matter that the Government, for reasons that the Australian Democrats support, wants to retain in its hands rather than leave to the uncertainty of a situation where the carrier would have absolutely no idea what the end result at the end of the day might be. That will make this process much more difficult for the Government to then implement.

—No other litigants are entitled to know in advance how much they might be able to get from the other parties simply by demonstrating a breach. Every other litigant in the land has to show that he or she has suffered loss or damage. That is not what subclause 7 provides. It entitles the Government to nominate any figure it likes, which becomes payable upon breach, irrespective of whether there is any loss or damage. I therefore ask the Minister: on what basis does the Government set that sum? Does it set it so high that it dissuades anyone from attempting to change it? Is that the rationale? If not, what is the underlying principle? It clearly is not compensation, so let us put that to one side; it is a penalty. I want to know how the Government determines the basis of that penalty.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston may well disagree with the explanation given, but I have given that explanation. That is a matter that will be negotiated and deliberately made to be negotiated between the Government and the second carrier.

—I am not satisfied. When the Minister says that the matter will be `negotiated', does he mean that, whatever amount the carrier decides is a sum that it would like to get in the event of a breach, that amount will be regarded as payable by the Government or is there some element of reasonableness that will be the basis of the negotiation? If so, how does the Government quantify that reasonableness? On the face of it, that enables the Government to put in any amount it likes.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, as I said before, that will be a matter for negotiation, but it will be subject to the scrutiny of this Parliament. We will be moving amendment No. 15 to clause 70 to require a copy of that agreement to be laid before the Parliament within 15 sitting days after the agreement is made. So it will be subject to the scrutiny of this House.

—I am grateful to the Minister for explaining what will happen after the event, but I want to know how he will determine the amount before the event. I say again, at the risk of being tedious, that subclause 7 does not provide for any form of compensation. It is quite unrelated to any loss or damage that might flow from a breach. It simply says that the Government can agree to pay an amount of money.
—Yes, a penalty.

—That is right. I want to know how that figure is set. Does the Government just put in $100m and say that that should be enough to frighten them off; does it in some way try to relate it to what might be a ballpark estimate of the maximum amount of damage that might flow; or does it just pluck a figure out of the air?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The figure will not be plucked out of the air. Unsatisfactory as Senator Alston may find it, I have explained it three times and I will explain it a fourth time. It will not be plucked out of the air; it will be negotiated between the parties. That provision appears, as Senator Alston says quite correctly, in subclause 3. If Senator Alston wants to describe it as a penalty, as I have done, for a change by the Government in the circumstances under which this is done, then I guess he can describe it as that.

SPEECH.PARA: However, if Senator Alston thinks this is an unusual provision in relation to a breach of agreement, it is not nearly as unusual as one I witnessed, which was unparalleled to the best of my knowledge. His conservative colleagues in the Northern Territory Parliament introduced an Act for compulsory acquisition, and not for a public purpose, to take $50m of privately owned property from one company and give it to another private company the Government elected to favour. There was no question of compensation, penalty payments or anything else being involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is uncon- stitutional.

—It was never tested because the company was so disgusted with the Government's actions that it pulled up stakes and left the Territory-I must say to the Territory's great detriment. I could not find any parallel for that legislation. But in this legislation we are imposing upon ourselves a commitment to provide for this to be done. If the competitive environment is changed, then that will be done by agreement between the Government and any potential second carrier.

—What the Minister is saying is that if the second carrier says `I am not going to apply for a licence unless you give me $50m in the event of a breach', that is how it will be negotiated. It will be a figure sufficient to induce the carrier to sign up. There are no other principles involved, are there?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not have words put into my mouth by Senator Alston. I say again that that is a matter that will be negotiated by the Government, with all its complexities. It is not quite as simple as Senator Alston would like to portray it. It is quite clearly laid out in this Bill. He may object to it, and I understand his philosophical objection very clearly, but it is quite clear from the legislation what is involved. He may object to it, but it is a matter to be negotiated between the Government and that second carrier. As I say, I understand the philosophical objection Senator Alston might have. He may fear, as he has already said, that the amount of money negotiated might be sufficient to dissuade further competition. I think that is how he put it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (15) Clause 70, page 32, at end of clause, add the following subclause:

``(8) The Minister must cause a copy of each agreement under subsection (1) or (4) to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the agreement is made, but failure to do so does not affect the validity of an agreement.''.

Clause 70 of the Bill enables the Minister to make an agreement-which we have just discussed-with a licence holder about the exercise of the powers to grant licences and the powers in relation to licence conditions. This provision is included to give some certainty to a carrier about the extent of competition, the obligations imposed on it, and in what circumstances the Government can change those obligations or the competitive environment for that second carrier. This amendment will ensure that the Parliament remains informed of any such agreement that is entered into by requiring the agreement to be tabled in each House of the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to be quite clear, what will be publicly known within 15 sitting days is the amount of the penalty inter alia; is that right?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is yes.

—The Democrats do not like the weasel sort of secondary clause at the end of this. I believe it indicates the purpose of the first part of it. I prefer the Liberal amendment which comes after this. We are talking about something that involves millions and millions of dollars and, although the Minister might have to cause a copy of each agreement to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days, the Liberal amendment forces the Minister to table the private agreement in parliament, and we think that is better. This is consistent with our emphasis throughout this debate on transparency in parliamentary scrutiny.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Frankly, I cannot understand what advantage is perceived. We are not going to die in a ditch on this, but from the Democrats' perspective I cannot understand what advantage they think there is in agreeing to the Liberal amendment, which talks about the form of the agreement being tabled, rather than the far more substantive Government amendment, which requires the actual agreement to be tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I cannot understand it is that we will not understand-we will not know-what the form of the agreement will be until we enter into negotiations with the second carrier. What the Government has said is a far more comprehensive solution for the Democrats and everyone else. We will not know what the agreement is-because one currently does not exist-until we enter into those negotiations with the second carrier and at the same time we will know the form of the agreement. We will at the end of the negotiation have the actual agreement. Rather than table the form of the agreement, which is all the Liberal amendment requires, under our amendment we are prepared to table the agreement itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our amendment requires the tabling in advance of a draft agreement. The Government amendment requires the tabling of the actual agreement after the event and we would therefore support the Government and pursue our own amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of further explanation, this is not a pro forma document that is going to be churned out by the Government Printer. At the time we know the form of the agreement, there will only be one second carrier. We will actually know the agreement. I am not quite sure what having the form of the agreement-that is, a form which in itself is meaningless-tabled in the Parliament will add but we can do it. That is why I say that I am not going to die in a ditch on it. We can certainly table a form in the Parliament. I thought the actual agreement itself would have been more useful.
—Could the Minister comment on the last part, that the tabling does not affect the validity of the agreement? I am more concerned about that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason is that the Government has agreed that the agreement itself will be the matter for debate. So, the validity of that agreement, whether it is good or bad, will be subject to public scrutiny. We have agreed to that. The Government will stand or fall, it will be condemned or supported in the electorate, depending upon the electorate's perceptions of the results of that debate. But it cannot affect the validity of an agreement. I am not prepared to go that far, because it will simply make the negotiation of that agreement an almost impossible procedure. It will make it very difficult for the Government to accomplish what it has set out to do in terms of its policy directions.

SPEECH.PARA: We have made a concession on this, as a result of negotiations that we have had with the Democrats. We are prepared to table the agreement openly in parliament and then to have it open to parliamentary debate. It will be a matter for the good judgment of people who see it subjected to that scrutiny and no doubt to criticism from the Democrats and the Opposition as to whether the Government has acted wisely on their behalf in the matter. We certainly cannot allow the validity of the agreement to be exorcised. Otherwise, it will make it impossible to properly and expeditiously enter into it.

We are not going to die in a ditch on the Opposition's amendment about tabling the form of the agreement. All I am saying is that this is not a pro forma agreement. The form of the agreement will not be known until we actually enter into negotiations with the prospective second carrier.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Proposed clause 70a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move the following amendment:

SPEECH.PARA: 13. After clause 70, page 32, insert the following clause:
Form of agreement to be tabled

``70a. As soon as practicable after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, the Minister shall cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament a copy of a form of agreement with carriers about licences.''.

As I have indicated, the Opposition amendment requires that a copy of the form of the agreement with the carriers be tabled so that we are able to make some sensible judgments in advance about just what it is that the Government is proposing to give away. We are not asking it to disclose every last dollar-and no doubt we will not get numbers given to us. But we ought at least be able to know the parameters of the agreements so that we can publicly judge whether or not the Government is going down the right track. That is why I have moved the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing the amendment principally for the reason I stated before-that is, that we want this matter to be dealt with expeditiously. The Government wants it to proceed. One of the concerns that we have in accepting the Liberal amendment-and we are not opposed to it in principle-is that, if it is accepted, it could mean that the whole Bill would have to be renumbered and recross-referenced. This could take a considerable amount of time and we may well miss the 1 July date for royal assent on this legislation. It is for that reason and that reason only that we oppose it.

—I understand that the Government wants this to proceed, but we are talking about an important principle here which I referred to earlier. We are talking about transparency and we are talking about multi-million dollars. I am of the view that the Parliament has a perfect right to scrutinise decisions of this magnitude. We will be supporting the Opposition's amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, can I throw myself on the mercy of the Opposition? I think that we will get it accepted. Senator Alston should just ask his adviser; he will give him the nod on this. All we are asking-and I must say, with the helpful advice of the Clerk-is that, to avoid that difficulty, the Opposition be prepared to accept what would in fact be a drafting amendment and have this included as a new subclause rather than a new clause, which means that we will not have to renumber and cross-reference the whole Bill. Hansard cannot hear that nod!
—Senator Alston, I have to find out whether you are willing to move it in that form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.
