TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, it does not make any substantive difference; it is simply a matter of form.
—It just saves us renumbering the Bill.
—In that case, I seek leave to withdraw my previous amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: 13. After clause 70, page 32, after subclause (7), add the following subclause:

``7a. As soon as practicable after the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent, the Minister shall cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament a copy of a form of agreement with carriers about licences.''.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Clause 71.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (16) Clause 71, page 32, at end of clause, add the following subclause:
``(5) An instrument under subsection (3) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.''.

Clause 71 of the Bill enables a licence to declare that a condition of the licence is a prescribed carrier obligation. This amendment would make an instrument inserting, varying or omitting a prescribed carrier obligation a disallowable instrument. This amendment is consequential to the amendment to clause 66 that has already been moved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats welcome this amendment and believe that there is an important principle being established here. We will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 72 to 115-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter in relation to clause 79. This is one of a number of discretions. Clause 79 relates to Austel's power to give directions concerning compliance with the code of practice. It is the contention of the Law Council that there ought in principle to be a right of review, an access to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. I therefore ask the Government why it has not been prepared to give that right of access in relation to this clause and I might say, for convenience, all the other clauses contained on page 3 of the Government's letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Beazley has in fact responded in writing on this matter to Mr Smith, Senator Alston's adviser. I quote from that letter:

SPEECH.PARA: It would not be appropriate to have such decisions taken by a specially constituted expert administrative body-Austel-and then subjected to a review by a generalist administrative body-the AAT . . .
I must say that makes an enormous amount of sense to me. The letter goes on:

Judicial review of these decisions is not in any way limited. Full judicial review is available in the Federal Court of Australia under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act and this protects all parties' legal rights in the appropriate forum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Minister for reading the contents of a letter which has only recently been handed to us. Nonetheless, I think it should go some way towards meeting these concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: I should pursue another matter in relation to clause 115. It is a matter of reasonable concern. I cannot tell on the run whether the Mr Beazley's letter has adequately dealt with the proposition. Clause 115 provides for an application to be made to Austel for reconsideration of a decision. The application must be made within 21 days after the applicant is informed of the decision concerned. The concern of the Law Council of Australia was that we might have a situation where reasons for the decision only became available at a much later point.

Without having the Council's correspondence in front of me, I cannot recall its solution to the problem. My solution would have been to amend subclause 115(2) so as to give the right to make such an application for reconsideration within 21 days of having received the statement of reasons, which would accord with the normal practice, and would enable an applicant to make a sensible judgment about whether to take the matter any further and not to appeal in the dark and then find subsequently that the matter was not one that should have been proceeded with. I ask the Minister why we cannot proceed in that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter is covered in Mr Beazley's response to Mr Smith. I thank the Minister for his discretion. This is a draft letter. We contacted the Minister tonight. He is currently in the air; he is not yet in Canberra. He approved providing it to the Opposition immediately after the dinner break before he signs it, which he will do tomorrow. I simply make that point to acknowledge the fact that Senator Alston has not had time to read the letter. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Warwick,
Reconsideration of Austel by its own decisions.

The decisions enumerated by the Law Council are also major in that they will be taken by all members of Austel corporately in the first instance. Little would be achieved by having these decisions subject to reconsideration by the same people. This contrasts with other decisions which may be taken by individual members of Austel or by delegated Austel staff on its behalf.

The Law Council complains of time limits. If an applicant seeks review of an Austel decision within the time allowed and has not received a statement of reasons Austel would, of course, not proceed further until it had supplied a statement of reasons and given an applicant an opportunity to consider these reasons. In two years of operation no criticism has been made of Austel's procedures in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am content with that assurance, although I would have contended that it ought to be in the legislation. I suspect that, in effect, the Minister is acknowledging the validity of the concerns and giving an undertaking. On that basis, we are content.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 116.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 15. Clause 116, page 51, after subclause (4), add the following subclause:

``(5) Nothing in this section affects the liability of a carrier to comply with a law of the Commonwealth, a State or Territory relating to planning or concerning the protection of the environment, including the natural environment, the cultural heritage and Aboriginal laws.''.

Clause 116 exempts, by way of regulation, carriers from State and Territory laws. The exemptions are drawn very broadly. The regulations may provide that specified carriers may engage in specified exempt activities despite specified laws of a State or Territory or despite any law of a State or Territory. The Australian Democrats are concerned that in the area of environmental protection, environment law, zoning, planning laws and so on those sorts of blanket exemptions simply should not obtain.

In addition to that wide ranging exemption, the Democrats are attempting with this amendment to claw back, as it were, the provisions which cover the environment, including the natural environment, cultural heritage and Aboriginal law. While the Democrats are concerned in the general sense that the Federal Government should not attempt to exempt itself from the laws which it imposes on all other citizens-and we state that as a general principle-we find it particularly repugnant that in the area of environmental protection law the Government is seeking to impose laws on all other people, and the States do likewise, while specifically exempting the provision of those laws with respect to the Commonwealth.

As it were, this amendment is a second best amendment that accepts the basic premise of clause 116-namely, that the Minister should be able to make certain carrier activities exempt from State and Territory laws. However, the Democrats accept that premise with reluctance. The sole purpose of this exemption clause is to fast track the development of the second carrier's network. Removing this clause completely would slow that process down, but that does not seem to the Democrats to be a very great tragedy.

Therefore, accepting the premise of the law, the Democrats believe that in this day and age-particularly with widespread community concern about the environment-it should not be possible for environmental, cultural heritage and Aboriginal laws to be overridden under any circumstances. This amendment would ensure that such laws continue to apply to exempt activities.

In further support of this amendment, in my experience of many decades of work with the environment movement and also with a prominent planning body in South Australia from 1963 onwards, I have become aware of many instances where Federal and State bodies enjoying some exemptions were extremely arrogant in the way in which they dealt with the environment and created enormous problems which were not appealable by ordinary citizens living in an area; indeed I became quite convinced that governments should not use these blanket exemption provisions.

To sum up, the amendment moved by the Democrats accepts reluctantly the general and wide ranging exemption of clause 116, which claws back the proposed sections dealing with the protection of the natural environment, cultural heritage and Aboriginal laws.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has canvassed this matter at some length in previous debate. I will go over it again. The Government will oppose this amendment. Apart from the tiny area of Telecom Australia's activities that involves Commonwealth property, Telecom is currently exempt from any requirements to comply with State or local government law in respect of its network. For the first time the Commonwealth is imposing upon the carriers obligations to comply with a strict national environmental code. Were this amendment to be carried, it would mean that notwithstanding the fact that a national code is to be negotiated between the Federal Government and each State and Territory government to impose these obligations on the carriers for the first time, those negotiations and that code of conduct will be totally negated. The carriers would still be subject to State and Territory planning and environmental law, and that would obviate the entire purpose of having a specific national code of practice specific to this industry to protect the environment.

SPEECH.PARA: In my briefing notes I am informed that this could mean that the Australian Capital Territory Government could pass a planning or environmental law requiring the dismantling of the Telecom tower on Black Mountain and the carrier would then have to comply. The Parliament can be assured that the national code will embody the most stringent environmental safeguards and that it will ensure that the telecommunications carriers are subject to uniform environmental requirements throughout Australia. I repeat: if this amendment were carried it would completely obviate the purpose of having a uniform national code of environmental protection specific to this industry across Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point the Minister has made in relation to Telecom already being exempted is precisely the point I was making. There have been numerous instances in which that exemption has caused great anguish in the community. I am interested that the Minister himself mentioned the Black Mountain tower. He will recall the incredible turmoil that went on in the Australian Capital Territory over whether that tower should or should not be built on Black Mountain. Quite clearly, the Minister is anticipating a situation where those sorts of decisions will be imposed on the public again and again, without the public necessarily being able to object or to use the normal environmental protection laws.

SPEECH.PARA: Given also that we are moving into an area where the Minister himself has said the technology is changing very rapidly-I may be misquoting him but I think he presaged a day not too far hence where we may move away from telephones connected by wires to essentially universal cellular telephones, with towers scattered all over the place-it is a problem one can see multiplying. The lack of a requirement on the part of Telecom to conform at the moment with safe laws simply confirms in my mind the necessity for bringing these carriers within the ambit of environmental protection laws.

Secondly, if the Minister is saying that the code of conduct-which, I remind the Committee, we have not yet seen-is going to be more stringent than those laws that are already in place, then I cannot see that any harm is done. If the laws are going to be better environmental protection laws, then this fallback position we are attempting to put in here by way of amendment is simply a sort of bottom line protection that allows the code of conduct to achieve better environmental protection. For each of those reasons, I would urge the Committee to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand why Senator Coulter, with his long record of being a strong environmentalist, would propose such an amendment. However, if this amendment is carried the concept of having a national telecommunications system in Australia is going to go out the window. We are not just talking in this amendment about the environment; it also includes cultural heritage and Aboriginal laws. What Senator Coulter is outlining is that in each of the States and Territories anybody who puts a piece of legislation through and defines it as natural environment, cultural heritage or Aboriginal law can use that as a basis to argue against the implementation of a national telecommunications system.

SPEECH.PARA: In Australia in the 1990s we should be moving towards uniform arrangements and uniform laws that are effective across all States and Territories. The Minister has very clearly outlined that a national code will be established that will be negotiated with the States. It will be a national set of standards that everybody understands and can work with. What the Democrats are proposing is, in effect, eight different standards of legislation that can be used, in my view, to hamstring the introduction of a telecommunications system that is efficient and effective.

I cannot think of anything worse for the delivery to the community, wherever it may be, of a decent telecommunications system-in one State we are arguing over one piece of legislation that can impose one set of standards and in another State or Territory we are arguing over a different set of standards. I can see that this clause would be a lawyer's dream in any State, with lawyers finding which part of an Act they could get hold of to stop the implementation of the telecommunications system. I think in the end the Australian public will go berserk with rage when they find they are not able to have delivered to them an efficient, effective telecommunications system because some people use a device of State and Territory legislation that is variable at best and chaotic at worst to stop that implementation.

I urge the Democrats to reconsider. If they do not reconsider I urge the Senate to reject this amendment and leave it that. If we want an efficient and effective telecommunications system, we will have a national environmental code which will be negotiated and which will set a standard for all Australia. I think in the 1990s we should be thinking of Australia as a whole, rather than as six States and two Territories, which would ensure that we did not get a decent national telecommunications system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised to hear what Senator Schacht has just said because he is really arguing for one set of standards for Telecom Australia and the private competitor. I simply pose the question: will we have separate standards for every industry in this country? We have a law which might cover the Commonwealth or we have a law which might cover a State and it applies to every industry in that whole area; it applies uniformly. I agree with Senator Schacht that it is a great pity that we do not have uniform environmental protection laws for the whole of Australia, but we do at least have laws which apply uniformly across all industries. In many instances they provide mechanisms for public input and they have mechanisms for scrutiny of decisions, such as the decision to build a tower on Black Mountain.

SPEECH.PARA: It is appropriate that each one of the government bodies which seeks to do things in the environment should be bound by exactly the same laws that this Parliament has seen fit to impose on every other person and corporation that seeks to do things in the environment. I fail to see any reason why the Government should simply exempt itself and set up a special and unique set of circumstances for one particular industry or technology in the community. I wonder what will happen if this pattern proliferates and we have different codes of practice for every industry that the Government gets its hands on. It really will be a dog's breakfast then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will respond again briefly as to why the Government is fundamentally opposed to this amendment. It goes much further than Senator Coulter is suggesting. The amendment talks about planning laws as well as environmental laws being applied. I reiterate the point I made in terms of Telecom Australia being exempted or some special condition being set up. The fact is that Telecom, the existing carrier, has established a network in Australia that is currently connected to 96 per cent of all Australian households. It has done that with total immunity from any planning or environmental requirements except for that tiny part of its activities which involves Commonwealth land. That is precisely the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The second carrier has to be expected to set up a network in competition with Telecom under a set of conditions that never applied to Telecom-that is, to be subject to State and Territory planning and environmental conditions. As I said before, at the time that the Telecom Tower on Black Mountain was erected, had I been a resident of the Australian Capital Territory and had I been here prior to its erection I may well have opposed it, not on the grounds of its aesthetic detriment but on the grounds of the absolutely blatantly rampant sexist, phallic symbolism of it-being the great feminist supporter that I am.

But the fact is that the example I gave was not a specious example. Again, without going into the merits of the case, we have had an ACT Government that determined to turn off the fluoride supply to the ACT water system. If this amendment is carried, there would be nothing to stop it-I agree with Senator Schacht that a nice old legal battle would ensue-passing legislation putting planning and environmental restrictions on Black Mountain that would require the dismantling of that Telecom facility. This is a very broad reaching amendment, indeed, covering a mass of unspecified planning and environmental legislation and providing, as Senator Schacht has said, for a whole range of different conditions to apply to the new carrier that never applied to Telecom in establishing a network that already reaches 96 per cent of Australian households.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand what the Minister is saying about the need for some equality in respect of the new carrier. Nevertheless, Senator Coulter has a point, and that is that various States and Territories have various environmental planning laws. This provision really will not necessarily take cognisance of what the carriers can do. In any event, when the instrument is made, it will be only a disallowable instrument. It will not come before this chamber, as has been the case with some other measures in respect of which amendments can be made in the same way as legislation is made. I think that is important. Here we have a situation where various State laws could be overruled by the new carrier and by the Government- at least by the Minister-in determining a national code and those State governments and those State parliaments will have no say in the matter at all.
—Or the public.

—And neither will the public. But I am just talking about the State parliaments. We in the Senate are supposed to be a States House. The provision contained in clause 117(4) is such that it is only a disallowable instrument. We really do not have the opportunity of expressing either what the public might say or what the various States may say in the sense of being able to amend adequately the national code.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe-although I have not focused on it as well as I might have-that the national code should be presented in a form which enables this Parliament, on behalf of the States, if one likes, to amend it as one would be able to amend a Bill. As honourable senators around the chamber know, the code could be presented to us in the form of `cop the lot or cop nothing'. Some of the measures that come to us as disallowable instruments are in that form.

Later on this week I hope to give notice of and present a Bill to the Parliament which will enable delegated legislation to be amended in accordance with what has been said over a number of years by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and, indeed, by Senator Collins. I think Senator Collins gets a mention in my second reading speech. But my Bill, which I think has a fair bit of support around the chamber, may not have passed the Senate or the other House by the time this national code is established.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond by saying that clause 117 of the Bill involves the scrutiny of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which I chaired. The national code is, under clause 117 of this Bill, a disallowable instrument.

—I understand what Senator Collins says. In fact, that is what I said, too-it is a disallowable instrument, but it is not an amendable instrument unless it comes to us in a manner where it has discrete provisions which, under the current powers of the chambers to disallow, we can then amend. I hope the national code at least will come to us in such a form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure it will be in reasonably good shape by the time it arrives here, because we intend to move amendment No. 18 to provide for the national code to be published as a draft and to involve the public in direct comment on the draft. In response to one thing that Senator Harradine said about the Senate-the States House-being able to deal with it on behalf of our colleagues in the State and Territory parliaments, I have to say with perhaps some regret that it has been a long time since the Senate has been a States House. I know that Senator Harradine is more aware of that than anyone in this chamber--
—We have had a few tribal wars.

—Indeed. I can say, being very specific, that I think my Territory colleagues in the Country-Liberal Party Government in the Northern Territory would be horrified to think that either Senator Tambling or I would negotiate on their behalf in a Senate debate on something that they would consider they were perfectly capable of debating themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (14). Clause 116, page 51, paragraph 1(b), line 10, omit the paragraph.

This amendment seeks to delete what is otherwise an open-ended provision in the clause. It is one which I have great difficulty in comprehending if it remains in. It seems to me to render paragraph 1(a) quite superfluous. If one is simply able to provide that specified carriers can engage in specified exempt activities despite any law of a State or Territory, why would one need to have something that also says `despite specified laws'? To the extent that there is a choice, we would much prefer (a) because we think the regulations ought to identify those particular laws and regulations that might otherwise be contravened. In that way, carriers will be able to know in advance what it is they can and cannot do. But if we leave in (b) and effectively negate (a) then they are at risk and in the dark. We therefore take the view that it is much more desirable to narrow the field and specify in advance, so that the carriers know where they stand.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will support this amendment. As I indicated earlier, we were really putting our second best option. This is the third best option and it is better than nothing. I agree entirely with the words just expressing the view that (b) is incredibly wide-one could just pass a regulation and simply wipe the slate clean with regard to any State or Territory laws. At least in deleting (b) one would have to specify each and every law in the State or Territory, and that would make the situation much clearer. Also, hopefully, the Government will reconsider leaving in place many laws which have been passed for very good reasons in the area of environmental protection. Leaving (a) in place but deleting (b) will mean the Government will have to give careful consideration and presumably think of good reasons why specified laws of the State or Territory should be exempted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing this amendment. Now that the Australian Democrats have indicated their support for it, I foreshadow that to make this Bill workable we will need to move some additional amendments, which to this time have not been circulated because we were not certain of the outcome of this debate. I understand that they are being circulated now. We will be opposing this amendment because it will prevent regulations providing that carriers may engage in specified activities relating to the establishment of a new network despite any law of a State or Territory. The power to make such regulations is included to enable activities that are essential to the effective operation of telecommunications networks to be able to proceed. The great even playing field that we hear so much about is difficult to achieve. I think it is a nonsense to even propose such an expression, but we are trying to even it up as best we can.
—Why do you put (a) in at all?

—It is a reserve power. I do not disagree with anything that Senator Alston has said in his contribution. He is precisely right; I agree with his interpretation of why it is there. He did not use the expression `reserve power', but I am quite happy to do so; that is why it is there. It was unlikely to be exercised in practice, as it is intended by the Government, to specify, under paragraph 116(1) (a):

SPEECH.PARA: Specified classes of laws which do not apply.

Of course, such regulations would be disallowable, which will ensure that the Parliament can be satisfied that there were necessary reasons to make such exemptions. In this case I think it is unlikely. Nevertheless, in any particular case, to provide for the establishment of a second network where such a requirement did occur, the Government deliberately left that reserve power in. I might say, as a territorian, although the power under the transfer of powers Act, which was enacted in this Parliament in 1977 or 1978, has never been exercised, all laws of the Northern Territory-which is effectively a self-governing Territory-are subject to the reserve power of the Commonwealth. The power has never been exercised by any Federal Government, but it was put there for the deliberate purpose of being a transitional arrangement. This was provided for exactly the same effect; that is why it is there. I am surprised that the Opposition is opposing it.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 117.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will not be proceeding with its amendment No. 15.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 16. Clause 117, page 51, subclause (1), line 22, omit ``may'', substitute ``must''.
Clause 117 deals with the national code about carrier's exempt activities. It follows closely upon clause 116. It reads:
The Minister may by writing determine a National Code that does one or more of the following . . .

It clearly leaves an unsatisfactory situation, to the extent that we could have exempted activities which should be picked up by a code, but the Minister may choose not to determine a national code. In other words, so that those activities are picked up, and so that we do see a national code, the Minister must by writing determine a national code that does one or more of the following things, et cetera.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the guidance of the Chair as to the appropriate time for me to move the amendment just circulated to this clause. As Opposition senators will see from their perusal of it, there is nothing of any particular import in this; it is simply, if you like, a drafting amendment to the Bill to accommodate the Opposition amendment which was just carried to the previous clause. As honourable senators will see, the impact of that is contained basically in amendment No. 1, subclause (2). It is simply to make the Opposition amendment, as much as we dislike it, workable.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 117, page 52, lines 1 to 8, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:

``(2) Where a regulation in force because of subsection 116(1) entitles a carrier to engage in an exempt activity despite particular laws of a State or Territory, a National Code determined under subsection (1) of this section may, in relation to that exempt activity, make provision in respect of matters in respect of which those laws make provision.''.

This amendment simply provides for the Bill to now be changed in accordance with the previous amendment which was moved by the Opposition and supported by the Democrats and carried. It simply makes that amendment workable.
Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister to Government amendment No. 18. It would seem to me that the Government's amendment No. 18 is preferable to Australian Democrat amendment No. 17. I therefore would not object if we were to resubmit Democrat amendment No. 17. It would seem to me that we should support the Government's amendment No. 18 and not Democrat amendment No. 17.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We agree with that course of action. We think it is a better proposal than Australian Democrat amendment No. 17. We would support that being recommitted so we could proceed with amendments Nos 17 and 18.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I will go back to the Australian Democrats' amendments Nos 16 and 17. I will resubmit amendment No. 16 and then resubmit amendment No. 17. I put the question that amendment No. 16 be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that amendment No. 17 be agreed to.
—We are quite happy to accept the Government's amendment. We will withdraw 17 in favour of the Government's amendment.
—We will accept that 17 was not put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Clause 117, page 52, subclause (4), line 11, omit ``this section'', substitute ``subsection (1)''.
(18) Clause 117, page 52, at end of clause, add the following subclauses:
``(5) Before determining a National Code under subsection (1), the Minister must:
(a) publish a draft of the Code and invite the public to comment on the draft; and
(b) cause a public inquiry to be held for the purposes of receiving and considering submissions about the draft.
``(6) The Minister may comply with paragraph (5)(b):
(a) by giving to AUSTEL an appropriate direction under paragraph 327(b) to hold a public inquiry under Part 14; or
(b) by arranging for a person, authority or body (other than AUSTEL) to hold a public inquiry.

``(7) Where the Minister arranges under paragraph (6)(b) for a person, authority or body to hold a public inquiry, Part 14 applies in relation to the person, authority or body, in relation to the inquiry, in the same way, as nearly as practicable, as that Part applies in relation to AUSTEL in relation to an inquiry under that Part.''.

The first amendment is minor and is consequential upon the second amendment, which ensures that the draft national code about safety, environmental and other standards that is published for public comment is not itself a disallowable instrument. The final code, determined after the public consultation, will be subject to parliamentary disallowance under subclause 117 (4).

The amendment is a redraft of the Democrats' amendment, which in the Government's view had technical deficiencies that obviously the Opposition agrees with. The amendment will require the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) to publish a draft of the code, invite public comment and cause a public inquiry to be held. The Minister can direct the public inquiry to be held by Austel or another person or body, but if it is held by someone else they must as far as practicable follow the same public inquiry procedures that Austel would be required to follow.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 118.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 118, page 52, subclause (1), lines 14 to 17, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:
``(1) This section applies where a regulation in force because of subsection 116(1) entitles a carrier to engage in an exempt activity despite particular laws of a particular State or Territory.''.
Clause 118, page 52, subclause (2), line 18, omit ``If paragraph (1)(a) applies the'', substitute ``The''.
Clause 118, page 52, subclause (3), lines 23 to 25, omit the subclause.

I move those amendments to clause 118, for the reasons I previously gave. The amendments will allow the Bill to be brought into line with the Opposition's amendment. These amendments are consequent upon the Opposition's amendment, which was adopted by the Committee, and they redraft the remaining clauses in the Bill to reflect that.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 119 and 120-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 121.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister, Mr Beazley, in his letter said that where Austel acts to limit tort liability it must specify the classes of tort action which it is limiting and the level of the limit. What is it about clause 121 that requires Austel to specify the classes of tort? It seems to me that all that Austel is required to do is determine a single amount in respect of torts in general. If that is not correct, then we ought to have it on the record that clause 121 will be used in such a way as to deal at different times with different torts and to set different amounts, because it seems on the face of it to empower the making of only one Act in relation to torts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The clause is drafted in this way-determining maximum amounts recoverable, which is not unique in legislation for damages, particularly in workers' compensation areas-because it enables Austel to determine maximum amounts recoverable in tort. The Government will oppose the amendment to this that has been circulated by the Opposition. The Government considers that it is necessary for Austel to make such determinations because of the potential for enormous and totally disproportionate damages to be levied against carriers for economic loss. In the event that a business deal, for example-and I will give an example that could well apply-was lost because of the failure of a 21c phone call, it is hardly reasonable under those circumstances to enable a carrier then to be sued for millions of dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: Austel is ideally placed to make such determinations as it combines legal expertise, technical knowledge of the industry and knowledge of the economic viability of the carrier operations. The reason for this provision is that it is a routine administrative and commonsense judgment which frankly, does not require the scrutiny of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the Minister for slavishly regurgitating the brief, but I was not even going to the amendment that is to be moved in the name of the Opposition.
—I presumed you were.
—No, I was not; I was asking a question in advance. I was not quarrelling with the proposition that one can have a ceiling, and it might be helpful if the Minister heard my objection, or my question.
—A ceiling? That is exactly what you did.
—No, it is not. That is why I say the Minister did not comprehend what I was putting. Clause 121 says:

SPEECH.PARA: AUSTEL may by writing determine the maximum amount recoverable in tort in relation to an act done . . .

That may well mean that Austel simply says on one occasion that the most that can henceforth be recovered for actions in tort is $3m. On the other hand, the Minister's letter seems to suggest that one can have a whole range of separate decisions setting different ceilings for different torts at different stages. If it is the latter, then I should like to have that on the record. It does not seem to me on the fact of it to countenance the setting of differential ceilings at different times.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me say by way of explanation-and I have the same disadvantage as Senator Alston in that I got the letter 30 seconds before he did-that the reason for my confusion--
—I don't even have it.
—We will organise that now; I am sorry.
—I am not talking about the letter that was handed over.
—We assumed that Senator Alston was. I searched through the letter and could not find the reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry. I think we might have made earlier reference to a letter to Mr Chaney. I give my apologies. Mr Chaney asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Why is AUSTEL being given a very wide power to limit tort liability?
The Minister spells that out quite satisfactorily, but he says:

The Government's approach has been to replace the carriers' hitherto total exemption from liability with an AUSTEL determined limit for specified torts. This approach leaves tort liability open ended unless AUSTEL acts. Where AUSTEL acts to limit tort liability, it must specify the classes of tort action which it is limiting, and the level of the limit.

In other words, the Minister is saying that at different times one can set different ceilings for different torts. Let us have that confirmed because it seems to me, on the face of it, that the clause is simply saying that on one occasion Austel will say, `So-and-so is the ceiling for tort actions'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do understand that now. This is the first time that I have heard mention of the Chaney letter. I just assumed that this was the letter that I have recently handed to him. I could not find the reference. Having heard the references from the letter, I understand the question that was asked.

SPEECH.PARA: Not having had the advantage of having the Chaney letter in front of me, I have to say to Senator Alston that on the face of it, from hearing what I just heard quoted from the letter, it would appear to me that Senator Alston's interpretation of the letter is correct. That is precisely the meaning it has for me, too. But I simply point out what the letter points out-that is, that we are providing a form of redress which was not formerly available at all, but putting a cap on it. We have determined that the appropriate body-and, indeed, I believe it is the appropriate body that will determine that cap-will be Austel for the reasons that I have given in response to the amendment which the Opposition has circulated relating to this same issue and which I presume it intends to move shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could seek another assurance. I would have thought that the Government did not intend that Austel would be able to set a ceiling for a particular action or a particular tort once an action at law had been commenced. If that is the case, again I think it would be useful to have that on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say philosophically to Senator Alston that I hope that would not be the case. I make no bones about saying that. Under the heading `Effect of limitation determined by Austel', proposed section 122 (1) (b) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . when the act was done, or the omission was made, a determination under section 121 was in force in relation to that basic carriage service.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that does answer my first question.
—It does. That is not the situation. I think that would satisfy Senator Alston.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not quite the point that I was raising, and I do not think it is quite the point that Senator Alston was raising earlier. I think he was raising the question of whether there would be one ceiling for all torts or whether classes of torts would be predetermined. It seems to me that it may simply swing on the word `an' in two places in the second last line on page 52, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . recoverable in tort in relation to an act done-
singular-
or an omission made . . .

This suggests, to my mind at least, that it would be one type of act or omission which would carry one type of ceiling. It is open then for different ceilings to be set for different acts and omissions. In my mind, as I understand Senator Alston, it seems to swing on two letters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, the determination will be made by way of a specific Act in relation to a specified basic carrier service and that will be laid out in the determination that will be made in writing by Austel. So that is the answer to the first part of the question; the answer to the second part of the question is contained in proposed section 121 (1) (b).
—In other words, there could be a series of determinations?
—Yes, there could be a series of determinations made for different classes of service provided for in relation to the supply of the specified basic carrier service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 16. Clause 121, page 52, at end of clause, add the following subclause:
``(2) An instrument made by AUSTEL under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46a of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.''.
This amendment simply provides for an instrument to be a disallowable instrument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say, Mr Chairman, that I am somewhat puzzled by the philosophical underpinning that promotes these amendments from the Opposition, in so far as one can pin down Opposition philosophy on any particular issue from day to day. Opposition members run something up the flagpole and see if people salute it, then if they do not, they pull the flag down again; that seems to be the order of the day from the Opposition at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Parliament is capable of doing a great many things. In my view one of the things that Parliament is not capable of doing is running a business; I make no bones about saying that.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are in favour of privatising Telecom?

—No, that is not what I am saying at all. Senator Alston knows full well what I am saying. I will be more specific: this chamber is certainly not the appropriate place to have a board. The analogy with Telecom is a greatly flawed one, and in fact it makes my case for me. The Government established Telecom as an agency, autonomous of government, that runs its own organisation. The Opposition amendments are in fact designed to do precisely the reverse, that is, to bring the running of that business into this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Considering all of the standing orders, restrictions and provisions in terms of disallowable instruments in this Parliament, I think that if one were uncharitable, one would be inclined to say that the only real philosophical bent that the Opposition would be determined to achieve in these amendments would be to make this arrangement as impossible as it can in terms of its actually working. As Senator Schacht would realise, it would protect the interests of the legal profession by moving to disallow regulations where the tariff was not, in the view of the lawyers in the Opposition, sufficiently high enough to attract the high fliers in the legal profession such as Senator Alston and his colleagues.

It is very difficult to find any other philosophical base for the amendment. We believe that it is entirely inappropriate. We have set up Austel, with that combination of legal expertise, industry knowledge and sound commonsense, deliberately for the purpose of making determinations such as this. We think that it is sensible to have it done that way. I stress again that it provides a form of redress that was not formerly available at all. We think that Austel is the sensible choice and the appropriate body to set a cap, not the Senate chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister made those comments about other amendments that we moved earlier on, saying that we were trying to give the Senate the right to run the business of telecommunications in this country. But here we are talking about liability for ordinary people. Ordinary people will suffer because of the negligence of the carriers. I am not entirely convinced that Austel is the best body to--
—Do you know who the biggest users of these services are? They are not ordinary people, Senator. They won't be the ones suing with the fleet of lawyers either.

—Somebody still has to consider the rights of ordinary people in this debate. When we were talking about compensation in the previous amendment we were really talking about big business and big government. I think this time we are talking about ordinary people. It is consistent for us to say that making this a disallowable instrument is in line with some of the amendments we moved previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been trying, and I still will, to keep the heat out of the debate, but that statement astonishes me in its total unreality.
—Don't be intimidated.

—Ordinary citizens will not be. I feel that on this occasion that statement is so far removed from the real world that it has to be responded to. As they say, justice is open to all-like the Ritz Hotel. If one has the tariff one can walk through the door. This is so particularly in cases of tort-in other words, the good old litigation road that is not criminal law but involves suing for damages.

SPEECH.PARA: I can assure Senator Kernot that it will not be the ordinary citizen who walks into court with a fleet of silks ready to sue Telecom for damages because of the failure that occurred when the phone call dropped out between him or her and Mrs Smith across the fence. The likely result will be that corporate organisations will be using fleets of corporate lawyers in an attempt to misuse this provision which has been provided to give people redress.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an outrageous presumption.

—It is an assumption that I am prepared to make on the record. To recover damages, it will not be the ordinary citizen suing Telecom. To think for a minute that an ordinary citizen would even contemplate walking into a lawyer's office is absurd. It costs $1,000 to open the door and say `Good morning' to a lawyer. I have dealt with enough of them to know. Can honourable senators imagine too many ordinary citizens taking some action under this particular provision? I do not think so. It is the corporate sector that we think sensible caps need to be provided for and we think that Austel--
—You might get legal aid.

—Senator Panizza should not provoke me by talking about legal aid. Can honourable senators imagine Mrs Jones walking into the Australian Legal Aid Office, which is up to its ears with a bunch of the most overworked lawyers in the country who work for legal affairs services and with restricted budgets, and saying, `I want to sue Telecom for $10m because it disconnected a phone call.'? It is hardly likely. I should not even rise to that sort of stuff, and I will not. These caps are not required to limit the rights of ordinary citizens; they are required to set sensible limits on the extent to which this redress can be abused by corporations.
—Could these ordinary citizens mount a class action and circumvent some of the problems you are raising?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know how far advanced the procedures to provide for class actions are at the moment. I have some mild indirect interest in it. It is not my particular area of responsibility. Recently I heard some reports that people were moving towards a situation where class actions would be provided for in some jurisdictions. I do not know whether it has been done yet.

SPEECH.PARA: Leaving that aside-again I am just trying to relate Senator Kernot's question to the real world-I was wondering how many private citizens whose telephone lines had dropped out would form themselves into a disconnected callers association around Australia and exchange information. With respect, it is a fairly unreal possibility. I simply rest on what I said originally: the purpose of this provision is clearly and transparently designed to put a reasonable cap on this provision which provides redress for the first time ever being misused and abused by corporations.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 122 to 254-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 255.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 18. Clause 255, page 114, lines 22 to 31, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

``255. A person must not sell or supply, or offer to sell or supply, to another person customer equipment unless the person purchasing the equipment is authorised by AUSTEL to purchase customer equipment the connection of which to a telecommunications network would be contrary to section 254.

This amendment seeks to remove the onus of proof for buying and selling non-permitted equipment from ordinary consumers and sales people to the individuals who wish to buy special non-permitted equipment. I acknowledge that only a small number of people, knowing that they cannot connect non-permitted equipment to the carrier network, will knowingly buy this non-permitted equipment. Those who do will be hobbyists who want to put intercom systems into their homes and private networks. This amendment will put the onus on such hobbyists to apply to Austel for an exemption letter, which can be presented in a shop as evidence that the person buying the equipment knows it is non-permitted equipment. I have a letter from the Australian Information Industry Association Ltd (AIIA), which states:

AIIA believes there should be more stringent controls on the sale of computer equipment which does not comply with the relevant technical standards. At present, non-compliant equipment can be sold providing the purchaser is ``advised'' that the equipment does not have a permit. This provision has proved to be both unenforceable and ineffective. Non-compliant equipment is readily available on the Australian market to the detriment of those companies which, at considerable costs in both time and money, obtain the necessary technical approvals.

In other jurisdictions, the US for example, there are prohibitions on the importation and sale of non-compliant equipment. These provisions are rigorously enforced as Australian companies which have exhibited equipment at US trade fairs prior to obtaining the necessary FCC approval will readily testify.
We accept DOTAC's advice that a ban on imports of non-compliant customer equipment is not achievable-although we note that such a ban is in place for radio communications equipment.
But a prohibition on the sale and the offering for sale of customer equipment which does not have the necessary AUSTEL permit is both practical and desirable.

The AIIA claims that this view is shared by Austel and is asking that clause 255 be amended to this effect. I think that the onus being taken off the shopkeeper to inform the consumer and the onus of proof taken away from the ordinary customer who may not be able to tell the difference between the approved and the non-approved equipment is a good thing. The hobbyist or the individual who wishes to buy non-approved equipment will know what it is for and will make a deliberate and conscious decision to purchase such equipment. In the opinion of the Australian Democrats this amendment leaves less room for consumer misunderstanding. The penalty of $12,000 is fairly stiff, but I think we want to ensure that no misunderstandings ensue from this clause.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask for clarification? Did I hear Senator Kernot say that this proposed amendment of the Australian Democrats, if not precisely, was supported by Austel in the sense that it wanted change? Senator Kernot made a reference to Austel wanting an amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did. I said that in this letter to me from the Australian Information Industry Association Ltd, the Association claims:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a prohibition on the sale and the offering for sale of customer equipment which does not have the necessary AUSTEL permit is both practical and desirable. This view is shared by AUSTEL.
That is what the Association claims.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government certainly will not be supporting this amendment. I concur with every word of the formal advice I have received opposing the Democrats' amendment. I think it is a very sensible and rational statement. This advice was prepared after consultation with Austel. The advice is to the effect that the Government has already acted strongly to deter the sales of un-authorised equipment where such equipment is intended to be connected to the network.

SPEECH.PARA: A regulation has already been prepared, in consultation with Austel and industry, which will require a notice to be displayed on unauthorised customer equipment offered for sale stating that the equipment has no Austel permit and that it is an offence, carrying a $12,000 penalty, to be connected to the telecommunications network. Were the Government to adopt the proposed amendment, all people using equipment for private non-interconnected purposes in their homes or workplace would have to apply for a permit to Austel.

TALK.START.PARA: —Line up every morning.

—That is right. This would be extremely cumbersome and unnecessary. If the equipment is not interconnected it does not pose a threat to the safety of other users or to the integrity of the network itself. There are many legitimate reasons why people may wish to use such equipment. To draw an analogy-it is not my analogy but I will draw it-the law does not prevent a farmer from purchasing an unregistered vehicle for his private use within the confines of his property. I use that analogy because it will get Senator Panizza right on board. I think it is a very legitimate objection to this proposed amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has also received extensive representations from the broadcasters and computer companies claiming that their equipment, which as the Committee knows is customer equipment interconnected with the telephone network, should be exempted from the requirement for Austel approval where such equipment is located beyond a line isolating device. The Democrats, as I understand it, have indicated that they are strongly supportive of the broadcasters' desire for an exemption from Austel for their computer equipment. I do not know which of the Democrats are allegedly supporting that but I do know some computer enthusiasts among the Democrats and some fellow `Macophiles', so perhaps it is coming from them. Maybe Senator Coulter could stand up and identify himself.

The Government has agreed to give effect to exemptions for broadcasters in the computing industry through subordinate legislation. This amendment would appear to bring all such equipment back firmly under Austel regulation so that all users of broadcasting equipment and purchasers of computers would have to get an Austel permit. I am sure that this is not intended by the Democrats. The fact is that the legislation as drafted does strike an appropriate balance between hefty sanctions-I think they are hefty at $12,000-on the interconnection of unapproved customer equipment, thereby protecting the safety of the network and its users, while allowing suitable flexibility in the sale and use of equipment for private non-interconnected purposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The clincher for me was that in the letter from the Australian Information Industry Association Ltd there was not one mention of harm to the network. The furthest the letter went was to suggest that there might be some detriment to the companies involved. I have quite a deal of time for a number of the people involved in that Association, but if the Association is saying that we ought to ensure that every piece of equipment is fully authorised and approved, irrespective of the use to which it is going to be put, one would have thought that was playing the old Telecom game of trying to ensure that there are as few suppliers as possible. We would not be able to make use of the cheap imports, the Dick Smiths and all those other items that people get a lot of enjoyment out of without having them formally authorised and therefore being made more expensive in the process.

—Could the Minister repeat what he said about how the sign stating that the equipment was not standard and permissible was going to be displayed? Did the Minister say that was going to be clearly displayed on every product?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. I will repeat for Senator Kernot precisely what I said. A regulation is being prepared, in consultation with Austel and the industry, which will require a notice to be displayed on unauthorised customer equipment offered for sale stating that the equipment has no Austel permit and that it is an offence, with a $12,000 penalty, to connect it to a telecommunications network. From personal experience, and being a computer enthusiast-as I know some others in here are-I know that the more responsible retailers already tell people that. In fact, I am very pleased to say that on a number of occasions when I have purchased equipment from Dick Smith and, indeed, from Tandy, I have been actually advised that the particular equipment did not carry a specific Telecom authorisation for its use in a connected network and that I would have to use it in an internal private network which was not connected to a Telecom network. The regulation which is currently being drafted in consultation with Austel does precisely what Senator Kernot indicated that I said it did.

—I would like to ask the Minister a question. The penalty specified here is $12,000-no ifs or buts, maximum or whatever. One could imagine a situation whereby a piece of equipment could have achieved recognition and been permitted to be connected but had not yet passed that stage and somebody might have already connected it. In other words, it is a relatively trivial breach and the penalty of $12,000 under those circumstances seems to me to be an excessive one. On the other hand, someone might connect a piece of equipment and cause extensive damage and $12,000 may be a trivial penalty under those circumstances. I wonder, when a penalty is stated in such bald terms, whether the courts have any discretion in relation to the size of the fine.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —With this Act, as with all other Acts, the courts have an absolute discretion. These penalties are simply expressed as maximum penalties. The court has a total discretion, consistent with the facts before it, to impose whatever lesser penalty it thinks appropriate in the circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have found the arguments persuasive enough to induce me to withdraw that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 256 to 330-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question for the Minister in relation to clause 330. This clause makes no reference to the need to respect applicable Commonwealth, State or Territory laws in the national code before cutting down trees or clearing vegetation. What assurances can the Minister offer that these legal provisions will be observed?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, but I cannot find anything about trees in clause 330. Clause 330 concerns a public inquiry about discussion papers available for purchase. I suppose the printing of discussion papers would involve the cutting down of trees, but it is a fairly obscure connection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I have been saying is out of order. I withdraw those remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 331.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 19. Clause 331, page 145, line 13, after ``submissions'' insert ``; protection from civil actions''.
20. Clause 331, page 145, at end of clause, add the following subclause:

``(2) Civil proceedings do not lie against a person in respect of loss, damage or injury of any kind suffered by another person because of the making in good faith of a statement, or the giving in good faith of a document or information, to AUSTEL in connection with a public inquiry under this Part, whether or not the statement is made, or the document or information is given, in connection with a written submission or a public hearing.''.

Amendment No. 19 simply seeks to make the clause heading consistent with our amendment No. 20. Amendment No. 20 seeks to grant immunity from defamation in respect of submissions and complaints arising out of a public hearing held by Austel. We think that immunity against such defamation is essential. We think that, without this clause, people who make complaints in public to Austel may find themselves being sued for defamation. That is a very big disincentive to consumers and others who may wish to make a complaint. As the Minister rightly points out, litigation will be commonplace in terms of some of the clauses that we have enacted this evening. But we wish to protect consumers who complain about the service from any disincentive or punishment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We think these are terrific amendments and we will support them.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clause 332 agreed to.
Clause 333.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 21. Clause 333, page 146, after paragraph (g), add the following paragraphs:
``; or (h) a contravention of a National Code in force under section 117; or
(i) the amount of, or the manner in which telecommunications services have been charged.''.

The Australian Democrats wish to add two paragraphs to clause 333. I do not know whether the correct version has been circulated but the word `and' should really be an `or'. So the amendment should read:
``; or (h) a contravention of a National Code in force under section 117; or
(i) the amount of, or the manner in which telecommunications services have been charged.''.

Every other paragraph is connected to the next one by an `or' but unfortunately that has been changed to an `and'. Paragraph (h) of this amendment gives Austel the power to investigate a breach of the national code. The fact that it cannot do so at present is an anomaly, given the significance of the code. It is a very significant anomaly in view of the remarks that I made earlier and the Minister's response to those remarks with respect to the importance of the code of conduct.

If, indeed, the code of conduct is going to be so instrumental in the area of environmental and other protections-in other words, to substitute totally for the application of State laws which have been excluded from application-surely Austel must be given the power to proceed to investigate breaches under this national code. One would have thought, following the Minister's remarks, that he would, without hesitation, accept this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we do not think this amendment is terrific at all. We oppose both parts of it because they are inappropriate and unnecessary. Firstly, it is certainly not clear to me that Austel would have the appropriate expertise to investigate environmental matters. Frankly, I think it will be doing very well to cover the ground that it has without being invested with these responsibilities. I do not think it is appropriately equipped to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: It is envisaged that the primary responsibility for investigating a contravention of the national code, that is, to protect the environment, should properly rest with the environment portfolio, although Austel may give effect to the results of such an investigation by exercising its power to give a carrier direction under clause 119 of the Bill. I would have thought the Democrats would have wanted the primary responsibility for these environmental matters to remain within the environment portfolio, as the Government intends it will. Secondly, besides being ungrammatical, paragraph (i) of the amendment is extremely regulatory and interventionist in its intent.

The fact is that the Government has already established comprehensive price cap regulation, administered by Austel, governing the dominant carrier to ensure that consumer interests are safeguarded. The amendment goes much further than that; it allows Austel to investigate any price charged by any service provider in the private or public sector regardless of its competitive situation or market power. I think it is a very extreme form of regulation making.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister: since complaints about charging and billing will actually form the majority of complaints-and do form the majority of complaints against Telecom at present-is he indicating to us that he is satisfied that that copious number of complaints can be satisfactorily dealt with under the proposal as it now stands? Why should we not give Austel some teeth to enforce its sanctions in this really important area?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said before, if we have a look at the all embracing nature of the proposed change, we will see that it goes across the entire ambit. It is absolutely open ended-the amount or the manner in which telecommunication services have been charged. As I say again, it will apply without question to provide Austel with the obligation of investigating any price charge by any service provider in this new industry in the private or public sector, regardless of its competitive situation or its market power. It is an all embracing power for Austel to investigate anything or everything. I say again, I believe that this is regulation making gone mad.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to pursue paragraph (h), which particularly concerns me in relation to environmental protection. It seems we have a situation here in which the Government at one stroke can allow these carriers to totally ignore all State planning, environmental protection, heritage, Aboriginal protection laws, and everything else. In pushing aside all that protective legislation, the Government has said it is going to put in place a code of practice. That will substitute for that whole paraphernalia of protection which the Government has swept aside-the law as it applies to environmental protection; its protective mechanisms; its sanctions; its investigatory mechanisms, and everything else. That is what the Minister has just said.

SPEECH.PARA: We are going to have a code of practice, and yet the organisation which will be responsible for the supervision of that code of practice apparently will not be able to have the sorts of investigative powers to see whether it is being observed or not. In reply to my earlier remarks in relation to environmental protection, the Minister said that will be carried out by the environment portfolio.

Where in the legislation before us is the environment Department given the standing to carry out these investigations? Which part of this Bill slots in the environment Department and confers on it the powers which will ensure that the code of practice will be written in a certain way, will be investigated in a certain way, will be prosecuted in a certain way, and will set sanctions in a certain way-in other words, will substitute totally for all those powers which, with a sweep of one clause of this Bill, have been put in the wastepaper basket?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I advised the Committee during previous debate on this matter-and I think it does bear repeating-the code of practice, which provides for the first time a requirement on telecommunications carriers to comply with environmental law and a national code, will be drawn up by the two Ministers responsible-that is, the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly). They will together draw up that code of practice.

SPEECH.PARA: The manner in which it will be enforced is to be contained within that code. That matter has not been determined finally, and very properly should not be determined finally until that code is-and which the Government, as it has stated again and again, intends to be-a rigid and proper environmental protection in regard to telecommunications. The provisions for the enforceability of it will be contained within that code.

Although the matter has not been finally determined, I do not think it is particularly appropriate that we should finally determine it. It is highly likely, and perhaps desirable, that the enforceability provisions of breaching the environmental code more properly lie with the environment Minister and the powers that she may exercise very independently of the telecommunications area rather than Austel, which I do not think, on the face of it-and the expertise that we intend to put on it-is particularly appropriate to investigate breaches of the environmental code. It may be that when the code is drawn up it is clearly in the best interests of the environment to have that responsibility rest principally with the Minister rather than with Austel.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 334 to 338-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 339.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 22. Clause 339, page 147, subclause (3), line 42, after ``1976'', add ``or an Ombudsman appointed pursuant to paragraph 63(m)''.

I need to amend that amendment in a technical way by adding the numeral 4 to make the paragraph 63(4)(m). This amendment brings clause 339 into consistency with clause 63(4)(m), to insert a reference to the independent industry ombudsman where the Bill says that Austel may transfer complaints to the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing this amendment on the ground that it simply does not make any sense. We believe that technically it will not work. The amendment would provide that a complaint transferred to the Ombudsman is taken to be transferred to the Ombudsman. The amendment does not indicate who should actually deal with the complaint.

SPEECH.PARA: When the details of the new industry ombudsman arrangements are settled following negotiations with the carriers, amendments may at that point need to be made to the Act to implement the actual arrangements. But this amendment does not go to providing the detail as to how the complaint will actually be dealt with. We think it is far more appropriate to deal with that matter when the details of the new industry ombudsman arrangements are settled.
