TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister saying that it is not consequential at all or that he just does not like it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not consider it to be consistent. It does not indicate who should deal with the complaint. As I have said, we are working out the arrangements of the new industry ombudsman. They will be settled after negotiations with the carriers. I can certainly assure Senator Kernot that that consultation will include the Australian Democrats. At that time it may then be appropriate to introduce amendments to the Act to more specifically lay out the arrangements as they will work with complaints.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to take the Minister's explanation on board. We were advised that we would need to do that in the interests of consistency. I seek leave to withdraw that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 340 to 346-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 347.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 23. Clause 347, page 150, after paragraph (d), insert the following paragraph:
``(da) a National Code under section 117;

The mechanism by which Austel Pty Ltd will enforce the code, as I understand it, is that it must become aware of a breach. The breach in itself is not a trigger for Austel to take action other than to call on the carrier to correct the breach. Austel can then invoke sanctions when and if the breach remains uncorrected. This is a rather unusual condition in that the code of practice will become part of the law. Simply breaking the law will not bring a sanction. In other words, breaking the code of practice will not bring a sanction against the carrier.

Only when the carrier has been requested to correct the breach may a sanction be put in place. I say that by way of preamble to this amendment, which seeks to add on to the list in clause 347 a national code under section 117 and a direction under section 400. Proposed new paragraph (p) of this amendment renders the carriers liable for legal redress for breaching the national code. In other words, if the law is broken and it is broken sufficiently seriously, then it seems appropriate that the carrier should be liable to a sanction for the breaching of the code.

As the Bill now stands, such a breach does not automatically invoke its enforcement provisions. It is first necessary for Austel, having become aware of the breach, to issue a direction to comply with the code, and if the breach continues Austel can seek an injunction or a financial penalty to be imposed for contravention of its direction.

The Democrats believe that this is an unjustifiably optional and indirect provision, particularly in the history of environmental law. This shows quite clearly that an optional enforcement leads to no enforcement at all. I repeat: if environmental protection, under all the existing laws of state, is to be excluded but simply written back in by way of a code of practice, and a national carrier-and at least one of them, it is argued, will be the largest industrial activity in this country very shortly-breaches that environmental code of practice, then surely that breach in itself should call forth a sanction. It should not be necessary for Austel to go through the process of warning, seeking correction of a breach, and then being able to seek a sanction.

It again raises the question of Austel's lack of expertise to prosecute environmental breaches. Having heard what the Minister said a moment ago in relation to the use of officers in the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories who become aware of the breach and who order that the breach be corrected, will it be the Department of the environment in this case and, if so, what is the interlinking at this level between the Department and Austel? Will the Department be able to invoke the code of practice directly or will it have to go through Austel, through this rather cumbersome procedure? In moving the amendment I ask those further questions of the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some little difficulty in following the Australian Democrats' arguments on this one. The Government will be opposing the Democrats' amendment because it believes that the enforceability provisions are, quite properly and reasonably, laid out in the legislation already. The procedure Senator Coulter finds objectionable we simply find to be reasonable. We think that is the appropriate way for Austel to proceed.

SPEECH.PARA: The code of practice will be drawn up by consultation with the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and the Minister for Transport and Communications. They will draw up the policy that will constrain and bind the telecommunications people, but it will be Austel that actually carries out the enforcement of that code of practice under clause 119 and, of course, the enforceability provisions under clause 347 of the Bill.

I must say that I find it a little inconsistent of the Democrats. One minute ago they were arguing for the far more difficult job, in terms of expertise, of investigating environmental breaches. Their amendment asserted by implication that Austel did have that expertise; we did not think it did. They then say, as Senator Coulter did one minute ago, that Austel is not the appropriate organisation to enforce action on breaches of the code because, and I quote him, `they would lack expertise in prosecuting environmental breaches'. With respect, it would take considerably more expertise to investigate and establish whether there was a case for an environmental breach than it would simply to invoke the mechanism that can be readily invoked under section 347 to prosecute the breach. I do find those arguments inconsistent.

The Government is satisfied that the provisions already laid down in clause 119, which provide for Austel to give a direction to carriers as to how to comply with their obligations under this code, and the subsequent enforceability provisions contained in 347 are appropriate.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 348.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 24. Clause 348, page 151, subclause (2), line 6, omit ``or AUSTEL'', substitute ``, AUSTEL or an interested person''.
25. Clause 348, page 151, subclause (4), line 11, omit ``or AUSTEL'', substitute ``, AUSTEL or an interested person''.

In the case of the first amendment, if a person other than Austel becomes aware of a breach it would be possible for that person to apply to the Federal Court for the application of the code of practice. As this thing goes on I find that the code of practice is becoming a weaker and less readily imposed set of sanctions. At least this would allow a private citizen or any other interested party to keep an over brief of the code of practice. Similarly, in the case of the second amendment, the words `or an interested person' are inserted. These amendments allow individuals and organisations to seek injunctions or financial penalties for breaches of the national code, and this allows direct legal action to be taken in the public interest.

The law is indeed moving ever so slowly in the direction of giving public interest groups a right of standing before the courts, to appear in defence of environmental protection-in this case to defend the code of practice, whatever that may contain when we finally see it. It would also stiffen the hand of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories because we are yet to see how that Department will become involved in this code of practice and the investigation and the sanctions setting, even though finally that will be in the hands of Austel. We have the Minister's assurance that it will be, and I certainly hope that that is the case. This would at least allow the public to have an overview of that whole situation and to institute proceedings under this section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to oppose these amendments with some vigour. The whole thrust of the Telecommunications Act is to create a regulatory regime and a code of practice, the enforcement of which in the public interest would occur principally through Austel's directions and ministerial decisions. I am sure we would all hope that it would only be as a last resort that litigation would occur. Acceptance of these amendments from the Democrats, apart from anything else, would turn the Telecommunications Act into an absolute lawyer's paradise.
—Gee, that is a lot. I was going to vote against it!

—I was expecting that interjection. I expect that in the cause of good government Senator Alston will anyway. It would create a flood of vexatious litigation and it would turn this Act into a lawyer's paradise, and on those grounds the Government opposes them.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not all as sane as I know Senator Coulter to be, or as reasonable and prepared to be as positive and to make sensible suggestions. The law would apply equally to those who are not sane, sensible or reasonable. It would give them the same rights of standing as interested people, as everyone else in the community, and it would turn this into a nightmare.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have accepted without division the other defeats. We will seek to divide on this matter. It is an important principle that public interest groups which seek to protect the environment should be given standing. This is the last of the amendments in relation to environmental protection. I am disappointed that the Government has chosen to go down this particular road. I made that quite clear in my speech in the second reading debate. To take standing away from the public altogether, when courts are moving towards giving standing to members of the public, particularly conservation groups and environmental interest groups, is a retrograde step, and accordingly we will divide on this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too am interested in the need for individuals and groups to have standing. I have spoken about this on a number of occasions in various contexts and I see no reason to change my view about that particular principle in regard to these amendments, so I intend to vote for the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clause 349.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (17) Clause 349, page 151, subclause (1), line 18, omit ``$5,000,000'', substitute ``$10,000,000''.

This amendment will effectively double the pecuniary penalty that could be ordered to be paid by the Federal Court in respect of contraventions of Austel directions. I think it is worth noting that amongst the matters that the Court can take into account is whether there have been previous offences. The maximum penalty would really, in practice, only be invoked against a carrier with prior convictions.

In the circumstances, given that carriers potentially probably have the deepest pockets in the country, they ought to be at risk for substantial sums of money-not that they would necessarily be ordered to pay those amounts. Parliament has an obligation to make it clear that it does want to impose a pecuniary penalty that will act as a deterrent. When we are dealing with corporations the size of some of the international carriers we have to be talking in very large sums of money. We therefore think that $10m is quite appropriate in the circumstances.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 350 to 355-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 356.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Clause 356, page 152, subclause (1), line 33, omit ``$5,000,000'', substitute ``$10,000,000''.
The reason for this amendment is obvious: it is to make the penalties consistent with the Opposition's amendment, which we have just accepted.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 357 to 392-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 393.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Clause 393, page 164, paragraph (2)(a) before the paragraph, insert the following paragraphs:
``(aa) a copy of each instrument that:
(i) AUSTEL gave to a carrier under subsection 46(1) during the financial year to which the annual report relates; and
(ii) in AUSTEL's opinion, contains no confidential information; and
(ab) in relation to each instrument that AUSTEL gave as mentioned in subparagraph (aa)(i) and that, in AUSTEL's opinion, contains confidential information:
(i) if, in AUSTEL's opinion, part of the instrument can be reproduced in the annual report without disclosing confidential information-a copy of that part; and
(ii) if subparagraph (i) does not apply-a statement specifying the instrument and the carrier to which, and the day on which, it was so given; and
(iii) a statement that, because of confidential information contained in the instrument, or in a part of it, as the case requires, the instrument or part is not reproduced in the annual report; and
(iv) a note summarising so much of the instrument as is not so reproduced, but without disclosing any information that, in AUSTEL's opinion, is confidential; and''.

The proposed Democrat amendment to clause 46 would have made Austel directions to carriers subject to parliamentary disallowance. That amendment was opposed for the reasons I gave when the amendment was discussed. One of those reasons was that such a direction may contain confidential information. This amendment will ensure that the Parliament remains fully informed to the extent consistent with requirements of confidentiality of all such directions by requiring Austel to include in its annual report a copy of each such direction that is given. Any confidential information is to be excluded, but a summary of excluded information is also to be included to the fullest extent possible so that people will know what has been left out.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 394 to 398-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 399.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 399, page 167, after subclause (2), insert the following subclause:
``(2A) When reviewing, and reporting on, the matters referred to in paragraphs (2)(a) and (b), AUSTEL must have regard to the performance standards it has developed under paragraph 38(2) (b).''.
This is simply a technical drafting amendment to the Bill and is consequential on an amendment the Committee has already carried relating to clause 38 of the Bill.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 400 to 405-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 405A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: After clause 405, page 168, insert the following clause:
Carriers or suppliers of eligible services not to supply certain telecommunications services

``405A (1) A carrier or commercial supplier of eligible services must not knowingly or recklessly supply a telecommunications service that involves the carrying across a telecommunications network of a communication that includes:

(a) if a minor can, without help from an adult, gain access to the service-material other than material that reasonable parents would feel confident that minors could view or hear without suffering harm or distress; or
(b) otherwise-material that:

(i) if it were contained in an item for which classification may be applied for under the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, would, under the guidelines for the time being applied under those Regulations, attract a classification of `R' or `X' or be refused classification; or

(ii) if it were contained in an item for which classification may be applied for under the Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 of the Australian Capital Territory, would, under the guidelines for the time being applied under that Ordinance, be classified under category 1 or 2 or be refused classification.
Penalty:
(a) in the case of a natural person $50,000; or
(b) in the case of a body corporate $250,000.''.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you proceeding with the other amendment as well?

—Senator Schacht has asked me whether I am proceeding with the other amendment circulated in my name. I am not. I will explain the reason for that. Honourable senators will note that this amendment is not as rigid as my previous amendment. There has been discussion with my Senate colleagues about this question and it is frankly considered that the whole issue of content and standards for broadcasting, telecommunications services, pay television and so on should be the subject of an inquiry by a select committee. It is also considered that in the meantime the current problem of child access, about which there is considerable concern in the community, should be dealt with in this Bill, and that the Bill should also be amended to ensure that a precedent in respect of pay television is not set which would pre-empt the outcome of an inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that is the view the Opposition holds, and I have discussed this with representatives of both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. The Telecommunications Bill and associated Bills are designed to give effect to the reforms announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) which would, inter alia, promote competition and dynamism in the telecommunications industry, maintain quality and services, and remove constraints that limit competition and do not serve the broader national interests. The provisions of the package appear to assume that the public interest is served merely by market forces, technical quality and integrity but not by the observance of standards of conduct.

There is an enormous amount of public interest and concern over the content and advertising of Telecom's 0055 and Discovery services. As indicated previously, last Thursday week I proposed an amendment that would have required Austel to adopt a code of conduct as a schedule to the Telecommunications Act and for carriers and suppliers to comply with that code of conduct. In fact, the schedule was couched in terms similar to those found in Telecom's contract with existing service providers for 0055. The provision also proposed that Austel be permitted to conduct a public inquiry into this question. However, since then, as I indicated, discussions have taken place and Austel has made it clear that it considers that it is not the appropriate body to establish or develop that code of conduct.

As honourable senators would know, Telecom has become concerned about the public outcry relating to its 0055 and Discovery services and has expressed legal doubts about its powers to set, administer and enforce content and advertising standards of the types that now form part of Telecom's service providers agreement. It was Telecom that first urged Austel, as the regulatory authority, to take responsibility in the area but, as I indicated, Austel considered that it was not the appropriate authority. I understand that there is also a view in this chamber that maybe Austel is not the appropriate authority. What has emerged from the discussions is that there ought to be a select committee of inquiry of the Parliament into this whole question of content standards in relation to broadcasts, telecommunications services, pay television, et cetera. No doubt there will be a number of other matters that honourable senators will want to have included in the terms of reference.

Frankly, I would have preferred to go along the lines that I proposed last Thursday week, but I understand the legitimacy of the view that has been expressed to me and I go along with it. I also go along with the very strong view that an amendment should be made to this Bill in the interim not only to cover the situation of child access to material that is considered harmful but also to allow for other material, provided that that material would not attract a classification of R or X or be refused classification. When I say `provided that that material', I mean that if it were contained in an item for classification under the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations it would, under the guidelines applied for the time being under those regulations, attract a classification of R or X or be refused classification. If it contained an item for which classification may be applied for under the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 it would, under the guidelines applied for the time being under that ordinance, be classified under category 1 or 2 or be refused classification. That would apply to the existing and future Telecom 0055 services and the Discovery services or like services.

The point is-and I make it very clear to the Committee-that in the arena of the video and audio entertainment and information services the Government's own guidelines provide that VAEIS providers will not program AO material unless arrangements have been made to ensure that the programs are not accessible to persons under the age of 18. I quote:
Films or other material that is classified ``R'' or ``X'' will not be carried under the authority of a VAEIS licence or contract.

In my view, that is a clear precedent and a clear indication that what is contained in my amendments is consistent with that particular view. Unless this amendment is carried, the lawyers will have an absolute field day with Telecom. Also, the new carrier will not be under any legislative constraints to adopt a reasonable code of conduct. Finally, I also believe that this amendment is essential-I do not suppose it is absolutely vital, but it will prevent a precedent being established-in order to prevent a precedent being established for pay television to include R and X material. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —For some reason, although it is not at all related to Austel, I have a funny feeling that we seem to have been debating this matter for ever. It has very little to do with the proposition put by Senator Harradine, the subject that he is concerned about. My particular reaction to this has to do with the ramifications of moving in the way that Senator Harradine wants to move. Indeed, that specifically is laid out in very clear terms in the schedule which was attached to Senator Harradine's original amendment which indicates the things which he wants to prevent being sent down telephone lines. At one stage-and I recall this as the then Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances-we had a regulation in force that made it an offence to tell a lie over the telephone. That regulation was done away with; it would have been interesting to have seen it policed and implemented.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not kidding; a regulation made it an offence to tell a lie over the telephone. It was removed a long time ago. I have sympathy and support for the proposition which further restricts access to 0055 numbers and I have taken that matter up with the Minister for Transport and Communications. But this legislation is not an appropriate vehicle for enacting what are essentially censorship arrangements governing the content of information and entertainment services that are provided over the network.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that Austel is considering proposals to restrict and place limitations on access to this service. The 0055 numbers available now contain stories that I have accessed purely for the purpose of knowing what I am talking about and that are the dullest, most boring and most unexciting pieces of nonsense that I have ever heard, although I concede that the question of excitement is a very subjective one.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are past your prime, of course.
—There is nothing wrong with my memory. I live on my memory.
—You are an extinct volcano.

—No, I am a senator. Being a senator, sitting the way we do, and being a Minister, I am required to live on my memory, although the existence of three beautiful children-fortunately they have a good looking mother-one of whom is only 18 months old, attests to it being more than a memory. But what is exciting is subjective. It is a very subjective matter, and that is one of my concerns about this amendment and its far reaching effects.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of my own personal life, having an engine failure in a single-engine aircraft at 10,000 feet over the Arafura Sea rates a perfect 10; a leadership challenge in the Australian Labor Party would probably come in at about six. Nothing I have heard over the 0055 number causes the needle on my excitement meter even to tremble, let alone register a response. I do concede that it is a subjective matter, and that is contained in clause 405A (1) (a), which says:

. . . if a minor can, without help from an adult, gain access to the service-material other than material that reasonable parents would feel confident that minors could view or hear without suffering harm or distress . . .

Tonight I will not again get into the tortuous debate as to what a reasonable parent is considered to be, because we have been into it in committees on which I have served and here in this Parliament on endless occasions. We have already established here in this chamber on more than one occasion that the subjective test of reason that would be applied by Senator Harradine is not the test that would be applied by me or, I dare to say, by a great many other senators, all of whom would have different views about what a reasonable parent is and what material should or should not be heard by children. If this is a matter of such great import, I am astounded at the lack of response from the electorate in terms of direct complaints.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about from Tasmania?

—Even in Tasmania there has been a dearth of complaints. Speaking personally, I have significant and considerable sympathy for Senator Harradine's view about restricting access. However, I have considerable difficulties in censoring the content of what goes over telephone lines. In having a look at the original attachment to Senator Harradine's original amendment, I have to say that it deserves some air time in terms of the all embracing nature of what is prevented from being sent down a telephone line in the form of titillating or sexually provocative conversations. It would make the life of a senator very dreary indeed if that small avenue of comfort were removed as well as any physical contact with one's family. We would have to be very careful what we said down a telephone line--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a question of subjective judgment. In response to Senator Harradine's interjection, I point out that it relates directly to his existing amendment-that is, the subjective matter of what reasonable people think is reasonable and what others might think is reasonable. It is a very subjective matter indeed. Here is this all-embracing clause which we are asked to enshrine in this legislation. I ask honourable senators to leave aside the views they may have on the matter of censorship. Senator Harradine complained about material being sprung on him from left field by the Government. I pointed out what a hollow criticism that was because an exposure draft of this telecommunications legislation has been around since February. I saw this amendment 10 minutes ago. It is not the same amendment as Senator Harradine confirmed he was going to move the last time we had this debate, and which I was familiar with. It is a new one which replaces that amendment, and I have just seen it.

SPEECH.PARA: As a matter of principle, and I say this having spent 15 years as a parliamentarian, I have a loathing of what the Standing Orders that I am more familiar with from another place refer to as `hasty and ill-considered legislation'. I hate making legislation on the run, particularly legislation which has such far reaching implications. I understand that Senator Harradine wants this referred to a committee. That proposition may or may not get up in the Senate, but it is interesting that before the matter is even referred to a committee-and we would expect this from Senator Harradine because we know what his views are-that reference is totally prejudged --

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all. I wanted it to go to a committee on the Thursday and you voted against it.

—That may well be Senator Harradine's view. It is not mine that we should be prejudging it. I am loath to give any support to such an all-embracing amendment as this. I have had only half an hour to consider it. I have read it as carefully as I could in the less than 30 minutes I had before I had to get up to speak to it. I would be loath to see enacted in a vehicle which is totally inappropriate, as this telecommunications package is, for the introduction of censorship regulation that has been so carelessly considered-at least by this Senate. I know it has been well considered by Senator Harradine, but this chamber has not had the chance to have a look at it yet. That is a point on which I have to take issue with him considering the criticisms he made of the Government during the last committee stage debate in foisting this telecommunications package on him, he alleged, at five minutes notice. I do not think any other piece of legislation that has reached this Senate has had more exposure to the public and had more submissions made on it than this telecommunications legislation. But I hesitate to put my stamp on an amendment to an Act of parliament which talks about reasonable people and what such people would feel confident that minors could view or hear without suffering harm or distress and so on. Where, in the interim, is that going to be judged-
—It comes from the Film Censorship Board.

—I know where it comes from. Senator Harradine knows full well the arguments. I think it is very inappropriate to apply the argument to what goes down telephone lines. I think the two matters are considerably different. Senator Harradine obviously thinks it is reasonable and appropriate to introduce censorship on what is going down a phone line. I do not think it is. What I think is absolutely appropriate is the question of access to that information. I know that Austel is considering that. I, along with others, have made representations on the subject directly and at length to the Minister for telecommunications following a commitment that I gave to Senator Harradine the last time this was debated in the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of all that, Austel is actively considering restrictions on access to this information-although, making a subjective judgment, I think the content of those current services is laughable rather than titillating. One wonders who in the hell these services are designed for. I suppose there is a market for it, as there must be for dial-a-joke or dial-an-insult, although I cannot understand why people ring those lines either.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not if you are in the Senate.

—Dial-a-joke comes in handy at times. I know that Austel is looking at the possibility of pin numbers to get access to these services or an opt-in service-that is, one has to apply for the service rather than have it available on any service-or a recorded message stating at the beginning what type of service is involved, the cost per minute, the fact that the number has been called, and that the number called will appear on a telephone bill, as these numbers do.

SPEECH.PARA: As a reasonable and responsible parent, I have canvassed my concerns about the original 0055 service generally in this Parliament before. I was probably one of the first cabs off the rank. My office is located in the Telecom building in Darwin and I remember taking the lift down to the Telecom Manager's office on the same day that the 0055 service started. I related in the House how I found out that very badly reproduced pop music, for example, could be accessed at whatever the cost is per minute; people could dial in for the top 40 numbers. That service was not then separately identified on a telephone account. Telecom responded very quickly to that. I am not saying that I was the only person who made representations. I asked Telecom to consider giving customers an opportunity to opt out, which they did not at that stage have-everyone had access to 0055 whether they wanted it or not-that that opt-out service should be free and that, in the case of people who opted to remain in, the actual numbers accessed would appear as separate accountable items on the telephone account. I did that purely because of the concern I had about access to this service by minors. This was not just in respect of `Ena does Iceland' and `Debbie does' something or other--

TALK.START.PARA: —Dallas.

—Not Dallas. That is real porn; this is pathetic porn. I did that because of access by minors to anything that 0055 provided. Telecom very promptly did that. We now have an opt-out service where one can telephone Telecom and request over the phone that access to 0055 numbers be barred from the telephone, which I have done. Telecom then moved to ensure that access to these numbers is itemised as separate items on a telephone account. It would be a strange parent indeed, and an unreasonable parent, who did not have concerns about what their children were doing over the phone. I, along with most parents, share a concern about telephone accounts, even though the taxpayers pay for mine, and I think that is reflected in how much of that service I use. It would be, as Senator Tambling has acknowledged, a reasonable amount. Most parents are very concerned about their telephone bills and the precise numbers that were being accessed from the phone would be very quickly obvious to any parent.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to speak briefly to Senator Harradine's amendment. In many ways my remarks will reflect the tenor of Senator Collins's remarks. First of all, as I said in the previous part of this debate, I do not believe that these sorts of amendments should be debated within this package of Bills, which deal with the restructuring of Australia's telecommunications industry. These amendments deal with other issues rather than the structure and operation of an efficient telecommunications system in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine has the right-and he has used it-to put forward his amendments. He has already withdrawn one circulated amendment which, as Senator Collins said, has the schedule of what Senator Harradine would consider should be banned from 0055. It is an extraordinarily wide definition. I just do not know how, in any modern society, Senator Harradine could carry out that definition without it being used to censor, in a pluralistic society, people's right to know and do what they like amongst themselves. It is about time we understood that consenting adults should be able to do and share certain things amongst themselves in a modern society without having busy-bodies imposing their moral values on what should or should not be allowed.

Senator Harradine has withdrawn that amendment and left the amendment before us, which does not contain the schedule. The schedule tips us off as to what he is really on about. In the amendment before us, Senator Harradine has in paragraph (a) a definition which he says he has taken-and I accept his explanation-from the definition used by the film censor. But we are not talking about films, we are talking about telecommunications-what goes down a copper wire or an optic fibre cable between two people.

As Senator Collins said, Senator Harradine's main concern, if it is genuine, should be who has access to 0055 numbers. I agree that there is a case that minors should not have access or be encouraged to have easy access to those numbers. I do not believe that Senator Harradine should take an attitude that everything should be banned because it is possible that one child sometime somewhere, even accidentally, may have access to the 0055 services that he is so offended by.

Senator Collins has intimated that the question of access may be referred to a select committee of the Senate. I think that may be useful. I hope it does not go through the torture of the previous select committee of the Senate, which dealt with R-rated and X-rated videos. It went on and on and became an absolute saga which nobody could agree with.
I draw Senator Harradine's attention to paragraph (a) of the amendment which deals with telecommunications. It states:
. . . material other than material that reasonable parents would feel confident that minors could view or hear without suffering harm or distress . . .

Firstly, how will Austel Pty Ltd determine who is a reasonable parent? Senator Harradine is not talking about an individual's minors; in this amendment he is talking about all minors. As I read it, parents could complain about any minor-not just their own but anyone's-having access to 0055.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will.

—Of course they will. We know that a small minority in this community will use that opportunity to impose their moral values on everybody else and claim that they are acting on behalf of delinquent parents.
—That is not true.

—That is what people will claim. I find it an intolerable situation that Senator Harradine would put forward such a sweeping clause that is open to wide interpretation. In fact, in some ways this clause and the one he has already withdrawn-thank goodness-are the sorts of things a totalitarian state would bring in to scare people off doing anything. It is the old technique: write a wide clause that can be interpreted by the police or the authorities in any way they like to catch somebody. In that way everybody is stopped from doing anything. It is a totalitarian method, and I know that Senator Harradine has spoken out against totalitarian communism in this chamber on many occasions. I give as an example what Senator Harradine has said in this chamber and elsewhere about the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968. Quite rightly, this chamber and this Parliament condemned that invasion, that suppression of human rights and civil liberties.

SPEECH.PARA: Recently there was shown in Australia a movie called The Unbearable Lightness Of Being. It was a fantastic movie about the Soviet takeover of Czechoslovakia in 1968. It showed every aspect of a totalitarian system trying to crush the individual spirit. Yet in that same movie there were scenes that, under Senator Harradine's definition in that schedule, would be inappropriate and would be banned from being shown on pay television. There is nudity and there is sexual activity, but it is not prurient; it is there in the context of the story. Under Senator Harradine's definition this movie would be banned. The movie does more to explain why totalitarian communism is evil than any number of speeches Senator Harradine or I could make in this chamber in 100 years. Yet he would ban it under the definitions he has put in this amendment and in the amendment he withdrew.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the amendments. That is wrong.
—I beg to differ.
—That is wrong.
—That is certainly so with the one Senator Harradine withdrew.
—It was on the 0055 requirement.

—The new technology is coming. I admit that I do not know how it will develop, but it may be possible before this decade is out for us to have, through the copper phone wire or the optic fibre cable, pay television showing movies such as The Unbearable Lightness of Being, with scenes Senator Harradine would find distasteful and would not want children to see.
—That wasn't an R and it wasn't an X; it was an M.
—The definition in the amendment Senator Harradine has withdrawn does not talk about R-rated.
—Read my amendment.

—Senator Harradine tried with one amendment and withdrew it. That is the bottom line; that is what he is really on about. Even in this amendment, paragraph (a) is the all-encompassing clause that gives Senator Harradine and people with like views the right to censor anybody else and to use it in a way that intimidates people.

SPEECH.PARA: To come back to the point Senator Collins dealt with, the access of minors to the 0055 numbers, I think Senator Harradine has a point. However, that can be dealt with simply by a committee. We can look at it and we can establish rules that I believe will not enable a minority to impose their morality on the majority but will provide reasonable protection for minors.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is no wonder Senator Schacht could not get the numbers for Mr Keating if that is the sort of specious nonsense that he was trotting around by way of argumentation. Virtually the bulk of Senator Schacht's contribution consisted of reference to a withdrawn amendment. I cannot believe that he could seriously stand up here and try to persuade people on the basis of a document that is no longer in existence. I should have thought that intelligent human beings having a discussion on the issue could at least confine themselves to the amendment before the Chair. Yet Senator Schacht was so preoccupied with his own prejudices that at one stage he thought that Austel was going to be the arbiter of this sort of conduct, when that is precisely what it is not about. The original amendment, from which he seems never to have moved, did involve a reference to Austel, and that is precisely why we were not in favour of it. I commend Senator Harradine for accepting the proposition--
—I don't think I said anything at all about Austel.

—The honourable senator did. He may not have meant to but he did. I think it is because he was preoccupied with that document and its schedule, which he seems to think is somehow the real agenda in this debate-a tragic way of dismissing the merits of an argument. I commend Senator Harradine on having accepted the proposition that it is not appropriate for a body such as Austel, which is concerned with the economics of the industry and the technology that has to be applied, in its spare time to accept the role of moral arbiter. Therefore, it was quite proper that we did not proceed down that track.

SPEECH.PARA: But what is now proposed, and what we ought to face up to, is that there are genuine concerns in the community about the 0055 service. Senator Collins in his more forthcoming moments uses terms such as, `I have a great sympathy and support for restricting access'. If the truth be known, he is really saying that he believes that there is very little going for these sorts of services. He does not believe that any healthy human being derives any great benefit from listening to them. We ought to think very seriously before we simply allow these sorts of things to be churned out.

All that is proposed in this amendment, given that we are all accepting that a select committee be proposed-and I believe that it will be supported and therefore established-is an interim arrangement that puts the onus on those who come later to revert to the open slather situation that we have at the moment. There is nothing wrong with that, in my view. If we want to maintain the status quo, we essentially have a hands-off arrangement and condone what is currently going down the lines. That is the very sort of thing to which Senator Collins and others say access ought to be restricted.

All that would be happening is that over the next period of months one would be in effect calling a halt to what is going on at the present time, pending the outcome of that committee assessment. That seems an appropriate way of approaching it. I am not persuaded, for example, that the various means suggested of restricting access will have that desired effect, particularly the opt in and opt out arrangement. It is very easy to envisage a situation in which one will simply be asked whether one wants to opt in or opt out without even knowing what one is being asked to opt for. In most instances people will be asked to make a black and white decision and there will be no genuine assessment of what they are opting for. At the moment one would be opting out of cricket and a whole range of other facilities. Presumably, there has to at least be a dividing line drawn between those sorts of services and the ones that concern this chamber and, I suspect, the wider community.

There are significant difficulties in the way of ensuring that minors are unable to access the network. It is therefore even more appropriate that we have a mature consideration by a select committee of the sorts of difficulties that will arise down the track-concerns not just about content but also about the appropriate regulatory authority and whether it ought to be the successor to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, a standards body or some other organisation. They are all very legitimate questions. They are not pre-empted by calling a stop to what is going on at the moment. That is simply a holding arrangement to enable the whole matter to be properly assessed. We should not for a moment be sidetracked by grotesque analogies with a totalitarian Czechoslovakia. Senator Schacht is re-running all those old arguments that somehow were never prepared to confront the reality of what people were concerned about.

No-one for a moment argues in favour of totalitarianism, but it is a disgraceful distortion of concern about moral issues or about the sorts of values that we all adopt in a society to accuse anyone who wants to restrict the sorts of outpourings to which others seem to be quite happy to be subjected as somehow totalitarian and therefore not worthy of consideration.

The reality, I would have thought, is that nearly everyone in this society does have genuine concerns about the sort of mush that comes out and there are very few redeeming features in favour of it. Therefore, to talk in the same breath about it being censorship to restrict the sort of coverage that we are talking about is simply hypocrisy.

I would argue very strongly that it is desirable that assessments be made of what ought to be available in the public domain to see whether such material does have any redeeming features-not to prejudge the issue, and certainly not to dismiss anyone who has the temerity to express concern and be prepared to consider limitations as somehow thoughtless, heartless, non-liberal and in all sorts of ways, as Senator Schacht would have it, totalitarian.

The fact of the matter is that there are quite a lot of people who I do not think benefit at all and who, in many ways, do not even know what they are opting for when they do call. Quite often, they might not even be getting their money's worth and they might want their money back. Someone at some stage has to make a judgment about what is available on those systems. For Senator Collins to pretend that somehow the standard that is proposed in 405A(1) (a) is entirely subjective simply shows a comprehensive misunderstanding of the concept of subjective and objective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to have a look at the case law?
—Let me take Senator Collins to it.
—I have been to it ad nauseam.

—Senator Collins has obviously visited it with his eyes closed. If he took a subjective view, he would have regard for what every individual parent thought; so that one particular parent who was greatly concerned-terrified-at the prospect would be able to rule the regime for society. That is a subjective approach and that is not what the Government does.
—It will be determined in the Federal Court, as you well know.

—The Minister can argue that there are problems with applying objective standards, and I do not quarrel with that because it is a difficult matter, but it is an entirely different notion. To characterise that as a subjective standard shows that he simply does not understand the meaning of the term.

SPEECH.PARA: An objective standard is one that is determined by a community group, parliament, tribunal or court that does its best to come up with a norm which others then have to conform to. If they fall below it because of their own personal idiosyncrasies, that is too bad. That is an objective standard, not a subjective standard. If Senator Collins were to apply a subjective standard, he would be simply taking account of each individual view of the world, and that is not what is proposed in this amendment. I just hope that we will not have a perpetuation of that sort of nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you are sensitive about not being a liberal any more, Richard.

—Those sorts of cheap shots are fairly typical, but they do not disguise the paucity of the Minister's argument. In many ways I thought it was very noticeable that he took his riding instructions from Senator Schacht. Once Senator Schacht told the Minister what to do, he started parroting this censorship line when in fact, as he well knows, all that is proposed here is a holding of the line until a sensible assessment is made by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister wants to go on about censorship, he is going down the same track as Senator Schacht and taking this dishonest, dismissive approach of totalitarianism, censorship or any other buzz word that they think will ring the right sorts of bells. It is a lazy intellectual approach to a very difficult question which deserves a lot more, and certainly the Minister is capable of giving it a lot more. If he comes in here and wrings his hands about his young children and how much concern he has for them, at the very least he ought to be able to address the argument on its merits and not throw around words such as `censorship'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have addressed it. I have cut off 0055.

—I simply say that I think it is desirable that these issues are faced up to, and that we do not just wash our hands of them and pretend that somehow what is going on there is beyond anyone's control. Telecom does not argue that. Telecom is simply--
—Have you accessed the service?
—No, I have not because I am not particularly interested.
—But you are happy to debate it as the lead speaker for the Opposition.
—Yes, I am happy to debate it.
—But you do not want to know what you are speaking about.
—Order! Would you address your remarks through the Chair, Senator Alston? I hope that interjections will cease.
—I am not prejudging the content. I am simply saying that a committee is the best judge of what ought to be a community standard.
—So you are not supporting the amendment?
—We are supporting the amendment, because we have to have a holding position.
—Why?

—Simply because either we allow something to run on or we decide not to let it run on, pending a hearing. Senator Collins knows full well that Telecom has been making a very big fat quid by turning a blind eye to this sort of thing. It is now slowly succumbing to community pressure and it is devising a range of defence mechanisms by way of contracting in and by way of recorded warnings. It is preposterous nonsense to suggest that if we put a recorded message on it saying, `Beware. You are about to listen to a very prurient message', it would act as a deterrent. One can just imagine what deterrent effect that would have.

SPEECH.PARA: There has to be a decision made either to let it run or to stop it, pending a proper investigation. That is all this amendment is doing. I would have thought that that was a perfectly responsible position. It does not constitute for a moment the closing down of a service. It simply says, `Let's stop and decide. We will have a presumption in favour of innocence. We will make it conform to a standard where no-one can seriously complain about it in the meantime'. Senator Collins may well be the expert on these matters and he may be able to pontificate at great length about the relative merits of the various services, but I do not even want to start doing that, because it does not particularly interest me. I am more concerned about having an objective inquiry and putting in place an objective standard in the interim. If we go down that track, as Senator Harradine proposes, then we will be acknowledging the seriousness of community concern. We will not be prejudging the issue, but taking a responsible approach to it. I very much regret that Senator Collins does not seem to be prepared to do any of those things.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to assist the Committee by explaining how the pin numbers might work. Would they in fact work to allay Senator Harradine's concern about minors having access to these services? Secondly, could the Minister tell us whether opting in means opting in for all the services? If so, that does not assist as much as we might have hoped.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of what will allay Senator Harradine's concerns can only be properly addressed by Senator Harradine.
—Is this copping out or opting out? You were asked about pin numbers.

—Will Senator Alston allow me to finish? I have only said one sentence. I am simply pointing out the obvious-that Senator Harradine's judgment on this matter is best expressed by Senator Harradine. However, I would assume from copious debates in the Senate that Senator Harradine is as concerned-as he himself would state-with content as he is with access. From listening to Senator Harradine's contributions, I do not think that he would be satisfied until the content itself was removed from the services. But Senator Harradine is the best person to address what Senator Harradine thinks.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —To answer Senator Kernot's question, rather than Senator Alston's interjections, the pin numbers would operate in precisely the same way as they do with credit cards now-if that were the option that Austel decided to adopt. In other words, it is a service for which one would have to apply. My own view is that the number of people who would actually apply for what is currently available would be very small. In response to Senator Alston's comments about that, I must say that I did suspect some time ago that the coalition had chased the last of the Liberals out of its ranks and I am now convinced that it has.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Alston made the extraordinary assertion, and it is a very common one, that because I have tried to become informed about what I am discussing and have actually accessed a service-and the Hansard will indicate what Senator Alston said-this indicates that I am some low character. In other words, he suggests that I am an expert on these matters, unlike Senator Alston, who said that he has no interest in this matter. I think that if people want to talk about being objective, and in the same breath suggest banning something that they admit they have not even listened to, before the Committee even has a chance to examine it, they should look rather to their own bona fides than cast smears and slurs, as Senator Alston tried to do. And, to be precise about it, Senator Alston, in the company of departmental officers, accessed these services to find out what material was in fact going to unsuspecting people down the phone line.
To make that cheap jibe about my being some sort of low character because I have actually accessed the service-to try to inform myself about that which I am talking-indicates an attitude--

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't say that.

—Senator Panizza should refer to the Hansard. It indicates an attitude, on behalf of what are so-called Liberals these days, that I find extraordinary. Pin numbers was only one of three options which I canvassed that I knew Austel was currently looking at. One was the opt-in service. The other option that I mentioned that Senator Alston took particular exception to-clearly, he did not listen to the last part of it-was a pre-recorded message that would advise people of what they were listening to. It was the last of the options that are being looked at. Senator Alston is now saying that it is a bad thing for people investigating things to even look at the whole range of options that are available. I did mention three, the first two of which Senator Alston did not even touch on. Fortunately, Senator Kernot has raised what I think is fundamentally what is likely to be, in my personal view, the most effective.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of my sweet reason, I have done what is available to other people around the place and not accessed the service. I have no need for any of the services provided, including advice on how to kill cockroaches, which is made available, the top 40 songs, cricket commentaries, or whatever. I do not have any need for any 0055 services. In any case, that was not in response to what Senator Alston said. The most effective measure I asked to have applied, which Telecom did apply, for responsible parents is that, as well as having the option to opt out of the system completely-Senator Alston was clearly not listening-a separate itemised account appear on every person's telephone account listing each 0055 number that is accessed in that service. So a person is immediately able to find out precisely what services are being accessed from their telephones in their homes.

The reason I raise that is that I consider that to be a reasonable interim measure introduced by Telecom since the beginning of this service, pending a more exhaustive examination. I stand on that: I think that is a reasonable measure to provide some degree of protection to parents who want to know how their telephone is being used to access this service. They know precisely just by examining the telephone account. Every single individual number is laid out on that telephone account as being a 0055 service that is accessed. I think that is reasonable in the interim. In the interim, Austel is examining the matter.

The Opposition has indicated-I did not know this until Senator Alston spoke-that it will be supporting the reference being sent to a committee, and it will go to a committee. Clearly, the numbers are here to do that. There is no doubt that the matters contained in this proposed legislation will be far more responsibly dealt with if a committee has an opportunity to examine it rather than its simply being done off the tops of our heads tonight in the Committee, it being part of a Bill which is clearly not designed to act as a conduit for censorship but is designed to operate for the operations of these new carriers. I do not want to unnecessarily delay the Committee any more. I think I have said as much as I can usefully say on the subject and I will leave it at that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that explanation. We have heard a lot about legitimate concerns being raised by these amendments and about genuine concerns in the community about 0055 numbers. These amendments give us a choice of two possibilities: either we accept the amendment's proposed interim arrangements pending an inquiry or we accept the status quo pending an inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: To say that one would support the interim arrangements makes a lot of assumptions that I do not believe have really been formally canvassed at this stage in the way an inquiry would achieve. I think an inquiry would hear a very wide range of views and the extent and precise nature of the concern about 0055 numbers as distinct from all the evidence some of us have already heard on X-rated videos. That distinct evidence has not yet been canvassed, and I agree with Senator Alston that someone has to make a judgment at some stage. However, it is the view of the Australian Democrats that this judgment ought to be made after the inquiry.

I suggest that, to avoid pre-empting the inquiry's findings, it might be suitable to proceed by ensuring that these amendments are actually referred to that committee in total, that this is a speedy reference and that the committee reports back at a date which ensures that the inquiry is not unnecessarily protracted in the way that some other inquiries have been. I think it would be quite helpful for us to have the opportunity to examine, for example, how pay television will be caught up in all of this and I would welcome that opportunity.

In the meantime, given a choice between an interim arrangement and the status quo, the Democrats would opt for the status quo in the knowledge that we were going to have this inquiry, and we would certainly be prepared to make sure that Senator Harradine's amendments were made part of the terms of reference of that inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I enter this debate by briefly taking up a point made earlier by Senator Schacht: that is, that this concern is not electorally driven. I find that an astonishing statement because of the number of petitions I have been asked to present to the Parliament, and the number of other communications sent to my office, including communications from the bishops around Australia. I believe the bishops are speaking for their congregations on this issue. If they are not, I am sure their congregations would have told us the opposite.
—They can't sack them.

—The Minister should not worry about that because that depends on where one's belief lies. A few congregations in Australia can sack their bishops; one main congregation cannot, and I belong to that one. So some bishops can be sacked. However, I presume that the bishops are talking for their congregations. Certainly the petitions and letters I have been receiving are genuine, as are the petitions and letters other members of parliament who represent Western Australia have been getting.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe we have to take notice of this sort of electorally-driven concern. I believe that following the interim line by coming back to the standard type of classifications presently in force for television and video would not be a bad thing to do until we have a report from the select committee. In the case of minors, we have to draw the line somewhere. It is all very well to say that parents must bring their own children up, but I believe one has to draw the line in respect of access. I know it has been said in this place that one can cut access by opting out. I opted out of one telephone service last week when I saw that my Telecom bill contained some 0055 numbers. I wondered what was going on and found out that the kids were using the 0055 number to find where the rostered fuel stations were. I believe there is a cheaper way to do that than by ringing the 0055 number, such as by reading the Sunday Times or whatever, so I opted to have that facility removed. Unfortunately, by doing that I opted out from other sources of information available through the 0055 number, such as stock exchange information and so on. Those are important things to which one must have access. I do not believe that opting out is an option at this stage.

I believe that as a nation we have to draw the line somewhere with minors. I go along with consenting adults in private being able to view, hear or do what they want to because that is their entitlement, but we have to draw the line somewhere with minors. In the meantime, there are ways of going about it, such as establishing the sorts of standard classifications we have. Senator Kernot said that we should leave it as it stands until we have a report. I disagree with that. I believe that technology will take over, as it does in most cases, and that this material will not be able to be accessed by a child without the help of an adult. This could be through using a pin number or some other device. That could be the way to go.

Until that comes, and the technology is probably available now, we should go down the line of having an inquiry by this committee, which I believe is going to be a quick inquiry. We can then deal with access through the use of a pin number or other device, and there are other ways. Pin numbers can be inserted not only by voice but also by ringing certain numbers, as happens with some telecards overseas. We know from reading our mail that the electoral pressure in relation to this matter is not minimal. In view of that pressure, I believe that this is a good compromise until we can resolve the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to refer first of all to what Senator Kernot said. Frankly, I am surprised that Senator Kernot should say that we should not do anything about the problem. There is a major problem at the moment which is twofold. It is being experienced by a wide range of people and also by Telecom itself. Telecom gets a large number of complaints. I think it was Senator Collins who said that in the interim separate billing would be appropriate. Telecom does not believe that separate billing fills the bill, if you like, and overcomes the problem.
—They don't.
—No, they do not. Telecom says that something else should be done about it.
—I will bet they don't say that this is what should be done.
—Telecom says that this type of material should go onto another numbering code.
—That is correct. They don't say that they would support your amendment.

—I do not know what Telecom says about that. My amendment says that material that is suitable for all ages should remain on 0055 and, so far as the other material is concerned, that that should be on another numbering system.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder whether Senator Kernot or Senator Collins realises what is happening in the Discovery service of Telecom. The Discovery service of Telecom is part of the AO closed user group. I will read out some of the material that is available through the closed user group: information which promotes, seeks or advertises sexual contact containing explicit depictions of sexual contact or sexual acts, proposed or containing obscene language; advertisements for sexual services where descriptions of sexual acts are provided-for example, `mistress available for domination'-and so on. We are talking about material that would fit within the X category if it contained items such as that. What Senator Schacht and Senator Collins are saying is that the Government does not care about content. They do not care about content; they care only about access.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to agree with you.

—Senator Schacht has to agree with me. We ought to be clear about what we are doing here. If my amendment is not carried, what the Government is proposing to do-Senator Schacht has said it-is to continue the current situation which sets a precedent for R- and X-rated videos to be carried over pay television when it comes in. That is contrary to--
—What is wrong with that?

—It is contrary to the Government's own VAEIS guidelines. I wish that Senator Kernot were here to listen to this because it is contrary to the Government's own VAEIS guidelines. The VAEIS guidelines say that material that is rated AO shall not be programmed by VAEIS providers unless arrangements have been made for access to be denied to persons under the age of 18. It specifically says that X- and R-rated material shall not be programmed by VAEIS providers. That is the Government's own guideline. We are learning something here tonight. It appears that the Government is saying-it is what Senator Schacht and Senator Collins are saying- `No, that's not right. We're not interested in what content goes over telecommunications services'. That is what they said.
—That is not what I said.

—That is what Senator Collins said and it is what Senator Schacht said: `We are not interested in the content that goes over these telecommunications services'. Of course, pay television will be part of the telecommunications services. OTC Ltd, Telecom or the new player will be providing the pay television services. All I am trying to do with this amendment is ensure that a precedent is not established. All of the nonsense, all of the straw men-or, as Senator Coulter said, the straw women-that have been put up are appalling. Senator Collins said that my proposal would have far-reaching effects. It would do nothing more nor less than what the Government does itself in its guidelines on VAEIS. I ask Senator Collins whether that is a far-reaching effect as far as these services are concerned. I ask him to think about that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins talks then about `a reasonable parent'. It will not be the reasonable parent or Austel who will be the judge who makes the determination; it will be the courts. The point is that these words are used quite commonly in legislation relating to content of entertainment services. The words are used in the legislation to which this amendment refers. They are used in the Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983, which is mentioned in this amendment. It is not unusual and it only shows the ignorance of the Minister and other people who have been speaking on behalf of the Government about what is contained in the legislation. Those people are ignorant of the proposals and of their own guidelines, and they are ignorant of their own legislation, upon which my amendment is based. I will not deal with the ludicrous points and straw men Senator Schacht has put up.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed.
—If I am given enough time I will. Senator Kernot says that the interim arrangements I have proposed make certain assumptions. What are those assumptions?
—That your concerns are proved to be shared by enough people to warrant taking that action, and that the right action to take is an inquiry.
—I respond by asking two questions. Firstly, has there not been a major expression of concern about this amongst voters, electors, concerned parents and others in the community?
—I am not sure.

—There has been. Secondly, does the honourable senator agree that the Discovery service should continue to send down the telecommunications networks communications which are the equivalent of R and X material?
—No, not necessarily.

—Not necessarily, but it is doing that. I have been there. I happen to have gone there and had a look at it, and I happen to know what is in the material. It surely is a precedent. Unless my amendment is carried, Senator Kernot is going to have a problem. She is accepting that the status quo should continue-that is, that Telecom's lines should be used for material such as Discovery material to go through the service.
—What do you want to do?

—I do not want to pre-empt the situation. That has been done without any authority of the Government or the Parliament. That is what has happened, and it is happening now. My amendment would ensure that the problem of child access is attended to. It would not be done immediately, but it would give the service providers until 1 July, when this Bill comes into operation, which would be enough time to get their act in order. It would also prevent pay television continuing to include R and X material. This is a very important question. I am afraid that a number of speakers have shown by their comments that they are not aware of the situation. I believe there is too much concentration-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

Tuesday, 18 June 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins does not have any further excuse. He could have had my amendment thoroughly checked and examined. His excuse beforehand was that he had had the amendment for only half an hour. The week before last I asked that the amendments go to a legislation committee on a Friday, but he refused that. Now he is denying himself the time to have a look at the matter. I believe we have the opportunity, by my amendment, to protect children who will not be protected until after the inquiry is completed. Unless we adopt this amendment those children will not be protected. It will be the fault of those senators who vote against this amendment that they will not be protected. That will be noted by the electors of this country-I can assure Senator Collins of that--

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

Omit `section 114 of the Telecommunications Act 1989', substitute `section 253 of the Telecommunications Act 1991'.
