Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 2, page 1, subclause (1), lines 7 and 8, omit ``a day to be fixed by proclamation'', substitute ``1 January 1992''.

This amendment seeks to insert a commencement date in the Bill, that date being 1 January 1992. We have many reasons for doing this. To begin with, we want to ensure that the staff of the merged entity do not suffer from the low morale and problems that ensue from the long period of uncertainty that attends these Acts waiting for a set date for the merger. We think that putting in a date in this way will break the nexus between the interconnect agreement and the merger. We want to make sure that the Government keeps its promise to go ahead with the merger.

In the explanatory notes to this Bill, the Minister for Transport and Communications deliberately left out a commencement date. I believe his reason was that this would act as a spur to ensure that the merged body and the new carrier reached agreement on interconnect price and capabilities as soon as possible. In fact, I understand that Austel's report on the interconnect fee may have reached the Minister either on Friday or today. I wonder whether the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support might care to respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tomorrow-today.
—That is convenient. I wonder whether the Minister might indicate when the findings of that report will be released. It is a crucial piece of the jigsaw puzzle we are all waiting for.

—It is my advice that the Minister will probably have a copy of it later this day, and it is proposed that the Government will deal with the matter expeditiously. It is proposed that the document will be available some time in the next few weeks.

—I thank the Minister. The interconnect and transmission charges and service access charges, including charges for billing and other ancillary services, will cover all the Australian and Overseas Telecommunication Corporation's related costs in providing the service and underpin its community service obligations on a pro rata basis. Because of the vital importance of interconnection, we did not think it right to see the merger hanging on the interconnect fee and capability.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that the matter of the merger has become a political football between some factions of the Australian Labor Party. I would think that, in not having a date on this legislation, the Government may be risking going against some of the special conference resolutions that called for this merger to go ahead as quickly as possible. I believe that the Government, in not having a date, is not adhering to the spirit of those resolutions. I am surprised that the Government may not support this amendment.

If it is the Opposition's intention to secure a healthy, viable, merged entity-a reason it gives for denying the Government the merger fee-I wonder whether it might not also be in the Opposition's interest to remove the uncertainty facing the staff of the merged body. I cannot see why it would not be consistent for the Opposition to support this amendment as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government strongly opposes this amendment, for reasons which I must say are not in the least bit conspiratorial or faction-based or anything else. They are again transparent. We oppose this amendment strongly because it is utterly against the interests of the competitor to Telecom and thereby consumers. There is no question about that.
—What about the disadvantage for Telecom?
—Senator Kernot asks about the problem of disadvantaging Telecom.
—Why should the Government give the advantage to one?

—Can I say in response to that, Mr Chairman, that I appreciate the Democrats' fundamental position. We are all starting from our own fundamental positions. I understand the Democrats' fundamental position that the very introduction of competition is a disadvantage to Telecom. But this amendment totally destroys the basis of the Government's careful and deliberate strategy in bringing this about. Telecom will have every incentive and, indeed, the obligation to implement equal access interconnect arrangements for the second carrier at the earliest possible date to allow the start-up of competition on a fair, competitive basis.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, the Government has determined that the merger of Telecom and OTC for the benefit-make no bones about it-of that competitor and thereby the consumer will not proceed until Austel has certified that satisfactory interconnect arrangements are in place. There will be an incentive and we are hopeful that it will happen before that date. We have said very deliberately-and this is the sole reason why the Government has not set a predetermined start-up date-that the merger will not go ahead until the interconnect arrangements are satisfactory, as far as the Government is concerned, for the benefit of the competitor and thereby the consumer. If this amendment were carried it would negate the safeguards that the Government has deliberately designed to accompany the merger and it could fundamentally undermine the Government's strategy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Safeguards!

—I have no difficulty in saying that the whole purpose of this exercise is to provide Telecom with competition. I understand and accept the Democrats' position-that it does not want competition for Telecom-but we do. The amendment would negate the safeguards that we have built in to accompany the merger. It would fundamentally undermine the Government's strategy to ensure that the competition between the carriers is fair and that the maximum benefits of competition are derived for all consumers. Therefore, we will not set a date until Austel determines that those interconnect arrangements are fair, and I freely confess that they may not necessarily be particularly to the advantage of Telecom.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 3, page 2, definition of ``authorised person'', line 13, at end of definition, add ``, provided that before so authorising a person the Minister shall be satisfied, having regard to that person's abilities and experience, that that person is suitably qualified to perform the functions required of the person''.

We simply want to ensure that an authorised person, where it is not the Minister himself or herself, is someone with qualifications and experience. We believe, therefore, that the definition ought to reflect those requirements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has no objection to the principle behind the Opposition's amendment. The Democrats are moving a similar amendment to the same clause and we do not object to the principle; we just prefer the wording of the Democrats' amendment. We would oppose the Opposition's amendment with a view to accepting the Democrats' amendment because, although it does the same thing, we think the wording is better.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment-by leave-withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —While we are dealing with clause 3- `Interpretations'-we have the description of AOTC. Has any consideration been given to the trading name of the merged carrier? I am interested to know whether it will use Telecom as its trading name. If not will it be left to the new board decide the trading name, trademark and so on?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Schacht's question is option 2. It will be a matter for the board to determine the trading name of the organisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. Clause 3, page 2, definition of ``authorised person'', paragraph (b), lines 12 and 13, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
``(b) a person who:
(i) is authorised by the Minister, in writing, for the purposes of the provision in which the expression is used; and

(ii) when the authorisation was given, was, in the Minister's opinion, suitably qualified, because of the person's abilities and experience, to perform the functions of an authorised person within the meaning of that provision;''.
For reasons similar to those outlined by Senator Alston, we think it is better that the person appointed must be qualified by experience and personal qualities.
Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.

Proposed new part 1a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. ``After clause 7, page 4, insert the following Part:
``PART 1A-REQUIREMENTS PRIOR TO SUCCESSION DAY
Proper commercial debt/equity ratio to be provided for Telecom and OTC

``7a. (1) Subject to subsections (3) and (4), a succession day shall not be fixed under subsection 2 (1) unless and until the Minister is satisfied that Telecom and OTC each have achieved a capital structure, in terms of debt and equity, on a commercial basis equivalent to the average interest cover and debt ratio of the mid-range Standard and Poors AA ratings of major telecommunications companies.

``(2) In this section `Standard and Poors' means the international organisation of that name which provides and publishes financial and other information and analysis relating to private and public organisations and entities.

``(3) As soon as practicable after forming a judgment as to whether the requirements of subsection (1) have been satisfied, the Minister shall cause to be laid before each House of the Parliament full documentation recording details of the debt and equity position of Telecom and OTC, in the terms required by subsection (1).
``(4) A succession day shall not be fixed under subsection 2 (1) unless and until the provisions of subsection (3) have been complied with.
Financial statements for Telecom and OTC to be presented

``7b. A succession day shall not be fixed under subsection 2 (1) unless and until the Minister has caused to be laid before each House of the Parliament financial statements of both Telecom and OTC having regard, so far as it possible, to the requirements of section 316 of the Corporations Law of the Australian Capital Territory.
Memorandum and articles of association of AOTC

``7c. A succession day shall not be fixed under subsection 2(1) unless and until the Minister has caused to be laid before each House of the Parliament a copy of the memorandum and articles of association of the AOTC.''.

The purpose of this amendment is to ensure that the merged entity-flawed though it will be-will have a capital structure that will reflect best international practice and will enable a proper balance to be struck and proper judgments to be made in terms of average interest times cover and the debt service ratio in order to enable judgments to be made by way of international comparisons. In that way, we believe that we will be able to make proper assessments from the outset.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this the privatisation clause?

—No. The next amendment, amendment No. 3, is the privatisation clause. Amendment No. 2 is a necessary concomitant of wanting an efficient carrier by whatever means. I would have thought that Senator Schacht would be just as interested in that as we are. It has nothing to do with privatisation as such, but it has everything to do with transparent accounting and enabling outsiders to judge the real worth of the enterprise. Unless we are interested in things such as interest cover, debt equity and debt service ratios, we simply cannot make proper judgments about how stable the enterprise is, what its real gearing ratio is and the like.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that that is very necessary. We also believe that there ought to be proper financial statements tabled in the Parliament prior to the merger so that the community is able to assess the true value of each of the enterprises and to make sensible judgments about how the merger ought to proceed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will oppose this Opposition amendment. We note that the amendment commences by saying that a succession day shall not be fixed unless the Minister satisfies certain requirements on financial papers and figures to be presented. The Australian Democrats believe that that is a fairly transparent device to delay the merger. We want the merger of OTC and Telecom to go ahead, and we do not want it to be delayed unnecessarily by subjecting the Minister to satisfying certain criteria, which we know will take considerable time.

SPEECH.PARA: However, we feel that in part the purpose of this amendment is justified, and our amendments Nos 3 to 7-particularly amendment No. 7-are specifically directed to the matters raised by the Opposition and will sufficiently cover the doubts that the Opposition may have about AOTC's future capital structure and its initial capital base. I conclude by saying that the words to the effect that a succession day shall not be fixed unless the Minister satisfies certain requirements are an obvious ploy to delay the merger as long as possible, and the Democrats oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say by way of reply that Senator Spindler is in fact saying that he does not believe that the capital structure of Telecom and OTC is anywhere near best international practice and that it would take a long time to get it up to that point. I do not accept the proposition, but it is an interesting assertion on his part.
—You only want to get it up so that you can flog it off.

—I would have thought that Senator Schacht would want to get it up as well, because surely it is in his interests to have a sound and stable capital base. That is all that this is about. If he takes the view that because it remains in public hands it does not really matter what the capital structure is, I would have thought that--
—You only want to flog it off.

—That may well be a legitimate objective, but it has nothing to do with this. If Senator Schacht thinks that the only time a company needs to be in shape is when he wants to flog it, this portrays an abysmal ignorance of the commercial realities. I would have thought that, if one wants to make a profit out of a company-as presumably Senator Schacht does; he would rather milk a billion dollars up-front by way of merger fee, but even if he does not get that, no doubt, he will be trying to rip it off through dividend policy-either way there needs to be a structure that maximises returns. I am fascinated to learn from the likes of Senator Schacht that, unless one has privatisation in contemplation, it does not really matter what sort of an outfit it is.
—Just briefly, we believe that these statements should be provided as soon as practicable but that the actual merger should not be made dependent upon them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing this amendment. It is in fact a piece of a transparent privatisation agenda, despite Senator Alston's protestations.
—I thought you guys were in favour of privatisation.

—We are a little more selective about how we apply that policy compared with the broad brush approach that the Liberal ideology compels those opposite to have. I do have quite a lot that I could say about this, but in consideration of the hour and the fact that the Democrats have indicated their opposition to this amendment, I will not.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause 8.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3. Clause 8, page 5, after subclause (3), add the following subclause:
``(4) AOTC may not issue shares, either voting or non-voting, to any person other than the Commonwealth.''.

The amendment seeks to strengthen the Government's purported anti-privatisation clause, clause 8. The Government's proposal successfully prohibits the transfer of any shares to be held in AOTC by the Commonwealth. In addition, the clause ensures that 100 per cent control must remain with the Commonwealth until this Parliament otherwise provides. However, the prohibition on the issuing of new shares by AOTC to anyone other than the Commonwealth is deliberately limited to voting shares. That is, the option of AOTC issuing non-voting shares which would still be eligible for dividends and the owners of which would therefore have an influence and certainly an interest in decisions affecting the company is left open to AOTC. In addition, there is no limitation on the power of the Minister to direct that AOTC issues such non-voting shares.

Yet again, the Government is claiming that retaining 100 per cent control is sufficient to guarantee non-privatisation. The Australian Democrats support retaining the merged telecommunications carrier in full public ownership. Unfortunately, this Bill does not guarantee full public ownership, and I do emphasise ownership. Non-voting shares are obviously contemplated as a future financing option, thereby guaranteeing that the Commonwealth's 100 per cent ownership of the carrier will be diluted. Accordingly, our amendment seeks to remove the power of AOTC to issue shares, whether voting or non-voting, to any person other than the Commonwealth.

Government members should be aware that voting against this amendment means they are voting against the concept of AOTC remaining in 100 per cent public ownership. It should be noted that the same model was used in the Commonwealth Bank privatisation and also in the Commonwealth Funds Management Limited. We managed to convince the Government to tighten the anti-privatisation provisions for the Commonwealth Funds Management company and we urge a similar decision in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this Australian Democrat amendment. It is an extraordinary proposition, considering the wording of the existing clause, to suggest that by not supporting the Democrat amendment, we are contributing to the non-continuation of public ownership in AOTC. Clause 8 as drafted in fact provides more than adequate arrangements to ensure that AOTC remains in full public ownership. The clause is drafted in terms of both ownership and control. Subclause 8(3) (a) is very specific about what gives rise to breaches of the previous subclause, that is, the Commonwealth not holding all of the voting shares in AOTC, and it specifies this:

SPEECH.PARA: The following are examples of things that could give rise to a breach of subsection (2):
(a) the issue by AOTC of voting shares in AOTC to a person other than the Commonwealth;

It is more than adequate in terms of protecting what the Government strongly wishes to do-that is, retain it in public ownership. Therefore, the Democrat amendment is simply completely unnecessary in terms of hardening up the public ownership provisions that are already in clause 8, and the Government will be opposing the amendment.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Spindler's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As rightly identified, this clause is related to privatisation and the Opposition will simply be voting against it.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 5, after the heading ``PART 3-OPERATION OF ATOC'', insert the following clause:
``AOTC not to be bound by Loan Council
9A. Borrowings by AOTC shall not be restricted to total borrowing limits for Commonwealth authorities agreed between the Commonwealth and the States from time to time.''.

This amendment proposes to allow the new carrier to operate in a truly commercial sense. Currently, Telecom's borrowings are limited to that amount which complies with the Loan Council global borrowing limits applicable to the Commonwealth and its instrumentalities. There is no question that this artificial limitation impacts upon the activities of Telecom, and clearly the same problem will apply to the new AOTC.

In its present position Telecom can to some extent cope with such capital starvation and it is not as serious as when the carrier will be in a competitive market, both internally and internationally. Indeed, capital starvation of Telecom appears to have been an integral part of the Government's philosophy of assisting any new competitor well beyond the level of fair competition. Accordingly, this amendment proposes to give AOTC the right to determine its own level of borrowings without the interference of either the Loan Council or the relevant Minister. It is also necessary to specifically disallow the Minister the right to intervene, as if this were not done.

I understand that the Government will not support this amendment. I wish to refer to a report released by the Government after this amendment was prepared. This is a report by the joint Commonwealth-State inquiry into the treatment of government trading enterprises by the Loan Council. The report, entitled Coverage of the Global Approach, establishes some criteria for exemption from the global limits imposed by the Loan Council. The two categories which are to be free of such global limits are, firstly, those entities that operate in a commercial manner, with a demonstrated track record of meeting certain commerciality criteria; and secondly, those that are owned privately to 40 per cent or more-clearly, that is not applicable.

However, other criteria do apply to the new entity. The appropriate commercial framework would involve operating in competition with the private sector; appropriate monitoring arrangements by the owner government; being subject to ordinary government taxes and charges; operating as a public company; and having minimal community service obligations. I would appreciate the Minister's comments on whether these provisions will apply to AOTC and whether the fact that the community service obligations of AOTC are substantial will negate such freedom from the global limits of the Loan Council.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The new organisation will have more than the minimal community service obligations. That is one of the reasons why it is not appropriate to support this amendment. I must say with some degree of feeling that the Government strongly opposes this amendment, considers it to be a irresponsible amendment, and feels that it is astonishing for the Democrats to have moved it. Obviously, Telecom has a place in the hearts of the Australian Democrats that no other organisation holds in terms of the extraordinary breadth of this proposed amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Spindler has talked about putting Telecom on a normal commercial basis. Can I assure Senator Spindler that there is not a single company operating in the private sector-certainly none as big as Telecom, and it is big-that would abrogate its financial responsibilities in the way Senator Spindler is suggesting the Government should in the operations of what will continue to be a publicly operated company. I find the amendment, in terms of the basic philosophy of the Democrats as I understand it, to be breathtaking in what it is proposing for Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no such thing as a Democrat philosophy.

—I disagree with Senator Kemp; I think there is such a thing as a Democrat philosophy. In so far as I understand it, I find this an extraordinary amendment. Obviously Telecom has some special licence in the minds of the Democrats that no other organisation has. I can assure Senator Spindler in terms of his comments about commercial realities and commercial practice that there is not a company in the private sector which a major shareholder or holding company would allow to operate in the way that Senator Spindler is suggesting that Telecom does-in this totally unfettered way; that we simply wash our hands, as the shareholder on behalf of the Australian public, with regard to how this organisation behaves from now on. It is an extraordinary amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: We are talking about public money and a publicly owned utility. The Opposition may well have-and, indeed, does have-differences within and from the Government as to how it would operate it. It has indicated that it has a substantially different view. But whilst it remains a public company, rightly or wrongly-and no doubt the Opposition will continue to protest it-I would be astonished if the Opposition would wear this extraordinary amendment. The viability and efficiency--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have made your point.

—I must say that I have been extremely restrained this evening, and I think responsible, considering the hour. But this is an amendment which needs to be defeated and very briefly-and it will be very briefly-I intend to address that. If the Loan Council controls were removed the Government would need to consider the removal of corresponding government guarantees over Telecom borrowings. Removal of the guarantees would cause serious difficulties for Telecom, particularly because its international credit ratings would fall as a result. As I have said--

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Kemp interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp may consider this a matter of great levity, but it is a serious debate and it has been conducted seriously until this point. It is an amendment which must be defeated and I must say again that it is very difficult to understand the Democrats' philosophy in even proposing it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be very pleased to accede to the Minister's wishes if he decided to place all privately owned companies under the controls of the Loan Council as well. But what we have here is a company that is to operate commercially in the marketplace, yet the Government obviously wants to continue its policy of hamstringing that public utility by starving it of capital. That is the reason for our amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. Clause 9, page 5, after subclause (2), insert the following subclause:
``(2A) The Minister must not give a direction under subsection (1) in relation to the amounts to be borrowed from time to time by AOTC.''.
This amendment simply extends the precaution that we wanted to take through the previous amendment by not permitting the Minister to subvert the regulations. I have nothing further to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is precisely what it does and the Government will be opposing it for the reasons I have already given.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6. Clause 9, page 6, after subclause (7), insert the following subclause:

``(8) The Minister must cause a copy of the memorandum of association and articles of association of AOTC to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the later of:
(a) the commencement of this section; or
(b) the incorporation of AOTC.''.

This amendment requires the Minister to cause a copy of the memorandum of association and articles of association of AOTC to be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after whichever is the later-the commencement of this proposed section or the incorporation of AOTC. The Australian Democrats believe that is a reasonable requirement which is well in keeping with the level of control that should be exercised over AOTC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment is not strictly necessary because the constituent documents that are involved here are required to be lodged with the Australian Securities Commission and by that being done they will, of necessity, become public documents. But the Government will not be opposing this Democrat amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 10 and 11-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 7. After clause 11, page 6, line 23, add the following clause:
Determination of AOTC's Initial Capital
``11A. (1) The Minister shall as soon as practicable after the commencement of this Act and after consultation with the Board, determine the amount of AOTC's initial capital under this Act.
(2) In making this determination, the Minister shall have regard to any relevant advice that the Board has given to the Minister.
(3) A determination made under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.''.

This amendment seeks to compel the Minister, after consultation with the board, to reveal the amount of AOTC's initial capital under this Act. This amendment will also make such a determination by the Minister a disallowable instrument which will enable the Parliament to review AOTC's capital structure. We think this is an important issue. We have the example of Qantas Airways Ltd and Australian Airlines which have been starved of cash by this Government, and the type of telephone service that domestic telephone users receive will be very much dependent on Telecom's liquidity and cash flow.

At the moment we are being asked to vote for a merged company that we know very little about. I think a parliamentary review of AOTC's capital structure to the extent that we are talking about the initial capital is a very little thing to ask as shareholders in the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth is a major shareholder and Australians are major shareholders. We all have a right to have some insight into AOTC's financial resources, and this is similar to the line the Opposition has been pursuing in other amendments here this evening.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment by the Australian Democrats is not supported by the Government.

—It is desirable that the Minister should support that amendment. I would have thought it would happen in any event. I would be interested in knowing the reason why the Government would quarrel with the proposition, unless somehow it takes the view that it is more a matter for the board than the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, because of the hour, I had not canvassed the reasons because they have in fact already been publicly canvassed in relation to an earlier amendment by the Opposition; I think it was new clause 7a which was in similar terms. In commenting on that amendment, the Government stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government will give full and proper consideration to the advice it receives from the interim board on the financial aspects of the merger. It fully appreciates the need to ensure the new company commences operations with a sound capital base. If it were to be demonstrated that the likely financial ratios of the new company were inadequate, capital injection may of course not be the only remedy. Consideration should also be given to what alternative financial or business strategies might be available to achieve improvement in these ratios.
To reinforce the point-and I think I will probably conclude at this point--
Senator Lewis interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I was asked to expand by Senator Lewis's colleague. I cannot satisfy everybody on the Opposition and he is the spokesperson in this chamber. To conclude, I will quote again from Minister Beazley on this point, when he replied to a question without notice probably from the shadow Minister in the House of Representatives on 4 June. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the profitability of Telecom last year was well over $1 billion and when it will have added to it another company-
AOTC-
with a profitability of around $300m.
The Minister noted:
Such companies are not in any sense, shape or form in trouble.
The Minister concluded:
Telecom is in good shape; it will be in better shape, and it will be an effective competitor in the communications regime that will kick off towards the end of this year.
So, for those reasons, we do not believe it is appropriate for this matter to be subject to disallowance again by the chamber, as is proposed by subclause (3) of this Australian Democrats' amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very disingenuous explanation, given the Minister's refusal to explain on the first occasion. It seems to me that we have heard nothing to indicate why it is that the amount of the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation's initial capital should not be determined by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to clear the record. I do not want to engage in tedious or repetitious debate, but there was no refusal by me to provide an explanation. As I have already said, the explanation has been provided on a number of occasions by Mr Beazley. In view of the hour, I thought it was unnecessary to go through it again.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4. After clause 11, page 6, line 23, add the following clause:
Merger fee not to be charged
``11a. No fee, payment or consideration shall be paid or payable by Telecom, OTC or AOTC to the Government as a result of or in connection with the merger of Telecom and OTC to create AOTC.''.

The proposition, simply put, is this: it is an entirely artificial concept to suggest that one publicly owned body ought to take money from another. It is about as specious as the attempt by the Victorian Government to have a transfer from the State Government Insurance Office to the Transport Accident Commission and somehow to pretend that was a sale of assets for which money ought to change hands. This is nothing more or less than a means of taking a very substantial sum of money out of the system.

Senator Richardson has already let the cat out of the bag. The Government thinks it can raise up to $1 billion by way of a merger fee. It is entirely artificial. It is up-front, off the top, unrelated to performance, and unrelated to the amount of dividend that may be payable. It is a very effective means of crippling an organisation if the Government simply is in the business of wanting to add to its coffers. It gives the Government carte blanche in this respect. It is a thoroughly bad proposition.

If the Government were fair dinkum it would be looking at the bottom line to see what amount could be responsibly paid out by way of dividends to the shareholders. But to somehow pretend that one arm of government can charge another arm of government up to $1 billion is an absolute nonsense. I would have thought, for a whole range of reasons, that everyone would see this for what it is-an attempt by the Government to get some money while it can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will be supporting this Opposition amendment. We think we could give 50 good reasons why the merger fee should not go ahead, but because of the hour I will give just a few. The first is because the Government snuck it in without telling anyone it had any intention of doing it. I think that is dishonest. We see no reason why the Government should use Telecom to fund railways, as Senator Schacht suggested at the last sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: I took the trouble to look up the allocation by this Government to the railways. In its whole history this Government has spent less than the Fraser Government spent in its last year. It is preposterous to think that, as well as putting in all the telecommunications infrastructure, Telecom should now provide all the rail infrastructure for this country.
Another reason is that we want to indicate to the Government that it cannot use this new GBE or any new GBE as a milch cow whenever it wants to meet a Budget surplus--

TALK.START.PARA: —Or deficit.

—Or deficit. We also oppose this merger fee because AOTC is a company which will need Government financial support to become the global competitor that the Minister claims is the whole basis for this legislation. Another reason is that AOTC will be the universal service provider to most Australian households and this merger fee should not be used as some kind of bargaining chip with our money. This merger fee represents a second tax on consumers, who have already paid $3,500 per household to establish both Telecom and OTC.

SPEECH.PARA: We want the Government to be open about the ruinous financial losses of Aussat instead of using the merger fee as a cover-up. It is interesting that Aussat's liabilities also amount to about $1 billion. We will not join the Government in attempting to deceive the Australian people over the importance and the purpose of this merger fee. We are not going to provide an artificial boost to a Budget position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly cannot allow those imputations of `deceit', `deception' and `the Government sneaking it in'. What a piece of arrant nonsense- `The Government snuck this in'. Senator Kernot may well object to it, but the Government explicitly announced that it would do this--
—Brazenly.

—Correct; I thank Senator Alston. I cannot understand where this business of `sneaking it in' came from. It was explicitly contained in the major statement on telecommunications reform that was tabled in the House of Representatives on 8 November last year. Page 9 of the document reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The new entity will pay to the Government a fee as a result of the merger.
I am not sure what Senator Kernot would call `sneaking it in'.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much did you have in mind?

—I imagine that the shadow spokesperson for telecommunications has some obligation to read the documents that are tabled on that specific matter in the House. The Government did not sneak it in; it announced it on 8 November last year.

SPEECH.PARA: The potential quantum might be objected to, but the arrangement of government entities paying other government entities fees for services rendered is commonplace. The Government is determined that a merger fee will be paid by the merged entity. Advice on the nature of the form of that fee is awaited from the interim board. Any attempt to prohibit the payment of the fee would be contrary to stated Government policy, and it is therefore unacceptable to the Government. By reason of the indications I have already received, I will not prolong the argument any further than that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My name was mentioned in the debate because of my contribution to the second reading debate. If anyone listened to the publicity of the special conference of the Australian Labor Party in September last year, they would know that it was a matter of considerable public debate that there would be a merger fee, that there would be money raised from asset sales-it was fully fledged in the debate-and that it would be used for infrastructure investment, including rail.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it astonishing that the Australian Democrats have fallen for the three-card trick with the Opposition. The reason the Opposition is opposed to the merger fee is very simple: it wants to keep Telecom, or the new merged entity, as cashed up as possible because it will get a better price for it when it tries to privatise it. That is exactly why it wants the money kept. Whatever the amount of money is, it wants it kept in so that it can flog it off at a higher price.

I find it extraordinary for Senator Alston to say that there is something unusual about asking for a fee for a merger of two government entities when the Opposition will be more than happy to get every possible cent out of it when it tries to flog it off privately, when it tries to sell it; it will not give it away.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would not be from an artificial merger.

—The Opposition would try to get back as much as possible. That is why it does not want the merger fee. What it has proposed is extremely transparent. It wants to keep it as cashed up as possible and then flog it off, yet it thinks this is unreasonable when two bodies merge. If it were in the private sector, there would be a fee for that merger. It would be quite reasonable. Senator Alston, as a supporter of the private sector, would be arguing very strongly for it. It is transparent why the Opposition is opposed to it. The Opposition wants the cash left in the new carrier so that whenever it gets into government-whenever that may be-it can try to flog it off, get a bigger price for it and use it to give tax cuts elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clauses 12 to 23-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 24.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 5. Clause 24, page 10, line 35, omit ``, or the regulations otherwise provide''.

This amendment is simply to cover the situation that the Australian and Overseas Telecommunications Corporation is taken, for the purposes of various laws of the Commonwealth, State or Territory, not to have been incorporated or established for public purpose, except in so far as a law of the Commonwealth, State or Territory might provide. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —One thing one can say about all the Bills in this package is that they are certainly not in plain English. This is one that contains the double negative in that it says that AOTC will not be a public authority and not be entitled to other powers, with an exception. The exception is covered by a law of the State or Territory, as the case may be or, as Senator Alston has pointed out, as the regulations otherwise provide. The Opposition is seeking to remove those last words so that the exemptions can be made only by way of amendments to this legislation and not by way of regulation, which can only be allowed or disallowed without amendment. We will be supporting the Opposition amendment to this clause, as we will to clause 27, which also seeks to remove the words `or the regulations', and for the same reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 24 also appears to exempt AOTC from the operations of the Australian Heritage Commission Act. The Government has indicated elsewhere and informally that the Heritage Commission Act will continue to apply to AOTC. I would like to know from the Minister exactly how this will be achieved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is consistent with Government policy for the organisation to be covered by the Australian Heritage Commission Act. —In other words, a consequential amendment would be necessary if regulations were taken out; or we must rely on the Minister's assurance that regulations will be passed to make this apply.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure Senator Coulter that I do not lightly insert statements like that into Hansard. That was the very purpose for stating it; it is on the record. It is the intention of the Government to do that. If the Opposition amendment is carried, we will not have the means by which we can do it. I make that statement quite clearly on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems a rather peculiar way of going around this. I am not sure whether Senator Alston has been listening, but the general provision of exceptions by way of regulation is certainly something we would support. That is the intent of the Opposition's amendment. If the Australian Heritage Commission Act is inadvertently caught by this, I would certainly seek-and it is difficult to do it at this time of night on one's feet-to include the operation of that Act, but still exclude the exceptions by way of regulation in terms of other Acts.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that means making a further amendment on the run but I certainly seek permission to have a look at that. I guess that would mean deferring consideration of clause 24 for a few moments so that we could have an amendment drafted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in the hands of the Committee on this. I understand precisely what the Democrats are concerned about. I am anxious to accommodate both the Opposition and the Democrats. The Democrats can correct me if I am wrong, but as I understand it they wish to support the Opposition amendment to delete the reference to regulation but want to ensure at the same time that the AOTC is subject to the Australian Heritage Commission Act. That will need a subsequent amendment, of course. I am perfectly happy to accommodate the Democrats in whatever way is practicable. We are happy to get an amendment containing that provision. SPEECH.PARA: Senator McMullan has come up with an even more brilliant idea, which I am happy to give Senator Coulter an assurance on now. The simplest way would be to proceed. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am only too well aware of the lateness of the hour but, given that we are in the last week of sitting, I would like to say a few words about a few things. I could not allow this session to pass without impressing on the Senate the works of a very active group of people dedicated to saving an old house for the future of our children and for the benefit of childhood dreams.

SPEECH.PARA: I doubt that there would be many, if any, in this place who are not familiar with the delightful works of May Gibbs. Gumnut Babies and Snugglepot and Cuddlepie brought to life the seeds of the Australian bush. Who could look at a gumnut or a mountain devil seed after reading or having had May Gibbs stories read to them and not see gumnut babies and the dancing lucky devil?

In order to preserve that very special part of Australian children's literature and its history, some years ago the May Gibbs Foundation established a fund to save Nutcote-May Gibbs' home-from the hands of developers and the dozers.

Over the years small, and not so small, donations have helped to raise nearly one-third of the $2.8m needed to ensure that Nutcote remains part of Australia's history. North Sydney Council has given $600,000. In a period of our history when government has given billions of dollars to build football fields, when million-dollar bribes and kickbacks seem rife, when fund-raisers for certain political parties can collect $1m from a luncheon for a few close friends, it ought not to be so difficult to find a kindly benefactor to help save such a worthy cause.

When one painting can be bought for $78m, what is $1m for an entire house full of history? One does not have to be a millionaire to be part of this wonderful project. The Nutcote trust has done its homework and subscriptions can be bought for $20. Donations over $2 are tax deductible. It seems somehow misplaced that people can pay sizeable amounts of money to visit places such as Dream World and Movie World to see imitations of the real thing when here we have a part of Australian childhood history begging to be saved. Members of the May Gibbs Foundation are to be commended for the work they do. They are not dreamers; they realise that once having saved Nutcote it must earn its keep, and they plan that Nutcote will play host to a wide range of educational and creative activities for children.

This is an opportunity for all Australians to invest in their children's future and to ensure that the memories of their childhood are protected. One of the things Australia misses is its link with history and the people of repute who have made contributions in the past and to have their memories kept forever. Other parts of the world remember their past so that they can prepare for their future. Why do we not support worthy causes such as the May Gibbs Foundation? I believe we should. I commend the Nutcote project and implore all honourable senators to support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Brownhill, I do not think it is unreasonable at 1.35 a.m. to thank you for that contribution, and to invite Senator Crichton-Browne to make his.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to raise the issue of the recent positive test of Australian cyclist Martin Vinnicombe. He was tested on 25 May by the Canadian anti-doping authority at the request of the Australian Sports Drug Agency while he was in Pennsylvania, United States of America. It was no accident that the request was made that he be tested and no great shock, I suspect, to informed bodies that he tested positive to stenolozol, a form of anabolic steroid.

SPEECH.PARA: He was able to be tested because of a reciprocal arrangement between Great Britain, Australia and Canada that does not prevail in respect of a number of countries, including the United States. We could not have got him tested by the United States. It is also of material consequence to observe that Great Britain, Australia and Canada all have independent sports drug testing agencies that are not creatures and captives of sporting officials.

The Australian Amateur Cycling Federation has banned Martin Vinnicombe for a period of two years. He tested positive at an International Olympic Committee accredited laboratory in Montreal and has been suspended for two years by the amateur cycling body in Australia. To my knowledge, the professional cycling association of Australia has not yet imposed a penalty. One would hope that it will also impose a reciprocal penalty. What is somewhat disturbing is that the penalty of the international body in such cases is a three-months suspension or a fine. One can have one's suspended period at any time one wishes during the 12 months. Presumably a professional athlete will take his suspension in the lay-off period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Christmas Day.

—Absolutely. That shows the absolute absurdity of the situation. I believe there was a time-it may still be the case-when most of the professional cycling bodies would add a second or two to athletes' times; in other words, there was a handicap. I suppose that was an incentive to take a few more anabolic steroids in order to make up the difference so that athletes could make themselves competitive again, but that is how it worked.

SPEECH.PARA: Two things flow from this test. First, it shows that, in countries with which Australia has reciprocal agreements, no Australian athlete is safe to cheat or is immune to testing either during training or during competition. Of course, that raises the question which both Senator Baume and I have raised before: the United States, for instance, does not have such a testing system because it cannot yet test all of its own athletes. As members of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts predicted in its excellent report-which I recommend to honourable senators-when it drew this material fact to the attention of the public, as long as Australia has an effective testing authority and until there is equally diligent testing in other parts of the world, Australian athletes will be disadvantaged. They will be disadvantaged to the extent that they do not cheat while athletes from other countries still can. Therefore it is imperative that other sporting nations bring themselves into line with the giant steps forward made by Australian sport to ensure that their athletes compete on an even playing field with each other under all circumstances. As I said, they do not presently do so with all other athletes.

Secondly, this test shows the gulf in integrity between a number of professional sports and a number of amateur sports. Martin Vinnicombe can now turn professional and pedal and compete for a more obvious material reward without suffering a penalty for cheating, as he was proven to have done very recently. I should also say that full credit should go to the Canadians. They had Martin Vinnicombe's urine sample within five hours of the demand for his sample being made. I heard Martin Vinnicombe say in an interview that he thought there had been a gap of eight days; I do not know where he got that time from. If I remember correctly, he also said that there was a gap of 28 days from the time he took the anabolic steroid to the time he was tested, and he could not understand how he had tested positive. For somebody who is as well informed about taking drugs and not getting caught as Martin Vinnicombe is, I am surprised that he did not know that an injected oil-based substance would remain in his body not for 28 days but for a great deal longer. I suspect that he did not imagine he would be competing again in Australia in the near future and would therefore be subject to testing.

Having drawn the distinction between the professional conduct and the diligent penalties applied by amateur sporting bodies generally, I refer to the fact that Martin Vinnicombe, for example, was used to advertise the virtues of a brand of glucose drink. That advertisement sought to demonstrate that, because Martin Vinnicombe took that glucose drink, he was a champion. Clearly, when champion athletes such as Martin Vinnicombe are used as role models for young people it shows the impression such champions can have on the attitude and the outlook of young people. I urge the Government therefore to raise significantly the global amount spent by Australian taxpayers on sport. Something like $64m of Australian taxpayers' money presently goes on sport, and that is why some of us suspect that we have thoroughly socialised sport in Australia.

Of the budget of $64m, something like 10 per cent of the Australian Sports Drug Agency's budget, or $200,000, is spent on education. In other words, of the $64m that we spend for gold-Senator Baume had something to say about that in his notice of motion this afternoon-only $200,000 goes towards educating young people that it is wrong to cheat. I hope that the Government does something about that.

I conclude by saying that the Australian Sports Drug Agency, which is an independent body set up under legislation-very much thanks to the efforts of the Senate Committee and the barracking of the Opposition-demonstrates the effectiveness of an independent body. It also demonstrates its capacity to sort out the cheats from the genuine athletes and to be able to clearly draw that distinction for the benefit of the public and all athletes.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 18 February 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is the Oestrogen Patch, which has been proven to prevent acute symptoms of menopause and also decrease the risk of heart disease and of fractures as a result of osteoporosis, not yet available to the women of Australia, even though it is available in 31 countries including the United Kingdom, the United States and New Zealand.
(2) Did the company manufacturing `Estraderm' apply in March 1987 for evaluation and registration for the patch.
(3) Was the prototype altered to stop the patch wrinkling, and did this involve a medical change.

(4) Was the company advised in September 1989 by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee that although it accepted that the performance of `Estraderm' in the body is the same for the improved product, the company must apply again for the modified product.
(5) Was a further appeal by the company rejected, and although the company submitted new data in March 1990 for the modified product, has no decision been made.

(6) Was the evaluation time before the product was released in the United Kingdom 21 months, in the USA 25 months and in New Zealand 7 months; if so why is this product, essential for the quality of life for so many Australian women, being denied to them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The `Estraderm' oestrogen patch, that is designed to be applied to the skin and deliver a predetermined dose of oestradiol, has recently been provisionally recommended for approval by the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee (ADEC), provided all outstanding quality and product information issues are resolved.

ADEC, as an independent committee of experts, advises the Minister as to whether a product should be marketed in Australia. In reaching its decision the Committee considers the quality, safety and efficacy of the product and makes a risk benefit decision.

ADEC has not previously recommended approval for this oestrogen patch, despite having considered the matter on eight occasions since December 1988, as the Committee was not satisfied with the data on quality, safety and efficacy that were submitted by the company.

(3) The prototype was altered, apparently to try to stop wrinkling, and this did involve a change significant enough to cause concern at the possibility of a different clinical effect from that seen in trials presented using the other patch systems.

(4) No, ADEC did not, as such, accept that `the performance of `Estraderm' in the body is the same for the improved product'. The company was requested to supply data on the patch intended for use in Australia or to identify, if possible, use of this patch in any trials submitted.

(5) The product `Estraderm' has been reviewed by ADEC on eight occasions since December 1988. On each occasion a decision was made, whether it be to recommend denying the marketing application, rejecting on appeal or, at the last meeting, provisionally recommending approval. In each case these decisions were based on the data and arguments submitted by the company.

(6) I cannot comment on overseas evaluation times without any evidence to support the information supplied. Nor do I believe it is necessarily appropriate to compare evaluation times for what were different products and different data packages, depending on the company's decisions at the time. The `Estraderm' patch was first considered by ADEC 21 months after receipt of the application in the Department of Community Services and Health.

I wish to emphasise that no Australian woman who has medically needed the oestrogen patch has been denied access to it. The patch has been available under the Individual Patient Usage Scheme for some years. I should also like to emphasise that there are other forms of oestrogen available on the market, that have previously been assessed and found satisfactory as regards quality, safety and efficacy.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: James Cook University of North Queensland

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 14 March 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Were meetings of a joint State and Federal Committee, to discuss funding for the construction of the first building at the Cairns campus site of James Cook University of North Queensland (JCUNQ), due to commence at the beginning of February.
(2) Have these meetings been delayed because the Federal Government has sought further information from the Queensland Government before meetings take place; if so:
(a) can the Minister advise what material the Federal Government asked the Queensland Government to supply before meetings proceed;
(b) why was additional information from the Queensland Government necessary, prior to any discussions on funding, for building work at the Cairns campus of JCUNQ;
(c) on what date(s) were any requests for further information made to the Queensland Government; and
(d) has all the information requested now been received.
(3) If the meetings have not been delayed due to a request for further information from the Queensland Government, what has caused the delay in the commencement of meetings.
(4) Will the Government require any additional information from the Queensland Government, or any other source, before meetings can proceed.
(5) On what date will meetings commence; if no date has been set, when will the Federal Government be in a position to commence discussions with the Committee.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) In its Report on Higher Education Funding for the 1991-93 Triennium released in November 1990, the Commonwealth Government announced that a joint Commonwealth/State/JCUNQ Working Party was being formed to oversee longer term planning for higher education provision in Cairns in the light of a detailed study of the nature and level of demand.

The Working Party had its first meeting in December 1990. It decided that JCUNQ should document its planning projections for the Cairns site and a memorandum of agreement relating to the joint usage by the University and TAFE of facilities in Cairns, should be prepared.

The Queensland Office of Higher Education agreed to oversee the development of the memorandum of agreement and sought the views of the two institutions on matters to be addressed in such an agreement.

The Office of Higher Education also asked JCUNQ to provide data on the size and nature of the demand for places in Cairns and the surrounding region, the array of offerings presently available and planned in future, student load projections in the light of likely growth scenarios for the University in the next four years and the funding available to support them.

The Working Party met in Cairns on 10 May 1991. It received and considered submissions provided by JCUNQ (which included the data requested by the Office of Higher Education); the local students and a Cairns community group (Far North Queensland Higher Education and Training Working Group).

The three principal parties, i.e. the Commonwealth, the State and James Cook University agreed on the planning basis for a new campus for Cairns. The proposed development is consistent with the community's submission.
Decisions on Commonwealth funding to support this development will be announced in November 1991, along with other decisions on funding for the 1992-94 triennium.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 10 April 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Estraderm patch, which is used for hormone replacement therapy in women, assist in preventing osteoporosis; if so, is the patch considered safe for women who may have had breast cancer or who are considered in the high risk category.
(2) What options are there to stave off osteoporosis for women who cannot take any of the hormone replacement therapy now available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Estraderm patch has been provisionally recommended for approval as hormone replacement therapy in post-menopausal women provided outstanding chemistry and quality control issues are resolved. Due to lack of any evidence of efficacy, the Estraderm patch is not approved for the prevention of osteoporosis.
Caution is advised with the use of all oestrogens in women who have had breast cancer or who are considered in the high risk category.

(2) The area of prevention and treatment of osteoporosis is receiving a great deal of ongoing research attention around the world. It is, therefore, not possible to recommend any particular therapy as a definitive treatment at the present time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 7 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the terms of the cease-fire agreement in place with Iraq and does the agreement include any monitoring of the sale of arms to Iraq.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: UN Security Council Resolution 687 of 3 April 1991 made provision for a formal ceasefire between Iraq and Kuwait and the member states cooperating with Kuwait in accordance with earlier resolutions of the Security Council, subject to Iraqi agreement to a number of conditions set out in Resolution 687.

Iraq notified its acceptance in writing of the terms of Resolution 687 to the UN Secretary General on 6 April and this was accepted by the Security Council on 11 April. The ceasefire has therefore been in force since that date.

The terms and conditions of Resolution 687 are very detailed, and a copy will be made available to Senator Jones. In relation to the sale of arms to Iraq, the Resolution makes the following specific provisions:

Decides that ``all States shall continue to prevent the sale or supply, or promotion or facilitation of such sale or supply, to Iraq by their nationals, or from their territories or using their flag vessels or aircraft, of arms and related materiel of all types'', including conventional weapons and also related technology and personnel (op. para. 24).

Requests the Secretary General to develop, within 60 days, a set of guidelines to facilitate these measures, and calls upon all States to act strictly in accordance with op. para. 24 in maintaining national controls to ensure compliance with the Secretary General's guidelines (op. paras. 25-27).
A continuing maritime monitoring capability will be required in the Persian Gulf to enable the UN to check compliance with sanctions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 16 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Department of Defence set down fundamental standards of behaviour for its service personnel visiting overseas ports.
(2) Does the department provide counselling on responsible sexual practices in foreign countries.
(3) Are condoms issued for shore leave.
(4) Are similar guarantees received by the department from other nations' navies visiting Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Standards of behaviour of service personnel are largely governed by the Defence Force Discipline Act (DFDA). Developing good standards of behaviour commences with initial training, where the standards laid down in the DFDA are rigorously imposed. Ongoing training emphasises expected social standards and includes drug and alcohol awareness and character guidance. When visiting a foreign port, the civil law of the country being visited also applies to all service personnel.

(2) Prior to a ship's arrival in a foreign port, sailors will be lectured on the social and religious customs of the country being visited, and will be briefed on expected standards of behaviour and responsible sexual practices accordingly.
(3) Condoms are available to all personnel aboard a ship visiting a foreign port.

(4) The Department of Defence does not inquire into the practices of foreign warships visiting Australian ports, although it is expected that similar standards apply to foreign vessels as would apply to Australian naval vessels visiting ports overseas. A liaison officer assigned to the visiting ship will advise the ship's Commanding Officer when it is requested. Visiting ships are required to complete the usual quarantine forms, and are specifically asked if any of the crew carry infectious diseases.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 16 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister advise as to any findings from the inquiry by the Bureau of Air Safety into the crash of an MU2 aircraft at Leonora on 16 December 1988.
(2) If the inquiry has not been completed, what are the reasons for the delay and when is the inquiry expected to finish.
(3) What extra conditions have been applied to the use of such aircraft in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The accident was subject to a detailed examination by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI). While no positive reasons for the accident were determined, it was considered that aircraft icing and/or pilot training and experience were possible factors. A series of recommendations aimed at reducing the likelihood of similar accidents was forwarded to the Civil Aviation Authority. Unfortunately, these recommendations had not been put in place before the accident to another MU2 at Meekatharra in January 1990.

(2) BASI is currently producing a report which will incorporate details of its investigations into both accidents. This report will also document the results of an extensive research study undertaken by the Bureau into the high altitude flying characteristics and performance capability of the MU2. The report is expected to be available for public distribution before the end of August 1991.

(3) The Civil Aviation Authority has been kept fully informed during the progress of the investigations, and has instituted a range of procedures for operators and pilots of the MU2 aircraft type. These included increasing the minimum experience and training requirements before a pilot is permitted to operate the aircraft. Restrictions were also placed on operations in icing conditions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The introduction of the Falcon 900 resulted in a reduction of No 34 Squadron's establishment from 184 to 128 positions, a saving of 56 positions. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 21 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to earlier enquiries concerning the reported disappearance on 8 October 1990 of two Timorese students, Emilio Pereira and Nazario Magno, of Belide High School in Dili:
(1) Have any further enquiries been made of independent sources.
(2) Have such enquiries confirmed or denied the disappearance of the two students.
(3) Was the Australian Parliamentary delegation informed of the reported disappearance of the students; if so, did they make enquiries concerning their whereabouts and well-being.
(4) Did embassy staff have time, in their busy schedule during the Parliamentary visit, to make enquiries.
(5) Will the Minister ask the Indonesian Government:
(a) if it is true that Emilio Pereira was held by Indonesian authorities and has now been released;
(b) if it is true that Nazario Magno is still in custody; and
(c) if any charges have been laid or convictions upheld against either of the students.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Embassy Staff have made repeated enquiries through independent non-government sources in Dili and Jakarta.
(2) Such enquiries have not revealed any information relating to the apparent disappearances which Senator Spindler has raised.

(3) The Australian Parliamentary delegation which visited East Timor as part of a wider visit to Indonesia from 3-11 February this year was thoroughly briefed on the human rights situation in that province though not on a case by case basis. However the answer to the fourth part of Senator Spindler's question is relevant to this point.

(4) Embassy officers accompanying the Parliamentary delegation did make enquiries through independent sources in East Timor. These enquiries were later followed up by Embassy officers with Timor-based sources visiting Jakarta. None of these enquiries have revealed any record of the alleged disappearances.

(5) I would not propose raising this matter with the Indonesian authorities. In my letter to Senator Spindler in February this year, I explained that the Australian Government's long term credibility as an advocate for human rights in Indonesia is best maintained by restricting ourselves to those cases where we have reasonably specific details of what occurred and where there has been some confirmation of the allegations by independent sources. As indicated by the responses to the first, second and fourth parts of Senator Spindler's question, repeated enquiries have not provided any confirmation of the alleged disappearances.
The Government will continue to monitor closely the human rights situation in East Timor, as in other parts of Indonesia, and make representations where appropriate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 21 May 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to the November 1990 accident involving a Macchi 326H of 76 Squadron crashing after the loss of a wing:
(1) Why did the wing fall off.
(2) What action was taken with regard to the remaining Macchi aircraft.
(3) Were any other Macchis found to have structural faults similar to those which resulted in the November 1990 crash.
(4) Have any operational restrictions been placed on the remaining Macchis.
(5) What actions, if any, need to be taken to ensure the flight worthiness of the remaining Macchis and what is the estimated cost of such actions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The wing separated from the aircraft as a result of structural failure induced by metal fatigue.

(2) The remaining Macchi aircraft were grounded until the aircraft wreckage was recovered from the sea and the cause of the structural failure conclusively established. Inspections were then conducted on the remaining aircraft. Those aircraft with no cracking were returned to service.

(3) During the inspection, four other Macchi wings were found to have cracking in the same general area as that on the crashed aircraft. The configuration and location of these cracks required that two of these wings be withdrawn from service. The cracking in the remaining two wings does not constitute a threat to aircraft airworthiness and will be routinely monitored in service.
(4) No operational restrictions have been placed on the remaining Macchi aircraft.

(5) Remaining Macchi aircraft will require periodic inspection of the wing structure to ensure continued airworthiness. The estimated cost of this recurrent inspection is between 1.5 and 2.0 manyears per year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 June 1991 (Hansard, page 4152), Senator Walters asked a question concerning the reduction in the spouse income threshold under Austudy. She also noted that the Austudy parental income threshold had increased.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Until this year the income threshold under AUSTUDY for both parental income and spouse's income was fixed at the same level, rising in accordance with indexation on an annual basis. In 1990 the threshold was $18,150.
In January 1991 the parental income threshold was increased to $19,300 in accordance with the indexing principle. The spouse income test threshold, however, was lowered from $18,150 to $12,150.

The reduction in the spouse income test threshold was made to bring AUSTUDY conditions closer to those available to the unemployed and to ensure that assistance is directed to students most in need. It is reasonable to assume that a student would have more access to a spouse's income for their personal needs than to parents' income.

Even after the reduction of the spouse income threshold to $12,150, the income test for married AUSTUDY recipients continues to be more liberal than the income test for married unemployment benefit recipients. A student loses $1 of AUSTUDY for every $2 earned by the spouse above the threshold of $12,150, which means a spouse can earn up to $24,733 in the previous year before the student's assistance cuts out. In addition the student can earn up to $4,000 in the calendar year of study before the student's AUSTUDY entitlement is reduced.
